div.head: The PREFACE to the Reader.
div.p:
ALtho' I have mot commonly found the Pretenders to New-Light, and rare Inventions (o common now a-Days) no more but Pretenders; yet having omething of Curioity, hall I call it, or Vanity, to be Inquiitive for Truth in uch Pretenions; the noie of a New-Light of Chirurgery, and a New Method of Phyick Built upon Principles directly contrary to, and overthrowing all whatoever has been done by the whole World of Phyicians, could not but excite in me an Attention, and caue me to enquire into the Truth of uch a Report. But when I had Read over one or two of thoe Books which at length gave occaion and Matter to the following Dicoure (tho' they contain omething, I confes very ncommon) I found nothing which could give me the leat Stomach to another Meal of the ame, or Appetite to any New-Dih, afterwards preented by the ame Author. I had found his Sawce owr enough, and the Dihes Garnih'd with Oranges and Lemons; but the Meat it elf o Raw and Inipid, I et it by as a ort of tuff I had for ever enough of. But ometime ince, convering with divers Perons having little, or no Skill in Medicinal Cookery, and finding them highly Commend as choie Viands, thoe things which I knew would be but of bad Digetion, and very apt to breed ill Humours: And conidering that it becomes an Honet and Generous Phyician, as well to Advie what things may preerve, or be prejudicial to the Health of his Neighbours, as to heal their Dieaes; I begun to think, whether I was not oblig'd in Duty to Mankind, as well to Dicover the evil Practice of another, as to labour to act rightly my elf. And foramuch as I know, an nreaonable and Rah Method of Phyick, tho' it hurts not Phyicians, may more than endanger the Lives and Healths of the People, tho' not in the Theory, yet in the Practice which is made upon them, I was perwaded once more to Read over what I had before been ated with, and what farther has been offer'd by the Author of the pretended New-Method, and to trancribe, and make ome Remarks upon ome of the chief Things whereby he endeavours to perawde the Truth of what he calls his New-Hypotheis: Which when I had done, I could not but yet more admire what it was in this Author, that Perons of any Literature and Sene, whether Young Phyicians, or Gentlemen found o taking; omething very ncommon, as I aid, there is. But what? < in non-Latin alphabet > , CONFIDENCE the ign of Ignorance of Art, as the Noble <>
Cous aies: Yet which methinks is trangely accounted now-a-days o great a Qualification, and particularly in a Phyician, that it can attone for, Yes, and et off, all the Imperfections, and Deformities of bad Language, want of Reaon, Reiterated Tautologies, Contradictions and Calumnies, the Author of a Quack Book, Bill, or Speech, can be guilty of. I was a little uneaie to think that the Judgment of our Age eem'd o declin'd it uch, and uch Perons: But yet they might have embrac'd their Nonene, and hugg'd their fale Juno long enough for me, Sed quod luditur de corio, imo de vita Humana, but that her Embraces I knew, might prove unwholome to them. Which I think, will appear in the following Dicoure, to all that will but grant that the Art of Healing is grounded upon Reaon, and Experimental Philoophy.
The way of Dialogue I choe to Write in, I think, will not only be les tireome, but more eaie and profitable to my Reader; ince I have Trancrib'd from my Author Word for Word, all that I take occaion to Speak too, for the mot part under the Peron of Acid, but what farther Excerptions I Reflect upon, Reheared by Alkali, you will find noted in Italick Characters, o that you may ave the Trouble or Charge of turning to his Books, in Reading mine. Wherein I aure you, I have not abued him. or alter'd his Sene in a Tittle, that I know of, or added, more than ome few Words of Connexion, and the entrance of the Dicoure, which the Jutet Reader, I uppoe, will pardon as a mall Trangreion againt the Man that I never aw, or owe any more Ill-Will too, than him that I never heard of, but wih him really, as great (if it were poible) as he aies he is, and would have us eteem him. 'Tis one of the Main Poynts of my Religion, tho' I am a Phyician, That I ought to be a Friend to all Men; but I am omewhat of the Opinion of Plautus, Amicum non catigare ob merita, mala noxia imane et facinus, I think it a Fault, not to reprove thoe Errors, even in a Friend, that may be of evil Conequence. But here are Errors, that may endanger even the Lives of better Men than him that I reprehend, if o unfortunate as to be entic'd by the love of harp Sawces, & to fall into the Hands of o Bold a Medicater. The expoing af whoe Faults, I know, may be in ome repect to his Private Damage, but the Publick-Good, ought to be eteem'd greater than the Private-Interet of any Man. Salus enim populi Suprema lex et. Yet if things be Weighed in the mot jut Ballance, I think it may be found, That I have aid nothing againt our Doctor, or which, may not be for his real Benefit, whom I look upon as a Sick-Man, and am o far of his own Opinion, as to think his Dieae cannot be Cured without harp Medicines; which tho' he may as little like in the Swallowing, or Application, as ome of his Patients may the Effects of his Acid-Does, I hope yet it may be for his Health hereafter. But there are o many things in my Author, which are the Breakings forth of Vicious Humours, I am doubtful whether I hall be reckon'd culpable for giving him o many, or o few Does, and applying my Corroives to o many, or o few of his Sores. I fear you will be weary of eeiug him Dres'd: Yet I hope no Phyician, or Chirurgeon, no, nor Gentleman, or Lady, but may ee omething worth their while; being if not o pleaant, yet of ueful Conideration. Therefore I hall no longer detain you at the Door of my Lazar-Houe, but take you in to hear, and ee, the Badnes of my Patient, and what ort of Medicines I have Prepared for him. And tho' you will hear him Talk ometimes Talk like a Mad-Man (his Dieae being much in his Head) and abue thoe that have done for him, as he has always done, calling all his Phyicians, Scoundrels, except Dr. Tuthil who got a little into his Favour; yet you need not fear if you don't come too near him, any more than I do, tho' I am reolv'd to handle him cloely, that if poible the poor Young-Man may have the benefit, and I the Credit of o great a Cure. But however it happens, I confes, I am almot aham'd of Preparing o many Remedies for o mean a Patient: But long Bills are Fahionable, and my medicines given Gratis.

div.head: A DIALOGUE BETWEEN ALKALI, and ACID.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: WELL met Mr. Acid, whither are you hurrying o fat, to ome Heroe run through the Lungs, or the Heart?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I hould hardly tay to tell you Mr. Alkali, but that I am engag'd to oppoe you where-ever we meet, you Principle of Death and Corruption, I am always provok'd by you, you have done o much michief in the World: And now to your farther reproach, I have a freh intance of your badnes, by a Meenger from my Lord Lazington, whom you have plagu'd with a fit of the Gout, and that a deperate one if I come not in time to his aitance, none can help him but I, and he thinks it 7 Years e're I come to him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You are very harp Mr. Acid. I ometime ince heard indeed, that you have reptoach'd me in all Companies, even in Coffee-Houes, as well as wrote Books againt me, but now I find it true: I am glad I have met with you, to tell you, you have candalouly reported divers things of me, which if you can't prove to my Face, I hall not eaily put up the Injury, nor part with you willingly without Proof, or Submiion. Let my Lord Lazington roar a little, you will be the welcomer when you come; and I know you can tell how to excue your delay; ome Duke or other had ent for you before, and perhaps my Lord will do as well without you. Let us try whether you can maintain your Charge: You call me the Principle of Death and Corruption, and I hear you ay, I am the caue of all Dieaes, and that you alone are the Dr. that can do any thing coniderable in the Cure of them, and that by detroying and expelling Alkali: And this you make an Hypotheis of, and call it a new one, of your dicovery.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
I am o far from denying what I have aid againt Alkali,
that I continue till to aert my Hypotheis. That all the Alkali in the Blood is mot certainly an Excrement in a way of being carried off by ome of the Emunctories, and when any of the Emunctories chance to be topp'd, that the Alkali has not room to pas out, then there is a Dieae. And the matter of all our Dtempers is the ame. And whereas Acids are contrary to Alkalies (there being a conflict between them where-ever they meet) their being given in due proportion, will leen the matter of the Ditemper, and in time, totally extirpate it. Similia imilibus gaudent, & contraria contrariis curantur. And I am o abolutely confirm'd in the truth of my Hypotheis, that I am ure it is not in the power of any one to overthrow it. Nay the Hypotheis on which I build, I am ure is true. And I have in all my Writings, Truth for my Guide: But the oppoition I have met with, hath been almot inupportable. Truth at its firt appearing never wants Oppoers. But the New Doctrine I have advanc'd has gain'd o much Ground, that few Authors in their own Life-time, have carce een the like. This unwonted and unexpected Encouragement, has fill'd me with a ene of Gratitude, to me inexpreible. Reaon is the true Touch-tone, by which we ought to Examine every thing, and I have never advanc'd any thing, till weigh'd in the Ballance of my bet Reaon, and yet, let Reaon hould deceive me, and I o impoe on the World; I have always join'd Experience to it; o both being conjoin'd, I could not well deceive my elf, nor lead others into Error. That Prodigy of Nature. Mrs. Anne Baynard, aid in my hearing, that, Reaon was that Eternal Standard God Almighty, as a Ray of his own Image has impres'd upon Man, to the election, or dilike of what may hurt, or uccour him; and where this is rais'd and improv'd, makes him an Angel, where unk and depres'd, a groveling Brute.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
I find your Confidence, Mr. Acid, as great as I have heard it reported, which is no Argument to me, that you are in the right; Confidence and Ignorance being uually Companions: And I am the more perwaded it may be in the power, of ome one or other to overthrow your Hypotheis. If you were ure of the truth of it, I confes, it would be impoible it hould be found untrue: But I upope you only fancy your elf ure. That you have Truth for your Guide, I uppoe (if you know what you ay) you mean, you have ome certain Truths, as Rules to guide you to the invention of others: But perhaps, you may as other fallible Men, take ome things for Truths that are not true, or not know how to ue them as Rules, if they are o. What oppoition you have met with I know not, it eems it was what you could hardly bear, I doubt you have thereby confes'd, your trength to be but weak. Why Truth hould always have Oppoers at firt, I ee
not, unles when it is not clearly demontrated, as your Hypotheis (to let you uppoe it true) is not, as you will go near to find, before we have done. And as for the ground, you ay your new Doctrine has gain'd in your (but yet hort) life-time, beyond the Inventions of other Authors, which o urfeits your Heart with Joy, I think no body ele ees it; for I could never yet meet with any one Ingenious Man of your Opinion. And if any few unwary Tyros, or Peron not tudious of Nature, have been pleaed with your Fancies, I believe, if they will but ue their Reaon, which you ay is the Touchtone of Truth, by which we are to examine all things; they will find Reaon to alter their Opinion, and find their Mater Acid's bet reaon was but a fale ballance, and did indeed deceive him, and that his experience was but mitaken experience, and o impos'd upon the Mater, and Scholars too. But that Reaon is an eternal Standard, I do not ee; tho' the prodigious Mrs. Ann Baynard aid o: I rather think her and you, too prodigious Metaphyitians; For I take Reaon to be peculiar to Creatures, and that Creatures and whatever belongs to them are not Eternal, unles in the ame ene, as an ignorant pretender in Phyick in the Beaux Language, would be call'd an eternal Quack. Neither can I ee by any of your reaonings Reaon o improved in your elf, as to give any body any ground to take you for an Angel. Mrs. Ann Baynard might be a great Wit for ought I know, and Wit and Beauty in a Woman, might poibly make a youngter mitake her even for a Goddes, and to be aid to be Witty and Pretty would pleae mot Women, and by pleaing the Women, a Doctor may be likely to meet with an Angel ometimes you know Sir.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The Doctrine I have advanced is o directly contrary to every thing that has been wrote yet, it is enough to tartle any young Man, nay ome old ones too; but I have o enquir'd into Dieaes, as to be altogether certain of the Truth of my Hypotheis, but not o as to make People Immortal, which I believe ome expect from me: But let People lay aide prejudice and et themelves to make Experiments, I am ure they will lay aide their old Notions, and embrace my new Hypotheis, and I am morally certain that my new Doctrine of Acids at preent o much decry'd, will oon obtain the publick vogue, carrying a elf-evidence along with it, and ome People will be o enamour'd with it, as to ue Acids with as much reaon, as others now ue the Cortex; which has been brought o extravagantly in vogue, that ome ue it in all Ditempers, and I believe it will in time, be put into Platers to Cure Corns. By this may be een the intability of Humane Nature that is more govern'd by Fancies than by Reaon,
o that what is to day condemn'd is to morrow in great value. But the Doctrine of Acids being a thing of Univeral extent, it is impoible any one hould do o much michief with them, as with the Cortex.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: If your Doctrine is directly contrary to every thing yet wrote, it is very likely to be contrary to Truth; for doubtles there has been ome Truth wrote before. But I am not at all tartled at your Doctrine Mr. Acid, tho' I confes, I am neither very young, nor old. What a Novice, or an Old Dotard may be, I know not; but if any thing be tartling, it is your Impudence, which indeed eems Montrous: That a Muhroom in Phyick hould o confidently oppoe all that has been yet wrote by all the Learned Phyicians of all Ages, and pretend to have o enquir'd into Dieae ince Yeterday, as to be certain that the long Study and Practice of all other Men gave them nothing but mitakes; but your little time has produced abolute certainty. But truly, notwithtanding your Opinion of your elf, I dare ay no body expects Immortality from you. As for prejudice, you would have us lay aide, I believe I laid it aide, for ome time before you began with the tudy of Pharmacy, and have ever ince made Experiments, and I believe, have had more opportunity, as well as time, to carry on a coure of experimental Philoophy, than your elf; (not to diparage you) yet I cannot lay aide all my Notions thereby gotten, and embrace your new Hypotheis. Your moral Certainty that it will obtain the Publick Vogue, is no better than to ay, an uncertain certainty. Nor is your Doctrine elf-evident to any but Mr. Acid's own harp elf; whoe Eyes perhaps are Microcopes in comparion to other Mens. But there is no fear, People will be enamoured with your Hypotheis it has o oure a Countenance. But the intability of Humane Nature, (I confes) is uch, and ome other Men are o much govern'd by Fancies as well as you, that poibly Acids may be ued with the like reaon, and extravagance as ome have ued the Cortex; but they will hardly mix them with Plaiters. But tho' Alkalies hould be to day wholly condemn'd, perhaps they may be to morrow in as great value as ever. And if it be not poible to do o much michief with Acids, as with the Cortex; yet I believe, ome Perons may find enough done with them to diwade us from uing them as you would have us: But I am certain, a confident Empirick may do a great deal of michief with Acids, Alkalies, Cortex, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
People mut long ince have known my Hypotheis, or they mut not; if they have not they have groped in the dark, and cured Dieaes as a blind Man may catch a Hare; if they have known it, their giving Alkalies is an Argument, they have not acted
like honet Men. But no one can charge me with any thing elfih, unles it be to leave a Name to Poterity. I want Univerity-Gloes to polih over my Dicoure, but Truth like Diamonds will parkle among Pebbles, yea appears bet naked; and I am orry, I am forced to promulgate this Doctrine in Terms that look o like elf-commendation but I have been too long meal mouth'd, whereby Truth has uffer'd, and my over modety has caus'd me to be oppres'd: But a contant eries of ucces has rais'd me many Friends, and nothing but an extraordinary Providence could have upported me againt o many Enemies: All the Ch • rurgeons in the World, and after the Phyitians, but from thee, I have had the fairer play, and they grow more civil, and among the Chirurgeons I gain Friends daily.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
How hould People have known your Hypotheis long ince, when it is not long, ince you conceived it, and brought it forth; pray you Sir excue them: And let us come to the tryal of Skill, whether your Hypotheis be well grounded or no, and ee whether you can prove, that all People that have not known your Hypotheis have groped in the dark, and cured Dieaes either by a very rare accident, or not at all, that you are the only Man God has given Eyes to, till which is done, I cannot but look upon you as a Peron of great Impudence, to accue all the World of Learned PHYSITIANS as Fools, or what is wore, as Knaves, and uncommon Arrogancy to aert your elf the only Wie, yea and honet Man pretending to Phyick; and that you have nothing elfih in you, but to leave a Name to Poterity. Truly methinks, you are as elfih as any body: But as for a a Name to Poterity, it's pity you hould want it, I'll help you, that you may be ure to have it, and not for nothing. I wih you could have written in Latin, that all the World might have known you. Tho' you ay, you want Univerity-Gloes, you are Rhetorical enough indeed Sir; for you have abundance of Hyperboles, nor want you other choie Foiles to et off your Diamonds, nor are your Truths naked, but o dres'd up (if you have any) that I cannot ee the Faces of them. But you commend your elf o much, it looks not like force put upon you; nor do you eem o meale-mouth'd, or over modet as you ay you are, but peak roundly enough. It's pity Truth hould uffer, or you be oppres'd for your Virtue, Poor young Man: but it may be hoped you will grow tronger. But you have had extraordinary Helps, contant Succes, and uncommon Providence has got you Friends, and upported you againt o many Enemies, all the Chirurgeons in the World, and after the Phyitians. Has your Fame pread o largely? Certainly this mut be by ome uncommon Providence, for I cannot find, that
half the Chirurgeons, or Phyitians in England have heard of you, (but I will endeavour that they may) much les all the World of them, when your Books are wrote but in your own Language. But prethee John let me hear no more of thee brags, but lets come to the contet: I'll give you as fair play as you can well wih, and will be added to the number of your Friends, if poible.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: In all Dieaes, Phyicians have unanimouly agreed, that Acids have abounded; and if to uch a Degree, that their Alkalies could not conquer it, then the Patient Dy'd. And as for Alkalous Medicines, I dare be poitive, they never yet Cured any one Ditemper; but frequently have done a great deal of michief. If any ever receiv'd any advantage by them, I dare be burnt. If they be given in acute Dieaes, and Nature be trong, he throws off the load in pight of them; if weak, they add to the load, and he falls under it. In Chronical Dieaes, uch as the Gout, poor Mortals are let alone to languih under the Ditemper. But you may ay, If my Hypotheis be true, how have others, mitaken Phyicians, Cur'd Dieaes? I anwer, I own they have Cur'd ome Dieaes, but they could never tell how: They have given Steel, Antimony, and other Preparations, without enquiring into the nature of them, uppoing them Alkalies; when they at the ame time are Acids; as alo many Vegetable Productions, and o Cur'd Dieaes, they being Acids.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Truly John, your Dicoure begins to grow naueous: You are not yet Forty Years old, and could you have pent Thirty of them in reading the Writings of Phyicians, you could not have read the Tenth part of what they have Writ, much les have known, what ucces they always had in their Practice. And as poitive as you are, I believe, I hall give you matter of Fact, as well as Reaon, enough to convince any modet Man, that Dieaes have been Cur'd by Alkalies, and when you are convinc'd, I would counel you, to burn your Books, rather than your elf, as dareing as you are. And for hame forbear to accue all Phyicians at this rate, either never to have Cur'd Dieaes, or now and then to have done it ignorantly, they knew not how, by giving Acids at unawares. Do you think others have not took as much pains to know the nature of Antimony, Steel, and Vegetable Productions as you? Had none of them any way to know Acids from Alkalies? Van He • mont, whom you ometime, call'd your Mater, aies, he wrought Forty Years with great labour and charge (and others have done the like) in Analizeing the materia Medica. Fye John, fye! prethee give over, I believe, you will ometime find you have done your elf no Credit, nor kindnes to cry your elf up, and cry down all Phyicians at this rate.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I have made reflections on Phyicians indeed, but they are principally Foreigners; they all to a Man, aerting the Doctrine of Alkalies. What I have aid, is not to reproach the Phyicians of our own Nation, who are many of them, as Great Men as ever were of the Profeion, and this City abounds with uch; but my deign, is to undeceive Young Phyicians, who have been impos'd upon by Foreigners, and to excite them not to rely upon Men, who have broach'd the Chymera's of their own Brain, without making Experiments, whether their Notions were true, or fale; my deign being, not to Reflect upon that Noble Society the College, the Glory of our Nation, and of the whole World; but I have the greatet Reverence and Repect for them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Mr. Acid, you do not know what all Foreigners have done, neither do they deerve your reproach more than the Phyicians of our own Nation, or are they les Men: You cannot well be ignorant, that ome of the College you applaud o, are Foreigners, and as deerving as any of the ret. Nor have Foreigners impos'd on Young Phyicians, more than thoe of our own Nation, nor have they been always Men more full of Chymera's, or les acquainted with Experiments; as every one acquainted with the Medical World mut acknowledg. Nor was Young Mr. Acid the fittet Man to undeceive Young Phyicians; he hould have left it to Older Heads, or have tay'd a little longer. Was there none of the Fathers of the Noble Society, whom after you had abued in general, with all Phyicians, you now weeten up o, as the Glory of the whole World: I ay, was there none of them that undertood the Vertue of Acids? Or, none of them o kind as to undeceive the Youngters, that they left it to you? Or, had none of them uch a Capacity to Write as Mr. Acid? I mut tell you truly Sir, you are no Credit to them, of what profit oever you may be, notwithtanding your Profeing Reverence and Repect for them. But I believe, after all your bouncing of a New Hypotheis, we hall find, that Phyicians have ued Acids, knowing them to be uch, long before you were Born; thinking rightly, that neither Acids nor Alkalies alone Cure Dieaes; but a Phyician uing them all with other things, when, and where he ees occaion. And to convince you, and hew you how apt you are to contradict your elf, (your Memory as you have ometime confes'd, being a very treaeherous one) To confirm the truth of your Doctrine, you told us, Dr. Jones commended Acids in divers Dieaes, a Man of uch clearnes of Reaon, that you never heard him mention any thing, but he was fully able to demontrate it. But if what you ay of him, be true, and your Doctrine may be uppos'd not fale; I think he is more like to be the Author of it than you, tho' he lets you take the Name;
and I would advie you, to get him to demontrate your Hypotheis; for I am ure you have not done it. And Dr. Baynard had alo wonderful Succes, and his Practice run upon Acids, and thoe Gentlemen embrac'd Acids out of a Life-aving principle (you ay) in oppoition to the multitude. Likewie you tell us at another time, that, Dr. Waton ued Acids for Ten Years, which was before the birth of your Hypotheis, if you were the Parent of it. Nay, you tell us Oyl of Vitriol is commended in Theatro Chymico, pag. 86, & 87. Vol. I. And your Mater Helmont by adviing a Man to take two Drops of Oyl of Sulphur every Meal, preerv'd him free from Dieaes to an Old-age; which advice was given, long before you were born, and doubtles he knew, Oyl of Sulphur was an Acid. Nay, Riverius alo comes in for a Snack, by your leave, when you are kind or forgetful, Curing a confirm'd Pthiis with Conerve of Roes and Oyl of Sulphur. Here are Foreigners Sir, tho' you ay, All of them to a Man, aerted the Doctrine of Alkalies. But, your treacherous Memory, once gave away all your glory; when you were almot poitive, that there was no Phyician in Chritendom, of any buines, but had made ue of Oyl of Vitriol, that dangerous Acid, tho' aerters of Alkalies. But then you ting them in the Concience for uch practice, how they can anwer for it you can't tell, that if Acids are the Caue of Dieaes, how they dare with a good Concience give the mot temperate Acids, you can't undertand. But I'll undertake to be Cauit for them, for once; eeing you can't reolve it. They ued Acids, when they aw occaion, with better reaon than you do, and Alkalies, as they found the nature of the Caes requir'd; being wier, than to think Acids alone, or onely Alkalies the Caue of all Dieaes, And to name one for intance, to convince you of the truth of the matter, Frederick Hoffman Publih'd an ingenious Treatie, 1689. againt the fancy of ome few, who would make Acid and Vicid the Caues of all Dieaes; wherein he commends Acids in many Caes, yet confees, that Acid and Vicid are the Caues of many Ditempers. Certiimum porro et (aies he, pag. 5.) & cuivis practicorum obvium acidum, & vicidum plurimorum morborum fomitem, ac mineram exitere, and gives everal Intances and Arguments to make it appear, and that a Phyician cannot be without Alkalous Medicines, & ane (aies he again, pag. 10.) nii velimus diimulare, nullus gratious medicus facile carere potet alibus itis Alkalinis Volatilibus, interquae paimas tenet Spiritus Oleoos Sylvii: Spiritus alis armoniaci vinous cum ol • is aromaticis, & carminativis varie eentificatus: Spiritus Vini a ale Vol. C. C. abtractus, Salia fixa, & illorum olutiones, Lapides Canerorum, Coralia cum lixivio alis Tartari imbibita & impri
•• s ali • fixa Sulphuri metallico amiciimo conjugio juncta, &c. And concludes, Aci ••• , ac vicidum motui anguinis nimis hotile; plurimorum
morborum cauam evadere poe, & contra Medicamenta Alkalina acidum detructiva decenter exhibita geneneroiima magnorum morborum exitere praeidia. And this was wrote everal Years before your Eay (as you call it) concerning Alkali and Acid. Where are you now John?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: It is true. Some few other Phyitians have ued Acids, but the aitance I had from them is inconiderable as to the etablihing my Principles, and if I have made any good teps, it is owing to my own indutry; for tho' I was not bred at Univerity, I have taken as much true pains to inform my elf in all parts of Phyick, perhaps as any Man ever did: And pent as much Money to qualifie me for the practice of Phyick as mot Men, who have pent their time in the Univerities, and I have had ocular demontration for my Money, when as ome of our Univerity-Men have had only the futy Notions of Old Aritotle for theirs. And tho' I have not aid all that is to be aid in behalf of my Hypotheis, yet I have aid o much, that I believe I may boldly ay, it is the bet and clearet Hypotheis now extant, on which the cure of Dieaes may be attempted on greater certainty, than on any other Publick.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
At one time you ay, all the Phyitians in Chritendom of any buines have ued Acids, now but ome few; we mut conclude either you contradict your elf, or ele the Men of buines, in all Chritendom have been but few: But if by Men of buines you mean uch as your elf, then I believe indeed they have been but few, and the aitance you have had from them, towards the etablihing your Principles, has not been great I grant; for your reading has been little. Yet ome aitance I am confident, you have had; for your Dicoures mell pretty trong of Dr. Andre, of Acid, and Alkali Publihed in Englih, 1689. But when you ay, you have taken as much true pains to inform your elf in all parts of Phyick as any ever did, you cannot be excued of Arrogancy; for we well know, you neither have had the Years, Abilities nor Opportunity many have had. Beides you are o extraordinarily accomplih'd in that one Qualification of a Doctor of Phyick fahionable Language, that it mut needs have taken up much of your time to acquire it, and hinder your learning other parts of Science. But as for your pending as much Money, as mot who have been bred at Univerities, we know very well you never had it to pend. But why could not Univerity-Men have Ocular demontration for their Money as well as you: Or, How come they to be confin'd to the futy Notions of Aritotle? for want of other Books? I hope you will upply them with freh Notions for the future. But you have not aid all that hould have been aid in
behalf of your Hypotheis, that is if it were to be made probable. Here you are in the right, and I hould have perceiv'd it, if you had not told me o. And I grant you believe, or would have us think your Hypotheis is the bet, and clearet in Phyick now extant to all intents and purpoes, and you have aid as much as this comes to over and over. 'Twas a thouand pities you were not able rightly to handle it, that it might have proved the mot glorious of its kind that ever appear'd on the tage of the World. But after all thee braggs, and tir for a Name to Poterity (not to talk of getting a little Money to purchae an old Coach for the preent) your Treacherous Memory o far fail'd you, as to let you ay, you did not pretend to be ole Author, or firt broacher of the Doctrine of Acids, it having long ince been the opinion of ome of the mot happy Practitioners in the World, and is now embraced by ome of the greatet Men, and mot happy Practitioners our Age affords, and that you don't pretend to be o great a Man, nor deerve o well of Mankind as Helmont, Paracelus, &c. who treading out of the common Path, did not want maligners; therefore why hould you who don't pretend to have arriv'd at thoe great Perfections they had, take it amis to be abus'd, and evil poken of? Here you are over modet and mealmouthed. For thee Men were Foreigners, and often ued Alkalies, and were ignorant of your Doctrine, that Acids are the cure of all Dieaes, and yet deerved better of Mankind than you. What fit of Modety is this John? 'Tis to be fear'd your caue will uffer for this. But I ee in all this you would commend your elf by comparing your elf to uch great Men; but you have not done it ingeniouly yet you hould let others praie you, and not your own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I have had everal congratulatory Letters from divers Learned Men in praie of my Dicovery of the Doctrine of Acids, as for intance from Dr. Jones, begining thus, Dear Sir, As for Acids, Dr. Baynard and your elf deerve eternal praie, &c. From N. Tyrling, Digniime, contra Jutitiae, morumque normam peccarem i virum cui Deo proximo vitam debeam ilentio preterirem. Nuper, enim cum e luce pene evaiem, tu mihi propitius adte • iti, candide effuliti, Tu meus Apollo, &c. And from Dr. Waton thus, Tractatus tuos ummis cum deliciis & voluptate perlegi, & tuum in promovendo illo nobiliimo Medicinae tudio intitutum maxime demiror in humani generis bonum univerale: Macte Bone vir Melioribus Avibus, & momos apernare, &c. And in the beginning of my Relation of the Peron bitten by a Viper, you will find the following Panegyrick. To the Unknown Dr. Colbatch, upon his mot Ingenious Tracts, epecially that of Alkalies and Acids.

lg.l: Phyick for Ages pat has grop'd her way
In Paths of Darknes, without any Ray
Of certain Truth, and till was going atray:
When COLBATCH roe, who with reviving Light
Dipell'd the Clouds, and chas'd away the Night,
By him th'important Secret is reveal'd
Through Fraud, and Ignorance o long conceal'd:
No ordid hopes of Gain, e'er way'd his mind,
His only Aim's the good of Humane kind;
Who firt with Pains, and Labour dug the Oar
Then freely gave us all the Golden tore.
Let Juggling Quacks grown envious of thy Name
Combine together to obcure thy Fame;
Such are the Myteries which thou dot unfold
They'll write thy Name in Characters of Gold,
To thee alone Mankind's indebted more
Than t'all the Doctors that have gone before.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Thee Men praie you at a great rate Mr. Acid, one thinks eternal Praies your due, another owes his Life to you his Pagan Deity, another is ravih'd almot in reading your luceous Writings, and admires your Capacity in promoting Medicine, claps you on the Back, and bids you depie your Carpers; But the fourth outdoes them all, and ings you too. I wonder no body did it ooner, for you are a Subject enough to inpire the dullet Mue: But the Poet might have let us have had his name at length, ure he needed not to have been hie of owning his Opinion of you any more than the other Gentlemen; Beides he might perhaps have prevented our mitaking him: For I cannot be perwaded but that it was John Colbatch Junior, that was the Poet, however I am ure that John Calbatch Junior, caued it to be printed in his Book, and had he not been a Junior it had never been there. To the Unknown Dr. Colbatch is a very odd Epithet on o Famous an Author, it cannot ure be an Ironie, but hold; John Colbatch Jun. may be very well thought to be unknown to himelf, otherwie he could never have Publihed his own Praies at o extravagant a rate. As for his Poetry I ay, in hort it is Poetry, and it is well it is o; for nothing but Poetica licentia can excue it, it being all fiction: And perhaps for this reaon Tom Saffold choe to Publih his Bills in Vere, knowing the liberty of the Mues to lie. And now I mention the Famous Tom Saffold, it brings into my mind what a Friend of Mr. Acids, who aw what J. C. Junior had written would have added, which was this:
Whilt Saffold liv'd (could you believe him) he
Outdid all other Quacks in Pharmacy.
'Twere Saffold's Pills o call'd among the ret,
Deervedly had gaind the name of bet.
Since J. C. Junior roe his greater fame
Defac'd the Monument of Saffold's Name:
Believe him, or his Friend, he merits more
Than all the Saffolds that have gon before.
His raret Tincture, and his great Wound-Powder,
Do praie him every day lowder and lowder.
In Villers-treet near to the As his head,
John Acid Liveth, now Tom Saffold's dead.
Acid like Saffold mighty Tales has told,
And here his famous Drops are to be old.
But to deal plainly with you Mr. Acid, this is but playing the Quack, and leat you hould take it unkindly if I hould handle him only in rough Proe, who now comes dres'd out o finely in Vere. I'll give the Quack his Character in the ame fahion. As follows,
A Quack's a Medicater, etting forth
By bae, unhandome means his feigned worth,
Whether on Saddle, moving Stage he it,
Boating his Remedies, from treet to treet.
Whether he keep a Fool to act his part,
To draw a concoure there to Preach his Art.
Whether at Coffee-Houe he does appear
At uch an Hour, plying for buines there:
Whether his Story he decribed has
O'th paper Hangings of a piing-place.
Or tho' his Tales unto a Volume rie,
To peak him Learned in the Peoples Eyes
The Quack's the ame in differing diguie.
But I long to ee whether John Acid deerves all his great Encomiums, and whether his new dug Oar will yield him any Metal that will tand the Tet, I doubt it will not go through the fiery Tryal.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
As for the great threats daily thundred out of my being confuted, they are but Scare-crows to me, I am far from being afraid of it, and whoever hall make it appear by olid Experiments,
that I am in the wrong, hall be my Great Apollo, and the firt thing I do, hall be to write a Publick Recantation.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Upon your word Mr. Acid you'll vomit up your o well digeted Hypotheis; if I can help you to an Emetick, that will work upon you: I believe you would never offer o fairly, but that you are confident that nothing will turn your tomach: I'll try. I fancy Antimony may yield a Medicine trong enough for you; you ay, 'Tis an Acid, therefore I hope you will be willing to take it, if that won't do, we will try your own Vulnerary Powder, that's vomitive too, and we will prepare them with Acids. I'll give you a proces I'll warrant you, and you hall prepare it, in your own Elaboratory, You are a profes'd Chymit you know, and a Diciple of Helmont, and know nothing o delightful as Cbymical Operations. Helmont purg'd himelf of the Galenical Hypotheis, by what he wrought out of the Fire, and if you follow my directions it may be you may clear your elf of yours, and you know you are Apothecary enough Mater Doctor, to dipence your own Medicines skilfully, when you have prepar'd them.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
I confes I was bred nn Apothecary, and under a Man that was not the greatet Mater in his Buines; but taking notice of my Mater's imperfections, I apply'd my elf, for Four Years of his time, to thoe things my Mater could not Teach me in ome meaure; and when I was become a Mater in Pharmacy the foundation on which Phyick is built; I was induc'd to look into the Body of Phyick it elf; and tho' I dont pretend to abolute Materhip, yet I hall endeavour to improve my Talent. The greatet part of my time I liv'd in Worceter, and tho' I kept an Apothecaries Shop, my dependance was wholly upon my Practice. And ince I peake of my being an Apothecary. I hall give the neceary Qualifications of one of that Profeion; that you may judg uch a one has made a large tep towards being a good Phyician. 1. An Apothecary mut have good acquaintance with the Vegetable Kingdom, not only to know the Faces of Plants; but their Natures and manners of Operation on Humane Bodies. 2. He mut well undertand the Nature and Operation of Minerals and Metals, which is not to be attain'd without much Reading and hard labour in the fire, and 3. of Animal Bodies, amongt which is Man, there being carce a part of his whole Body, but what is ometime or other to be ued as a Medicine; but firt requires the Apothecaries Skill for its Preparation. The famous Etmuller was not aham'd to own that he erv'd Eight Years to an Apothecary; yet he became one of the mot Eminent Phyicians in Europe: And for ought I know, the los of him at that Age he
Dy'd, deerves as much to be lamented as the los of any one private Man, from him o much might have been expected.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
One might have gues'd you to be an Apothecary, if you had never told us o, you talk o like an Apothecary: But I am orry you had no better a Mater; it had been well you had met with one that could have taught you a little good Manners; for truly John, you hew none in publihing your Mater's imperfections. But pray you, who taught you for that Four Years you went o far beyond your Mater's Capacity, as to become a Mater your elf in Pharmacy? Truly I can hardly believe you are a Mater in Pharmacy yet. For tho' you call your elf a Doctor, I am ure you talk as if you knew not what Pharmacy means, when you tell us it is the foundation on which Phyick is built. You have look'd into the Body of Phyick at a fine rate: But indeed, you don't talk like an abolute Mater, to tell us, That Pharmacy, that is the making of Medicines, is the foundation on which Phyick, that is Natural Knowledge, is built. Surely John, you never read any Intitutions, or if you did, what you read lip'd out of your treacherous Memory; but it may be, you would peak with the Vulgar, while you think with the Learned, and then the ene of it is, That the making of Medicines, is that upon which Medicine •
is built. But if you would talk with the Doctors, they place Phyick or Phyiology in the firt place, as the foundation, meaning the conideration of Nature it elf, in its ound tate, or due order. Then Pathology, the account of its Defects. And thirdly, Semeiotice, the conideration of the events or iues of thoe Defects. Then Hygieine which teaches to preerve from thoe Defects, as much as my be. And in the Lat place, comes Therapuetice, the method of reducing the Defects of Nature, and the fitting the Intruments for that purpoe is Pharmacy: So that it is far from the foundation of the Building. What Practice you built on your foundation of Pharmacy, I know not, or whether your dependance were on that Practice. You are very kind in giving us the neceary Qualifications of an Apothecary, you are willing to inform the World, how fit a Man Mr. Apothecary would be thought to be to make a Doctor of. But by your Materhip you hew in Pharmacy, and your acquaintance with Materia Medica, I believe before we have done, it will appear, you have not made that large tride an expert Apothecary has took towards being a good Phyician: But I hall remark here only, what acquaintance you have with Animals; epecially uch an one as your elf, of which you ay, There is carce a part but is ometime or other to be ued as a Medicine. I believe your Brains would make an excellent one, but they would hardly yeild one Grain of harpnes in Ditillation. And as I uppoe, you would not ue
Man's fleh crude (except in ome few Ditempers of Women) becaue you ay it ought to be prepar'd: If the Fire mut be ued, it will produce Alkalies copiouly from both fluids and olid parts of Man's Body; and Alkalies acording to your Hypotheis are the principle of Death and corruption; and yet all parts of Man's Body are ometimes to be prepar'd for a Mediaine. You forget your elf o oft John, I am aham'd of you. The famous Etmulier was a Foreigner and an aerter of Alkalies to be good Medicines, and Acids the caue of many Dieaes: How comes he in o much Credit with you here Sir? He hould be rather infamous methinks for his Fraud or Ignorance; but you forgive him I ee for ake, ake; that is, he was an Apothecary, and yeilds you an Argument for us, thus, Etmuller was an Apothecary; and yet became one of the mot Famous Phyicians in Europe! one whoe los is much to be lamented, he might have been o ueful: Ergo, Mr. Acid who was an Apothecary, may nevertheles be one of the mot Famous Phyicians in Europe; and o, much to be priz'd: This is the Logick of it. But truly I can ee no uch great hopes of him, he is o apt to forget what ever he ays and do's; but a blind man may catch a Hare, they ay.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I wrote my Eay of Alkalies and Acids, during the Siege of Namur, when I had not the opportunity of conulting Books, nor the benefit of coming at my own Papers, wherein I had et down my Obervations; wherefore, I only made ue of thoe occur'd to my Memory, which is a very taeacherous one, o they are not o numerous and exact as I deign'd them; but yet I was willing to venture them abroad as they were, for ome reaons; they being not in the leat deign'd to entertain the Learned, but to undeceive the Multitude. I have aim'd at certainty, if I can once arrive to that (which I will never ret till I have done) I care not. If we could have a publick Laboratory at the Nation's Expence I hould hope to ee the matter ooner effected. It cots the Nation ome Hundred thouand's a Year in Powder and Ball to detroy Mankind: Why not One Thouand in Experiments to ave their Lives? There is a Noble Laboratory already Built at the College the fittet place for uch a thing, and the Governing Officers are Men of Fidelity, and of uch Publick Spirits, that they are fit to be truted with a greater Summ.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
I think it had been well Mr. Acid you had let alone Writing till you could have conulted Books, as well as your own Papers, that you might have help'd your Memory (which you now confes to be a very treacherous one, and o hew, I have not abus'd you) for truly your Obervations are not o exact as they hould be. But you had Reaons to venture them abroad, not to entertain the
Learned; but to undeceive the Multitude. What's the meaning of this Sir, who are the Learned? The Aeyd Doctors uch as your elf, Dr. Jones, Dr. Waton, Dr. Baynard? &c. And are all the ret the Multitude? Thoe perhaps whom you call Young Phyicians, tho' for Years they may be Old Men. Or, do you mean by the Learned, all Phyicians, and by the Multitude all other Men who undertand no thing of Phyick. Thee lat you rather eem to mean: But what do you Write to teach them Phyick? What will become of the Doctors then? There is Vinegar, Crab-Verjuice, Lemons and Oranges enuough to be had and you tell them, They can never over Doe it, for the Stomach wont fail to reject whatever is to much, and the damage is but a puke or two: We hall have them all turn Doctors, your method is o eaie. But by undeceiving them, I rather uppoe, you mean you would convince them that the Alkali-Doctors are dangerous fellows, or at bet good for nothing; that they may Employ you Mr. Acid, and your Diciples, if you have any: There's the knack of it; and I confes, there needs not much exactnes in putting our Bills to invite thoe that know nothing of Nature, or good Sene; and this conideration makes me inclinable to fancy, you may be as harp a Fellow in Politicks as Tom. Saffold, who once hew'd himelf more Knave then Fool, when being told, his Bills were Non-ene; He wittily reply'd, he Liv'd not by Men of Sene. And I confes Fools are oonet caught. I applaud you for aiming at Certainty; but if you mean Certainty in Phyick, and will never ret till you arrive to it; I think, I may ptomie the World a perpetual motion on your Credit. A Publick Laboratory at the Nation's Expence, would be a brave thing (but that would never make you an infallible Doctor, tho' you were the Director of it) and a Thouand a Year; yea, Ten Thouand would be better pent in uch a Deign to ave Mens Lives, than ome Hundreds of Thouands to detroy Mankind. But methinks Mr. Acid, you give the Nation a hard Complement, aud epecially His Majety the Supreme Director of our Expences, to ay o much Money is pent to detroy Mankind. I don't believe, any uch wicked Deign; but that you abue both King and People. But we have a Noble Laboratory to our wih at the College, the fittet place for uch a thing. But John, you do not only bepatter every body ele, but you digrace the College too, by begging Money to buy them Coals and Glaes, as if they were either not able to defray the Charges of the deign themelves, or o covetous they would not, unles the People give Money to intruct them in their Art, as well as pay their Fees for the effects of it. What the Governing Officers are as to trut, and Publick Spirit, I hall leave to thoe that bet know them. But
indeed John I have no hope that thoe Men who undertand Philoophy enough already, will ever be eager in the deign you talk of, either with their own, or others Money; and ubmit it to your teachings: I could never find them o olicitous about Intructing young Phyicians as your elf Sir; but if they were, I hould till fear a publick Laboratory, as you would direct it, would rather be a publick Pet, than a publick Benefit; there would be o much Oyl of Vitriol, of Sulphur, and other harp Corroives made, and given to the Sick, as would detroy ten to one more than Powder and Ball do's: When not one in ten but ometimes may want a Doctor; but not one in ten thouand go's to the Wars: And thee things would be o much more dangerous; becaue (like White-Powder) they would do execution, without giving a report. For John I mut tell you, I till believe, that Acids-may be the Caue of many Dieaes; epecially in the Hand of a four Hypothetick: And Alkalies may in many caes be very good Medicines: And this will go near to be my Opinion, till you have convinc'd me by good Reaons, grounded on ufficient Experiments, that your new Hypotheis is any more, than a new Method of Quacking.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
Every Man may be capable of judging, whether my Hypotheis is true or fale, from this eaie Method. Every Apothecary's Boy knows that all Acids pour'd on Syrup of Violets, or a olution of it, will turn in Red, and as the Acid is tronger, or weaker, o will the Red colour be: So on the other hand, all manifet Alkalies, lixivious or Volatile will turn the Syrup Green, and as the Alkali is tronger, or weaker, o will the Green Colour be. Whence I infer if the Serum of Blood did turn the Syrup Red, it would be plain, that the Serum did abound with Acids; but if on the other hand it turns the Syrup Green it is more, or les impregned with Alkalous Particles. I poitively aert, I could never find the Serum turn the Syrup into any colour but Green. All manifet Alkalies thus change the Syrup to a Green. Ergo, If the Serum too do's o change it, it mut needs abound with Alkalous Particles. This is an eaie way of Arguing, and the plainet Demontration in the World. And no one that labours under the Gout, or any other Ditemper Chronical, or Acute; but will be glad to loe two or three Ounces of Blood, to make this Experiment, on which o much depends. Every Gentleman, may thus reaon with himelf: My Phyician tells me, my Blood abounds with Acids, and upon that core, gives me Alkalies to correct them; but if he hould be mitaken, and my Blood abound with Alkalies, his giving me Alkalies will encreae the Ditemper: Therefore ince I have o fair an opportunity, my own
Eyes hall be judg, what my Blood abounds with: Whether Dr. Colbatch's Enemies, being almot all the World of Phyicians, or he are to be blam'd. If my Blood abound with Acids, he ought to be Kick'd out of the Common-Wealth; if on the other hand, it abounds with Alkalies; he deerves all the Encouragement in the World; for dicovering o ueful and neceary a Truth, and thereby expoing himelf to the malice and rage of o many. This Experiment is liable to no Objection, I know of; and by it I can refer my elf to every Gentleman, and from Gentlemen, I hall have Jutice. Phyicians have endeavour'd to expoe me, becaue owning me to in the be right; would be owning their own mitakes: But by this Experiment, I have appeal'd to more jut Judges.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
You being to talk like a Philoopher, and a Logician too; now Mr. Acid, I hope, that I hall have ome Work, and that we hall leave Playing: And I am very glad, I am capable of judging of your Hypotheis, by your own conceion, ince you ay, every Man is o: And I hope, ome Men will be capable of judging of what I hall ay to it; tho' perhaps, every Apothecary's Boy may not: For in ome places they do not teach them for the firt thing, the change of colours in Syrup of Violets, by Acids and Alkalies. But I hall appeal to Phyicians, and Gentlemen too, if Men of Sene. Gentlemen you know, are many of them, troubled with the Gout; and I remember you have told us, Tbat all that are afflicted with the Gout, are Men of Sene; for you never met with one Block-head that was troubled with it. This is good Logick, could we uppoe, you had met with all the Men troubled with the Gout. But I hall love Alkalies the better for this trick: For if all that are troubled with the Gout, are Men of Sene, and all that are troubled with the Gout abound with Alkalies (as you have affirm'd) it looks omething like an Argument that Men abounding with Alkalies, are Men of Sense; and then on the contrary, Men abounding with Acids, are likely to be Block-heads; and I hould always be afraid of an Acid Doctor, not only leat he hould be an As himelf, but leat he hould make me a Fool too, by detroying the Alkali in my Blood; which gives me more happines in a enible Undertanding, than infelicity in the ence of a Gouty Paroxyme. But tho' I appeal to Gentlemen, as well as Phyicians; I hall not like, you o far digrace my Profeion, as to uppoe, Gentlemen better Judges in Phyical matters, than Phyycians themelves: Should I do o, I hould hew my elf no wier, than the Barreter who woulld be judg'd by his Clients, whether he pleaded Law, or no. I will not accue Phyicians, as either les Wie, or les Jut, than Gentlemen; however Mr. Acid, or other Gentlemen may take it: But aert their Education for the generality, in all
repects equal to, if not exceeding Gentlemen; and if their accomplhments in Phyical Knowledge be not greater, it is a great hame, and Gentlemen are unwie in uing them. But let us come to the reaon of your Hypotheis. All Alkalies turn Syrup of Violets Green, Tarbox the Blood abounds with Alkalous particles. This is an eaie way of argueing; but truly your Argument is far from a Demontration; you are out in your Logick here, and have not prov'd the Point. For unles you could have made a regular Category, and have aid, Whatever turns Syrup of Violets Green, is an Alkali. But Serum of Blood turns Syrup of Violets Green; therefore it is an Alkali, or abounds with Alkali: and then have prov'd your Major: It will not follow, that the Serum abounds with Alkali: For tho' all Alkalies will turn Syrup of Violets Green; yet it wants to be prov'd that whatoever turns it Green, is an Alkali, or that nothing but Alkali will do o: Which I am ure, you will never be able to do, but by denying ome of your aertions; as may appear before we have done. But I grant, that the Blood abounds with Alkalous particles; if by abounding, you mean only that it yields, or contains a great deal of Alkali, and not that it has always too much. And what then Mr. Acid? You don't deerve all the Encouragement in the World for this neceary Dicovery; becaue truely, it is none of your Dicovery; being well known, long before you were born, to your Mater Helmont, and a great many more Famous Men; yea, I dare ay, all that at preent deerve the Name of Phyicians, knew it before you ever aw Blood Ditill'd, or knew it would yield a Salt, or that Serum would turn Syrup of Violets Green. But you have dicover'd one thing indeed, in aerting this your Dicovery, that is your elf, unacquainted with the World of Phyicians, or arrogant and foolih in publihing that, as your Invention, which was generally known, long before you knew any thing of Phyick. And truly John, you deerve to be laugh'd at and his'd, if not kick'd out of the Company of Phyicians, for this Dicovery. But to the Argument, 'Tis true, the Blood abounds with Alkali, whoever dicover'd the truth of it. What then, do's it follow, that the Blood's abounding with Alkalies, is the Caue of all Dieaes? Not at all. For, if it abound with Alkalies, I ay, it hould do o, as it naturally does in Perons mot healthy; and it no way follows, that the abundance of that which ought to abound; is the Caue of Dieaes: But the want of the due quantity of that which ought to abound; or the abounding of that which hould not, or do's not naturally abound, is much more likely to be the Caue of a Dieae. It is well known to thoe Phyicians who have (as they ought) been
exercis'd in Experimental Phyloophy, that Man's Body by a Pyrotechinal Examination yields a great quantity of Volatile, Alkalous Salt; but the quantity of it is much exceeded by the other Products; yea, even by one of them, viz. Water, the abundance of which, a Hypothetick Brain, might as well have fancy'd the caue, not only of a Dropy; but of all other Dieaes; there being more of it to be carry'd off by Perpiration, than of any other Matter. It is beyond all doubt, that the Particles contituting the Humane Frame, are of different Figures and Sizes, and have their determinate Proportions, as to quantity; from whence arie the different appearances of the Parts in their Natural Shapes and Contitutions; as alo the different qualities of the Artificial Products from one, and another of them. But for a Man to ay, That the abounding of any one of thee (tho' by abounding, he mean one of them is too much in quantity) is the Caue of all Dieaes; looks o unlike a Philoopher, or even a Rational Man, that I admire any one fond of a Reputation, hould be guilty of uch a folly, as either to aert it, or believe it! It is evident to all Men, that in any ort, tudy the Nature of Bodies, that a due Proportion of the component Parts is requiite to the proper Contitution of a Compound Body. And if a Body conited but of two orts of Particles: For intance, Acid and Alkalous (uppoing them themelves to be imple Bodies) in all Reaon, as there ought to be a certain Proportion; the abounding of one, as well as of the other, would make an undue Contitution, or Dieae. But the Body of Man, conits not wholly of Acid and Alkalous Particles; o that one of thee two mut needs abound, to make a Diproportion; but of divers others, either Natural Contituents, or Artificial Products: And that it hould be aid, that but one of thee can poibly abound, is without any colour of Reaon; when not only our Food, which encreaes and maintains the bulk of our Bodies, is o different, abounding now with one, then with another ort of Particles Homogeneous to thoe our Bodies conit of; but alo the various Excrements to be Egeted, may be now one, then another retain'd, or too hatily carry'd off, and o caue a diproportion; and what the proportion ought to be between thee divers Particles, I doubt, will be found a matter too hard for a better Philoopher than Mr. Acid, certainly to determine. Moreover, the Body of Man is to be conider'd as coniting of olid and fluid Parts, containing and contained; beides which, there is in Man < in non-Latin alphabet >
Impetum faciens, and as we conider Dieaes, with relation to this threefold Diviion; the fancy of Alkalies abounding to be the caue of all Dieases, will till appear more groundles, too narrow and
inufficient. In the olid Parts, there is to be conider'd, their undue Conformation; too little, or too great, too narrow, or too wide in proportion to one another; and o their unequal trength, their being too hard or too oft, olid or poreous; with many unperceiv'd Solutions of Continuity, &c. from which, divers Dieaes, on divers occaions, may proceed; and all which, undue Conformations, unequal trengths or breaches, cannot be uppos'd o different and contrary, to proceed from the ingle abounding of Alkalies in the Blood. For intance, a large diproportionate Liver, mall Lungs, narrow Veins, Cartilaginous Aorta, ingle Kidney, inward imperceptible Breaches, are impoible to be accounted for, from the abounding of Alkali. 2. The Liquors or Contents of the Body may be too thick, or too thin; moved too fat, or retarded too much, Extravaated, or Coagulated in ome Veel or other; of which contrary Effects, the abounding of Alkalies onely, cannot be always either the occaional or formal Caue. 3. As to the < in non-Latin alphabet > of Hippocrates, or Archeus of Helmont; becaue ome more thinking Heads, than Mr. Acid's our one, have thought it too abtrue or ubtil a Notion: I hall firt tell you plainly, what I mean by it, leaving others to determine, whether Hippocrates and Helmont meant the ame. By the < in non-Latin alphabet > I mean the Soul, or Mind of Man in its extravagant Appetities: And that nothing ele ought to be undertood, by that of Man which is conider'd as an Agent; but his Mind is apparent from This, (which all coniderate Metaphyicians mut acknowledge as a Truth) That there is no Being we have any Idea of, but Mind and Body; the one being Active, the other Paive: And tho' all created Minds may uffer, as well as do; yet all Body is univerally un-active, and can do nothing. Tho' this Notion may eem a Paradox to ome, I hall ay no more of it here, than what relates to my preent purpoe; becaue I may have occaion to peak farther of it, if I live to finih a Dicoure I have for ome time pent ome thoughts upon, Of the • oot of Dieaes, and their Cure in Humane Nature. But to return to the buines in Hand, It is apparent, that the exorbitant Deire or violent action of the Will of Man; is that which often produces uch an alteration in his Body, as when perceiv'd becomes a Dieae. For intance, the Blood is too much retarded, or accelarated in its coure, as well as the more ubtile Liquors variouly diordered; from whence proceed divers ill Effects, which cannot be thought to proceed from the Production of too much Alkali, or retarding its uppoed neceary Evacuation in a Moment. The unatisfy'd deire in its mot udden Diappointments, cannot be thought to be
o great a Chymit, as to produce in an intant a greater quantiyt of Alkali Salt than the Body can bear, or o oon eparate the Acid that hould attemper it; but is rather to be thought, to produce its Effects in a more ubtil way. The force of Imagination and Deire upon the Body, is very well known, tho' the way of working thoe various Effects is little undertood: But I hall conider it no farther here, than in relation to Alkali, which is with no colour of Reaon to be thought either the Caue of thoe Mental Diorder, or the intrument of the Effects produc'd thereby. But to come a little cloer to the Term of abounding either of Alkali or Acid, in the liquid or olid Parts: When may either be aid to abound, o as to be likely to be the Caue of a Dieae? I anwer, When there is too much of the one or the other. And how hall we know that? May Gentlemen ay (for we will appeal to Gentlemen; yea, and Ladies too, if they will Read us: Poor Men and Phyicians we hall get but little by; tho' they hould think us Skilful Doctors.) I mut tell you, Sirs and Madams, there ought to be ome Conideration of the due Proportion, before we talk of abounding; and it is certain, That there is abundantly more Alkali in, or produc'd from the Blood and other Parts of Man's Body than Acid, and ought to be o in a ound Man, as we have een Demontrated by abundance of Experiments. The proportion of Alkali to Acid, we need not cruple to uppoe, no les than as twenty to one, when we have found the Alkali to the Salum as eventeen to one: But we will not pretend to acertain the Proportions; it being a very difficult matter to find them. But we will uppoe, twenty to one, or but ten to one if you pleae, to hew you that your Doctor John has talk'd like an As-ey'd Doctor to you. For if there ought to be but one part of Acid to ten of Alkali, and there be jut that proportion; neither can be aid to abound, or thought to caue a Dieae: But if there be two, or more parts of Acid to ten of Alkali, the Acid mut be aid to abound, or be too much, not the Alkali. And as for the little Trick John has hew'd you with Syrup of Violets, at the expence of two or three Ounces of your Blood (which in ome Caes ought not to be par'd.) I think, I hould undervalue your Parts, if I hould uppoe, you can't ee thro' the Juggle and make an Objection, where your Doctor ays he can ee none. For tho' Acid greatly abound, or be a deal too much; yet the Serum will not turn Syrup of Violets Red, unles there were more Acid then Alkali. And uch a quantity of Acid (if it were poible, in a Living Humane Body) would be a Ditemper too great, for either an Acid or an Alkali-Doctor ever to
reduce. And that you may atisfie your own Eyes, and judge whether Doctor Acid, or all the Phyicians in the World, ought to be Kick'd out of the Common-wealth; without the trouble, and ometimes hazard of loing two, or three Ounces of your Blood. Take Syrup of Violets, and drop into it a quantity of an Alkalous Spirit: and you will find it preently turn Green, and then take an Acid, and drop but a little in, and you hall not find it turn Red; but drop in till you have over-power'd the Alkali, it will turn Red; then drop in again of the Alkali, and as oon as you have over-power'd the Acid, it will turn Green again. By this Experiment you may be rationally perwaded, there may be too much Acid in the Blood, and o enough to caue a Dieae; tho' the Blood does not contain more Acid than Alkali; and o turn the Syrup Red. And that there may not be too much Alkali, tho' there is enough to turn the Syrup Greeen.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The Phyicians of our own Age, more particularly of our Nation, and among them (mot epecially of our College) have made greater Dicoveries in the Anatomy of the olid Parts, than ever were made before; but as for the fluids, wherein the Caue and Seat of Dieases lurk, they have in a great meaure been neglected: But the College abounds with Men of uch large Capacities, that if once they et about the Work, I doubt not, but they will perfect it. Being Skill'd in the Anatomy of the olid Parts. A Noble Qualification! Enables a Man to talk finely; but do's not in the leat enable him to Cure Dieaes. For it's an exact skill in the Anatomy of the Juices, that makes a Man a good Phyician. And I have made it the buines of my Life, to undertand rightly the the Juices of Humane Bodies in their Natural and Morbid States; and by that means have been capable of doing more than other People; and I tell you, that the Blood has never any Acid in it; but when People are in a perfect tate of Health: Nay, I tell you, the Blood can't over-abound with Acids, neither in a Morbid nor Healthy State: For tho' manifet Acids, are things the Stomach much more covets and delights in, than any thing beides: When he is loaded with more than the Body has occaion for, he won't fail of rejecting them by Vomit; which may be experienc'd by an over large Draught of Vinegar; but altho it can't over-doe; yet it is very defective in conveying a ufficient quantity into it, thro' its own fault, or the Phyicians. But the Blood of Dieaed Perons has more Alkali, than that of the Healthy; as in Fits of the Gout, it abounds with Alkalous Particles, more than in Health as ix to four, or five and a half, or as five to four; which you will find in my Book of Blood, where my Experiments are as clear Demontrations of my Hypotheis, as what is given by the greatet
Mathematicians. So in the Small-Pox and in Scorbutick Perons it does appear by many Tryals, that the Blood of uch Perons does more abound with Alkalous Particles, than that of ound People, and a Sick Peron's Serum will turn Syrup of Violets Green ooner than a well Peron's. And if Phyicians would Critically Analize the Blood in all Ditempers, I believe, thereby the Caue of all Dieaes would be certainly known.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Mr. Acid, you are very lavih of your praies where you place your favour; I wonder the College who have o great a hare of them, are not ufeited. They have made more Dicoveries in the Anatomy of the olid Parts, you ay, than ever was made before. What Dicoveries have they made I pray you? Wherein have they out-done others, either of the foregoing Age, or Foreigners of this? What improvements have they made in the Anatomy of the olid Parts? You know perhaps, but you won't tell us: and 'tis no matter, whether it be any thing or nothing. For being skil'd in the Anatomy of the olid Parts is a Noble Qualification you ay: But how do's it Ennoble a Man? Why, onely enables him to talk finely; but do's not in the leat enable him to Cure Dieaes. It is an exact Skill in the Anatomy of the Juices, that makes a Man a good Phyician; which Anatomy has been neglected even by our College. What is the inference of this? Why, our College have a Noble Qualification of Talking finely; but not in the leat an ability to Cure Dieaes. Pray you Sir, what are the People the better for the Colleges Ability to Talk finely; if they have none to Cure Dieaes. No, but they are Men of large Capacities! Capable of perfecting the Anatomy of the Juices too, if they would but once et about the Work. But when that will be, who knows? They undertand Philoophy enough already (tho' their Friend John ays no) and while they are in that Opinion, they will hardly learn more. While they think the Anatomy of the olid Parts is enough for them; they will never et about the Anatomy of the Fluids by Mr. Acid's Direction: And o for ought we know, they are like to remain Phyicians in Verbo only; Fine Talkers. But Mr. Acid is the only Phyician in Re, indeed, amongt them. 'Twas great Prudence in them to take you into the College Sir, that they might have one real Phyician to actuate the ret; that they might not be a Body without a Soul: You know Acid is the Soul of the World. And an As-Ey'd Doctor may as well be the Soul of the College. I can hardly think, they would o readily have given you a Licence; but that they expected you would do omething for them, they could not do for themelves; run down the Badger, catch the Salmon, or ome other piece of Difficulty.
You, who have made it the Buines of your Life, to undertand rightly the Juices of Humane Bodies in their Natural and Morbid States; by that means have been capable of doing more than other People (if you ay true) more than all the ret of the College. But you are a Particle of the College, and what you do; is the doing of the College. 'Tis well they have you, that they may not only be aid to do omething; but more than other People; tho' not in the whole, yet in one part of them, viz. Mr. Acid. But truly John, your crying down the Skill in the Anatomy of the olid Parts, is but a dull way of excuing your Ignorance therein, and you do but as Block-heads commonly do, cry down as ueles, all Knowledg they themelves have not; that Fools may think them Wie enough. But I mut tell you John, and the Gentlemen too, That the Skill in the Anatomy of the Solids, is o far neceary, that the Anatomy of the Juices ignifies little to a Phyician without it. The Animal Oeconomy can never be well undertood in its due Order and Defects, by one that knows nothing of the Structure of the Parts. For intance, tho' I knew the Gall to be of uch, and uch, a Nature and Quality, and by a Pyrotechnical Analyis, to yield uch, and uch different Bodies, or Sets of Particles: What am I the wier, as a Phyician, unles I know where this, thus qualify'd Liquor, is eparated and dicharg'd? How otherwie, can I determine of the Ue, or Defects of this Liquor? So likewie as to the other Liquors of the Body: How can I know their Motions, Secretions and Ues, unles I know which way they pas, and where eparated? Was the Famous Harvey, or Servetus before him, nothing the better for being aware of the ways of the circular Motion of the Blood, but only that they could Talk finely. Fye John, you don't talk like a Light in Phyick, much les in Chirurgery. I mut tell you, if you had been skill'd in the Anatomy of the olid Parts; you would not only have talk'd more finely; but more truly than you do, as we hall ee in a Material intance before we have done. And as you have foolihly confes'd your Ignorance in the Anatomy of the olid Parts (a hame to any Phyician, epecially to one that Writes himelf of the Noble College) o I believe, I hall find you ignorant of the Anatomy of the Fluids too; and that it will appear, you have not done more than other People in any thing, but Impudent Boating! You tell me, that the Blood has never any Acid in it, but when People are in a perfect tate of Health; and that it can't uper-abound, neither in a Morbid, nor Healthy tate: For tho' the Stomach covets Acids more than any thing ele, he will not fail to reject what's more than enough, by Vomit; but tho' he can't over-doe, yet he's very defective
through her own, or the Phyician's fault. You are a cunning Man! Of a he Stomach. You once told us, That all Perons have ome degree of Sicknes. Now that the Blood has never any Acid in it, but in a perfect tate of Health. But I anwer, If all Perons have ome degree of Sicknes; then none are in perfect Health; and if none are in perfect Health, according to you, none have any Acid in their Blood. Yet again you tell us, That Leannes is for want of enough Acid in the Blood, and Fat is nothing but a concrete of Acid and oily Parts; and over-much Fatnes, if it may be call'd a Dieae, is caus'd by Acids. What a miery it is for a Man to have a Treacherous Memory; o to contradict himelf. If Fat be a concrete of Acid and Oily Parts, wherever there is Fat there is Acid; but there's Fat in Perons under many Dieaes: I have open'd a Body, before now, that Dy'd of another Dieae than Fatnes, that cut two or three Inches in Fat upon the Abdomen: And Fatnes in ome, is Dieae enough; and if your Doctrine were true, nothing could be more proper than Alkalies to Cure it. But farther Sir, If there be never any Acid in the Blood; but in a State of perfect Health: How can Acids Cure the Dieaes of the Blood: Mortifie and Expel the luxriant Alcalous Particles, reduce the erum to fluidity, make the too thick Blood thin, and the too thin Blood thick, The Miracles of Acids! That he that can hew how this can be, what Acids taken in the Latitude can do, mut be as Wie as Solomon, the Wiet Man that ever was, or hall be. Yet you tell us, That Acids produce thee different things, by being differently pecificated with other things, but Acid is the oul of them. And o Solomon is not the Wiet Man, for you are as Wie as he. But tho' I believe there has been, or may be, one Man at leat Wier than Solomon, and you too Sir, I much quetion whether he would be cunning enough to tell, how all thee fine things come to pas, which you ay are done in the Blood of Dieaed Perons by Acids, if as you ay, there never comes any Acid there, but in a tate of perfect Health; or how he could make it appear, that the tomack o unerringly rejects to a grain, whatever of its beloved Acid is too much to be convey'd into the Blood, and yet is foolihly defective in letting in enough. But to leave thee contradictions to their Author, and to perwade you (at leat the Gentlemen, who are uch impartial Judges) that there is even too much Acid in the Blood in many Dieaes, I might firt give you a Hundred Authorities from Famous and Learned Authors, but that Authority is nothing to you, who have cry'd down all the Phyitians in the World. Yet methinks the judgment of ome of them might be of ome weight with you, epecially thoe you
have commended, and perhaps the Gentlemen may believe them as oon as you. Your Brother Etmuller aerts Acids in the Blood as the caue of many Dieaes: It would be endles to recite the Paages; o I hall give you but two or three. Of the Gout, ays he, page 361. Partis ecundae. Quoad cauam efficientem Acidum volatile Spirituoum ui tamen generis, eu pecifici aporis piritui influo maritatum ynoviam imprimis, & partes vicinas membranaceas inquinans, & affligens primarius Tortor et. And pag. 394. De malo Hypochondriaco, & corbuto, ays he, Caua proxima horum malorum complicatorum et Stomachi cruditas Acida, ive Acidum ventriculi vitioum, ex defectu vitioo digetionis primae in tomacho enatum, a quo omnia reliqua ymptomata originem ducunt. And as for Feavers, ays he, page 251. Partis primae. Conitere dicimus Febrim formaliter in fermentatione anguinis praeternaturali. And page 252. Aetus omnis occaionalis fit ab Acido crafin anguinis immutante, & inde fermentativum ejus motum, hinc Spirituum alterationem & majorem incalecentiam, & fervorem inducente. And goes on to prove by many Arguments, that Acid is chiefly in the fault in Feavers. And page 369. he aiys, the ame in relation to the Small-Pox. The forementioned Hoffman (the rather to be noted, becaue he Writes on purpoe to contradict the fancy of thoe that would make Acid, and vicid the caue of all Dieaes) gives us Intances, and Arguments to prove Acids the caue of ome Dieaes. Cap. 2. De acido & vicido, ays he, Caeterum quantas torturas acidum vitioum in corpore notro excitet, tetantur Hypocondriaci, hytericae, corbutici qui a leviimo acido mire aepe laeduntur exacerbatis omnibus ymptomatibus: tetantur quoque, id iporum vomituae, aepe tam corroivi, ac tanta aciditate praediti ut vaa aenea, imò ipe linteamina, intar aquae fortis, corroa inde videas. And gives us a relation of two Brothers, who by accutoming themelves to drink Vinegar, were brought, the one into an incurable hectick Feaver with a Cough, and leannes of his whole Body, and horrid pain of his Feet; and the other, into very great diorders. And adds he, Tandem obervatu dignum quodam qui quoties utuntur aceto, altero mane pruritum in fontanellis entire manifeto indicio acidum intactum, & integrum penetralia corporis ubire poe. And your Mater Helmont, becaue you have confes'd him a greater Man than you, may be heard aying, page 319. Tormina ab acido intetinorum, in lotio tranguria, in ulceribus corroio, in pelle Soabies, in artubus podagra, &c. Quod i experire velis ad manum, emictae noviter abque dolore urinae, aliquot altem guttas vini aciduli immice, & per yringam injice. Experieris te invito quod vera doceam. In latice quoque pluritidem notham, ucitat. At i Archeus in cruoris gremium leviculam ibi initro applicatam aciditatem
depouit; tatim extravenatur, ejicitur a venis preta, & apotema parit ubicunque id locorum contigerit: in vero profundius in venis eveniat petilens aliquod Pathema inurgit. Quod probo quippe eruor aut caro nunquam aceerunt abque actuali putrefactionis conecutione (quod alibi per carnes belluarum, ub canicula ociime putrefientes, ideo juculum acidum dantes probavi ex intituto) cruor enim acecens mox contra naturam venarum totiuque carnis indolem (quandiu vivit) coagulatur. But if your Mater Helmont be depis'd with you, be pleas'd to hear what Father Hippocrates ays, an Old Gentleman o venerable among Phyitians, that I never met with any one yet that had the confidence to depie him; tho' many that never read him. Says he in his Dicoure De veteri Medicina;
