Which, leat you hould complain of Heathen-Greek, and ay, Non potet legi; I will give you in Englih, thus: For thereis in Man Bitter and Salt, and Sweet and Acid, and Atringent and Humid, and others innumerable; having all Kinds of Faculties abundance and Strength. Thee indeed, being mix'd and contemper'd with one another, are neither apparent, nor hurt a Man: But when either of thee is eparated, and is of it elf; then it is apparent and hurts a Man. And again, ays he, of our Food, Whatoever things are diagreeing and hurt a Man being taken in; each of thee is omething Bitter and Intemperate, or Salt or Acid, or omething ele intemperate and trong; and for this Caue we are
troubl'd by them, as alo by thoe things which are eparated out of the Body. And a little after, ays he, If the weet Juice is chang'd to another Form, not by mixture; but being of it elf what it was before, Bitter, or Salt, or Atringent, or Acid; but the Acid Juice is diagreeing, the ret being for the mot part profitable, but the Sweet Juice of all is mot agreeing. But if the Judgment of thee Famous Men, be not enough; let me reaon with you a little farther my elf. How can Dieaes if caus'd by Alkali (as you ay) be Cur'd by Acids, but by Acids coming into the Blood. Mut not there be ome time for their Operation there, before they can mortifie and expel the Abundant Alkali, o as that Acid mut be in the Blood, while the Peron is yet Dieas'd? Or, do's Alkali leap out at one Door as afrighted, eeing Acid with his our Face coming in at another? Are your Cures all o udden? No John, I uppoe not. But altho' there were no Acid-Doctor to convey our Liquors into the Blood; yet I ay, there may be Acid, and that too much, in the Blood of a Dieas'd Peron, as the caue of his Dieae. It's undoubted among Phyicians, that the Health of the Body, very much conits in the due Temper and Conitence of the Blood, and other Liquors of the Body, that they be neither too thick nor too thin. If they be too thick, they cannot pus freely through the mall Veels, and circulate through the Aanatomoes of the Arteries and Veins, but tick and caue Obtructions; whence arie Swellings and Pains, by ditention of the Parts, and the Liquors tagnating; get a fermentavive Motion, and o corrupt and corrode the olid Parts, and produce Ulcers: But if the Obtruction be ooner open'd, and the Coagulated Parts be carry'd along again into the Mas of Blood; it is thereby retarded in its motion, before the Particles can be eparated; from whence may proceed divers Diorders. Now it's certain, that Acids coagulate and thicken the Blood, and other Juices of the Body, as any one may ee by mixing a little Acid Liquor, as Oyl of Vitrol, p. of Niter, Oyl of Sulphur, &c. with a little Blood, or Serum: The Acids turning the Serum into thick white Corruption, and the Red part into a tough black Matter. So Acid Liquors injected into the Veins of Animals kill them by coagulating their Blood: When on the other Hand, Alkalous Liquors make the Blood more thin and florid, on which account it cannot be thought, by any Body that has his Senes, that when the Blood is too thick, or coagulated, 'its caus'd by Alkalies, and not by Acids. You aid Mr. Acid, that Whoever hou'd take upon them to Anwer any thing you have aid, unles they back their Arguments with Experiments, you hould take no notice of them. But truly Sir, you have not back'd your Aertion. That Acids make the
Blood thin when too thick with Experiments. I would counel the Gentlemen to do it for you, and they will ee how friendly your Acids are to the Blood. Beides, that there's too much Acid in the Blood, in ome Dieaes, may fairly be argu'd, a Juvantibus & laedentibus. It being commonly een, that Perons afflicted with ome Dieaes, are very much hurt and the Symptoms exaperated by the ue of Acids, as Hypocondriacks, Hyterical and Scorbutick Perons; thoe afflicted with divers kinds of Ulcers and that have Iues: On the contrary Reliev'd, Eas'd and Heal'd by Alkalies; as is well known to Phyicians and Chirurgeons. Farther, to atisfie you, becaue by all the ways you could yet contrive, you have not been able to procure one Grain of pure Acid from the Blood either of Healthy, or Sick People. I'll teach you. From the Blood of either Dieas'd or Healthy Perons, as alo from their Urine which is eparated, from thence you may get a Sal alum, like Sea-Salt, which you ay, is an Acid; but I ay, yields an Acid by Ditillation, and from Fleh and Blood, as well as from Urine, may be got the Phophorus, which is an Oyl coagulated into an open Sulphur, by an Acid; which Acid may be as eaily eparated, as the Acid is from common Sulphur, which is eaie enough, tho' you ay, 'tis no eaie matter to do it. And from Urine, an excrement of the Blood, beides Phophorus, I have made a perfect burning Sulphur, without any addition of any Body that could yield it, or help to compoe it; which Sulphur would make good Matches, and might be Ditill'd into Oyl of Sulphur, per Campanam as eaily as any other Sulphur; and every thing is diolv'd, you ay, into that of which it was made. But I ay, not by every ort of Diolution. But that in a common Ditillation of Blood, by uch a Ditiller as your elf, there's no Acid produc'd, is eaie to anwer, by an Experiment or two. For intance, I will take an Alkali, and mix with it a coniderable quantity of an Acid, and you hall Ditill them, and hall not get one Grain of Acid; but an Alkalous Liquor. Again, I will take an Alkali, and mix an Acid with it, and you hall Ditill them, and hall not get one Grain of Acid; but they hall both unite, and both come over in a Liquor, neither an Alkali, nor Acid but a alum. Again, I will take an Alkali, and mix an Acid with it, and you hall Ditill them, and hall get neither Acid, Alkali nor Salum; but a burning Oyl. Which things, if you are a Chymit, as you profes, you can't be Ignorant of. From which Experiments, it may eaily be believ'd, that tho' there may be a mall quantity of Acid, actually in the Blood, yea, a large quantity in comparion of what there hould be; yet the Alkali far exceeding it; the Acid may be o far alter'd by the Fire, or lock'd up with the Alkali, as to come over as an Alkali, or
remain a Salum? And though a mere Salum cannot truly be aid to be either an Acid, or an Alkali, or have an affect as either, Whatever eparations or alterations the Fire, may make from it, or upon it; yet it is certain that the Natural or Artificial Conjunction of an Acid with an Alkali, does make a Salum, and nothing is more common, than to have the Blood apparantly Salt, even to the tate, in many Caes, in ome more, ome les; which Salum (tho' the Acid that is coagulated with the Alkali were not eparate in the Body firt, and o capable of hurting) is very likely as a Salum, to be the Caue of divers Dieaes, when it too much abounds; which we may eaily believe, from this Conideration, That it's well known, that the Eating too much common Salt, is the Caue of many Diorders. As for intance Seamen (as you confes) who live upon Salt-meat, and Salt-fih, are more troubled with the Scurvey than others, not as you ay, becaue they eat more Fleh and Fih (which abound with Alkalous parts) than others: For others that cat as much Fleh and Fih, and that freh too, are not o much troubled with it, but becaue their Fleh and Fih is more Salt, and is alo kept longer, whereby the Spiritous and Volatile parts are exhal'd, and o yield a groer Chyle. Nor as you ay, That the moit Air hinders perpiration; For it is well known, That Men at Sea generally eat more, and void fewer Excrements of the Belly, than at Land, and conequently perpire more. Nor is the Sea-Salt carry'd off all by rine, it being to be found in a greater or leer quantity in the Blood, and other Liquors of the Body. Nor can Sea Salt, and any Alkali make a Sal Armoniack, as you tell us, either in the Body, or by a Pyrothechnical Conjunction; unles the Sea-Salt be firt an Acid, as I have found by experience, and any body may ee that will try to make a Sal Armoniack. And tho' the Air at, Sea hould hinder weat, as you ay, yet it furthers Perpiration; whereby the Alkalies if they could do any hurt, may be carry'd off, if that be uppos'd the coure they ought to go. And that we perpire more when we don't weat, than when we do (tho' it may eem trange to ome) might be urg'd by divers Reaons, if it were neceary, and may be try'd by Staticks. How an Acid Spirit hould be Ditill'd from Sea-Salt while in the Blood, or other Liquors of the Body, I confes I ee not, but I know by certain Experience, that there's often eparated, or produc'd in the Stomach, a Praternatural Acid, a kind of Vinegar, from things taken in, that are fermentable into Vinegar; as Sugar, Honey, Bread, trong Liquors; which tho' in their firt ingeted Form, could not be truly call'd Acids, yet become very trong ones, and if they were Acids grow tronger. Beides, every one knows,
that we Eat and Drink things already our, both which we know, are not always rejected by Vomit (as Mr. Acid aies) But notwithtanding, there's a more trict Guard for keeping the Acids out <>
the Blood, viz, the Gall pouring out its forces upon them in the mall Guts; yet it's very probable that ome Acid Particles more than hould o do, may pas this Watch, and get in with the Chyle into the Veins; of which Enemy, we are after aware, by the diturbance made in the Vital Oeconomy, which Phyicians of any coniderable Judgment and Practice will eaily be perwaded of. But I hall here give you two or three Intances of Acids found even eparate in farther Recees than the Stomach and Guts. One intance was in a Cancerous-Breat, Cut off by one Mr. Smith a Chirurgeon of the Hopital (divers other Peron tetifying the truth of the matter, being preent) who when he had done the Operation, and came to examine the Breat, ope ••
ing a Citus, found therein a Liquor, which being pour'd on the Ground fermented as it were Aqua fortis; which when he adventured to tate was an Acid, and withall o penetrating and venemous, that he could not wah away the tate; but it Infected his whole Body; o as to be the occaion of his Death within ome few Months, as he himelf affirm'd, on his Decth-bed, to an Eminent Phyician, who gave me the Account, and was alo at the Amputation. Again, Etmuller tells you, in Medicina Hippocrates Cap. 2. That he was acquainted with a Youth vehemently afflicted with the Itch, whoe Itchey-Ulcers being open'd by cratching, pour'd forth a erous Liquor of a manifetly Acid odour, as it were of a ubtil and penetrating Vinegar. And that he aw a Scorb •
tick Young Man, who in a Morning yet fating, pit uch a harp bloody Spittle upon a firm double Paper, that it was thence in a hort time corroded. Another intance you have in Act: Med: Haffn. Vol. 4. Pag. 174. Where it's oberv'd that the Sweat of an Hydropick Peron was Acid coagulating Milk. Beides, the Cure of Ulcers, Itch, Eryipelas's, &c. which I have often done by Aborbents and manifet Alkalies, arguing Acids to abound in thee Caes. I don't quetion, but if we try other proper ways, Acids would be found in divers Ulcers, tho' Mr. Smith's fate, is enough to dicourage one from Tating. But you ay, the Blood of Dieaed Perons contains or yields more Alkali, than that of Sound Perons. I anwer, It's a more difficult thing than you, or any other young Chymit would imagine, exactly to find the quantity of Alkali-Salt in a parcel of Blood. To eparate the Volatile-Salt wholly from the Phlegm, and from the Oyl, and both of them from the Caput mort. will be found too hard a Task for an older Work-man than your elf. The difficulty of giveing an exact account of the
contents of a parcel of Blood, will appear from divers Coniderations. Blood is a Body that will well up as it drys, o that the top of the matter will have les Heat than the bottom, and retain ome of the Volatile Parts; o that if you don't take it out and Ditil part of it again in another Retort, you will not get all, and notwithtanding all the care poible, ome of the Volatile parts will be lot in working; o that the mot wary Artit, do what he can, will not be able to ay, Here's all the Alkali, or Oyl, contain'd in o much Blood. But there will be till greater Difficulties in giving the true Contents in divers parcels of Blood; for if you hould take a Pound, or any other quantity of Blood, and divide it into equal parts, and Ditil one half in one Retort, the other in another, the products would not be the ame. For the different degrees of Fire that might happen, different time of Ditilling, and taking off, and eparating the Phlegm, Oyl, and Salt, the different cloenes of Luteing, yea, the very hapes and izes of the Retorts and Receivers, would almot in inevitably caue different Products. Farther, the Bloods of divers Perons, tho' all in Health, or of one healthy Peron, took at divers times, would as much differ in the Products, as that of the Dieas'd and Healthy, as well as vary upon other Tryals. As I have een the Sweat of a Peron in perfect Health, turn Syrup of Violets Green readily, when the very ichor and corruption in the putles of the Small-Pox, would hardly alter its colour into a dicernable Greennes. So the Blood of the ame Dieas'd Peron, taken at one time or tate of the Dieae, would as much differ from that taken at another time, as either of them would from a Sound Peron's; having ometimes more, ometimes les Serum. So that I mut tell you, you have not been a Chymit long enough, to deerve Credit, ince it appears you have not yet Learn'd to peak modetly and wyrily; but confidently give us, from mall and odd quantities of Blood (the more difficut, to be exact in) o many Drachms, Scruples, and Grains as the certain Contents of Phlegm, Salt, Oyl, and Caput mort. from which exact account the agacious Mr. Boyle excus'd himelf: And no expert Chymit will readily pretend to give. But you Sir, pretend to give us the true Proportion of Alkalies in a Gouty Man's Blood, and a well Man's; when you have Ditill'd perhaps but two or three well Men's Blood, and one or two Gouty Men's Blood. Do you not think the Bloods of Gouty Men differ, as well as the Bloods of well Men? Let us have the products of a Pound of Blood, from one hundred well Men's Bloods, or o many ick Men's Bloods; and if they are exactly the ame, then you may do omething toward perwading us to harken to you: Or if you can tell us the exact proportion
and difference of the Products of an Acid Doctor's Blood from thoe of an Alkali Doctor's: Till which, I hall never expect to find your Experiments in your promis'd Book of Blood, as clear Demontrations of your Hypotheis, as what is given by the greatet Mathematicians; unles you mean, as clear Demontrations, as they give of your Hypotheis, and not of their own Propoitions And if all the vat Capacities of the College, and you to direct them, hould ever o Critically (Analize, as you call it) the Blood of Perons in all Dieaes (which by the way, I tell you could not well be done, when Phlebotomy in ome Dieaes is pernicious,) I ay, they would be far from knowing certainly the Caue of all Dieaes; if all Dieafes could be thought to <>
in the Blood: For many Reaons, apparent to every coniderate and experienc'd Naturalit: Tho' a Tyro may believe, by his <>
he can do all things; even hew a Man in the Ditillation of a little of his Wifes Blood, without ever eeing her, that he has <>
the Pox; and the very Face of the Spark that Clap'd her, with as great confidence, as ome young Logicians, believe, by a Sy •
logime, they can prove the Moon made of Green-Chee: <>
as I have heard one eriouly aert, That by Logick, one migh •
prove a Man to be a Hore, or a Hore to be an As. But let us uppoe, that John has gues'd right (tho' not Demontrated that a quantity of the Blood of one, or another Dieas'd Peron is ome Ditempers being Ditill'd yields more Alkali, than as muc •
of the Blood of ome one, or other Healthy Peron (for he has made but few tryals:) It will not prove, that in thoe Ditempers, too much Alkali was the caue of the Dieae, and not too much Acid. For intance, in the Small-Pox, Scurvey, Go ••
where he particularly aerts, he has found the Blood abounding with Alkili more than in Sound Perons: I ay, that in thoe, an •
ome other Ditempers we may reaonably uppoe, that the Acid Particles meeting ome of the Alkalous, are Precipitated, and fix ••
in the exttemities; o that the ret of the Mas of Blood flowin •
in the Veins and Arteries is depurated, and more free from Acidity, and o in Ditillation, may poibly yield a greater proportion of Alkali. But I find you Mr. Acid, make a few light and in acurate Experiments, making them all erve your Hypotheis running away with your < in non-Latin alphabet > with as little conideration and as great mitakes, as any body I have met with. You boat your elf better Skill'd in the Anatomy of the Juices, tha •
others, and that, you are able to do more than other People Truely Sir, I find no Argument of your greater Skill, or doing more than others; we have but your greater Skill, or doing more than others; we have but your own word for it. But pray you, let me hear what knowledge you have got of the Nature
and Properties of ome other of the Liquors of the Body? What may you to the Saliva, the firt we meet with.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The Spittle is highly impregnated with a penetrating Saline Spirit, which appears from its killing Mercury, which nothing will do, but things manifetly Saline: This matter eparated by the Oral Glands, is impregnated with a Volatile Acid, as manifet
••
appears: And was deign'd to impregnate our Food, and to diolve it in the Stomach, and turn it into a ubtance fit for
• utrition: For there's no innate ferment in the Stomach: And that this Mentruum the Saliva, is an Acid, appears by numerous Experiments; yea, all noble Mentruums, I know of, are Acids, in the three Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
You till go on to hew your dareing Confidence and Indicretion, in aerting poitively, things you have but the leat appearance of Reaon for. You ay, the Spittle is highly impregnated with a Saline Spirit, with a noble volatile Acid: That it manifetly appears to be an Acid and that from numerous Experiments; when you have made none: And give us no other Argument, but that of its killing Mercury, which you ay, nothing will do, but things manifetly Saline. Here is a Liquor, I find you have never Anatomiz'd; here Mercury alone, reolves your Quetion, who as the Old Woman aies, is kill'd by Fating-pittle: But I mut tell you, the Old Woman had but one Eye, and o thought that Mercury was dead and bury'd, when the Wagg lay granning, on the Blind-ide of her: And you are as Blind a Chymit as he, if you talk of killing of Mercury thus, to Phyicians and Philoophers. But you talk as a Mountebank, to the Vulgar. Well, Spittle in a Vulgar ene, kills Mercury: But what does it really do to it? Why it divides it, being rubb'd together, into mall Particles, that a dull Eye cannot perceive them. And this is done by nothing, but things manifetly Saline, ay you. I ee the Clerk has forgot that ever he was a Sexton. Mr. Doctor, if your Memory had not been Treacherous, you might have remembred, That when you was an Apothecary's Boy at Worceter, your Mater was not o imperfect in his Art, but that he taught you, that Turpentine, would thus kill Quick-ilver, and Turpentine, it is well known, is not manifetly Saline: I believe, you would be hardly put to it, to get me a Salt from it, or any thing of a Saline nature. Greee likewie is a Body, whereby the Particles of Mercury may be divided; or almot any Body of a oft clammy Conitence; not from any thing Saline in uch Bodies, but from their coniting of ramous flexible Parts, whereby they are apt to enwrap and entangle the globules of Mercury; yea, even dead and inipid Calxes, or other Powders, may be rubb'd with Mercury, o as to do, what you call
killing, tho' with more labour. As <> things manifetly Sali ••
(except thoe Acid Spirits, that diolve Mercury) they are ti ••
farther from doing the buines, than Unctuous Bodies. As if you take common Salt, you hall find it more difficult to kill Mercu ••
therewith, than with Turpentine or Greae; and with ome Sal •••
Liquors it will not be done at all. But if you had made as man •
Experiments on the Saliva, as you would have us believe, you would have found, that according to your own method of trying thing •
it is not manifetly Acid: (Not to mention the judgment by th •
Tate) you know, that manifet Acids turn Syrup of Violets Red •
Spittle in all the Tryals that I have made, (which have not been •
few) never turn'd the Syrup Red, but Green, more or les which tho' I will not ay, is alone an infallible Argument, •
prove it an Alkali; yet I ay, it is enough to prove it not a •
Acid. I acknowledg indeed, as it's mot Reaonable to do, th •
the Saliva, mut be thought to differ, as the Blood from whence it's eparated, differs in divers Perons, and may be Acid in ome Dieaes, as I noted before: And the mot of the Tryals I have made on this Liquor, were on the Saliue of Sound Perons. I will not venture to determine, that Mr. Acid's Saliva mut be as Alkali: When he ues o much Vinegar, Lemons and Oranges, Oy •
of Vitriol, &c. or that his old Patients, may not pit Acid:
<>
what I have try'd, has been from thoe that often Eat and Drin ••
Acid things, and are ometimes troubled with too much Acidity i •
their Stomachs, and yet I could find no igns of Acid in their Saliva Tho' I mix'd it with Milk, and let it tand to ee whether it wou ••
thereby turn our the ooner: I found that another parcel tha •
had none in it, was turn'd ooner than that. But this is Obervable tho' Spittle is often more thick and clammy than the Serum o •
Blood; yet it will not o oon be coagulated by the Fire, and no •
at all by Acid Spirits, as Blood and its Serum will: And as Blood Serum, and other Animal ubtances evaporated on the Fire, will giv •
but an unpleaant Smell; on the contrary, I have always found Spittle when evaporated (if not o far as to be burnt) yield a grateful Savour. But let us ee what this Liquor appears by Pyrotechnical examination, taking your own Rules for the preent (tho' I may dient from them another time) That thoe things which by Ditillation yield a greater quantity of Acid than of Alkalous Subtance, are to be reputed Acids, & evice vera, and that every thing is diolv'd into that of which it was made. Take the Saliva of a Sound Peron (as I did, a good quantity; becaue it yields but little beide Phlegm •
Ditill it gently in a Retort, and you will find the greatet part of it come over in an in • pid Water, or Phelgm; when you ee the matter in the Bottom dry, increae the Fire, and there will come
•• er an Alkalous Spirit in White fumes, and after that a black
•• nking Oyl: The Spirit is very like that Ditill'd from Blood, turns
•• rup of Violets Green preently, and ferments with Acids, and
• the firt Ditillation I have oberved a volatile Salt, tick in the Neck of the Retort. From the Caput mort. is Extracted with Water, a mall quantity of Sal alum, very like common Salt;
<> is o far from turning Syrup of Violets Red, that it inclines into a Greennes, and is diolv'd by and ferments with Oyl of Vitriol, like common Salt. Where hall we find your Noble Acid Mentruum now Sir? And where are the numerous Experiments, whereby it appears to be Acid? You firt concluded the Saliva to be a Noble Mentruum, I uppoe, and all the Noble Mentruums, in the Three Kingdoms, you know of, being Acids: Therefore this mut be an Acid. I dare ay: you know no Noble Mentrum in either of the Three Kingdoms; and I quetion, whether you ever aw an Ounce of Acid Mentruum from the Animal Kingdom, tho' there is uch a thing to be had in great quantity. It has been the Opinion of many Phyicians, That there is an Acid Mentrum, or Ferment in the Stomach: You ay, there is no innate Ferment there: But the Saliva was deign'd to impregnate our Food, and diolve it in the Stomach. I mut tell you, thereis no need of an Acid Mentruum, or Ferment in the Stomach, either there generated, or brought from ome other Part. As for my own Stomach, I have a Capacity of knowing what is in it at all times, which few Men have; and I always obe • ve, when my Stomach is in bet order, there is no Acid there; not o much as to curdle Milk, or turn Syrup of Violets Red: But whenever there is an Acid, is is produced from omething or other ingeted, and is preternatural, and diagreeing: And I very eldom find my Stomach out of order, but from things ingeted, that are, or turn our, or ele from things too fat and oily. I will not here contend with thoe who make the Saliva the Mentruum, or Ferment of the Stomach, if it has any thing properly o call'd; But I ee no more reaon to think, that the eparation, diviion, or alteration of out Food, is performed by virtue of that mall quantity of Alkali, Salt Oyl, or Salum, produc'd from the Saliva, by the Fire; than that the in
• briating quality of Wine proceeds from a volatile Alkalous Spirit, that by Art, is therehence obtain'd. But I conclude, that unles Mankind have divers orts of Ferments, or Mentruums in their Stomachs, there's never any manifet Acid requir'd there, or produc'd, but what is preternatural.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
It's well known, few People are troubled with Acidity in their Stomachs, but thoe that ue very little Exercie, or live a edentary Life; by which means, the Chyle when made,
for want of motion (the fibers of the Stomach alo having lo ••
their tone, and become lax) is not oon enough carryed one of the Stomach, and lying there too long, the greatet part <>
turn'd into a ubtance like unto the Ferment, which at fir •
diolv'd it; it being the nature of Ferments to endeavour the •
change of thoe things they are mix'd with into their own <>
And that ome may ay, How hall this Acid be kept from being convey'd into the Blood, and o being the Caue of Dieaes. <>
anwer, Thoe that have an extraordinary Acidity in their Stomachs, 1t. Make Water often, and in large quantities. 2dly. A •
very Lean. 3ly. Are Cotive, all which Symptoms are for want o •
the Acid of the Stomach's being convey'd into the Blood. The •
make more Water, becaue the olid Food is by too much <>
attenuated, and converted into a thin ubtance, which by the •
preure of the Liver on the Stomach, intead of paing thro' th •
Pylorus, is queez'd thro' certain Veels which pas from the botto •
of the Stomach to the Kidneys, and o carry'd off by Urine. An •
that there are uch Veels, ee Doleus Enhcyclopaed. Med. pag. 359. I uppoe ays he, liquid Subtances may be convey'd from the Stomach thro' the Omentum to the Kidneys, hence thoe Animal •
that have no Gall, make no Water, as Birds and Fihes: For confirmation of which Opinion, I have Diected Animals gorging the •
with Water before, and found the Veels of the Caul very turgid. In Hydropical People I have Diected, I have found the Caul ether torn, putrify'd, or obtructed with Oedematous Tumours whence it follows, Liquids contain'd in the Stomach, mut fall into the Abdomen. Alo a Peron Cut for an Omental Rupture, par •
of the Caul being Cut away, had a difficulty of making Water and if he Drink much has a pain and weight at his Stomach, and <>
always Looe: Hence in my Conjecture, ome Veels that carry the Uirne right on to the Emulgents were Cut, by which means, all the Drink he drank, was carry'd into the Duodenum. It is therefor •
certain, that Liquid Subtances lying at the bottom of the Stomach pas thro' in that part which is join'd to the Caul, and if thoe Veels, or the Caul it elf are broken, putrify'd, or obtructed it necearily follows, that the Liquid Subtances contain'd in the Stomach, mut be let fall into the Cavity of the Abdomen, and for Dropie is caus'd. Thus Doleus. From this Doctrine may be great conolation to People labouring under the Stone. A reaon I believe, Perons have not made uch diligent earch for uch Medicines, has been a uppoition, that carce any Medicine could retain its Vertue thro' o many alterations: But were they atisfy'd of this horter Cut, they would not think the diolving the Stone o hard a Task: Farther to prove the Exitence of thee Paages,
•• d that the Medicines may pas unalter'd to the Kidneys and Blad
•• r: Take thee two Caes, 1t. A Peron that had not made Wa
•••
in two Days, and had an intolerable pain in his Back, I gave him ome Medicines, and in an Hour and half's time he was well, having pis'd two Chamber-pots full, and in the firt two
•• oonfulls of mall Stones. Now had thee Medicines been convey'd through the Lacteal Veins and o on through the
•• ood, it had been impoible the Effect hould have been o oon, or the Medicines not altered, or totally detroyed. Another Peron afflicted with the Stone in the Bladder Nine Months, and depaired of a Cure, all common means being ued in vain, was at lat prevail'd with to end for me, and to try what I could do for her: Upon Monday Morning he began to take my Medicines, and on Wedneday Night, I Examin'd her Water, and found ome mall pieces of Stones in it, and Tateing the Water, I could dicern the Tate of the Medicines, as vigorous as they were before they were taken: On Thurday Morning he ent to acquaint me, he was perfectly well; and viiting her, I found he had voided a tone an Inch and half and a quarter long, three Inches and a half round. I could add everal intances of this nature; but thee two I think ufficient, and plain Demontrations that there are uch Veels. Nay, I don't quetion, but uddenly to make it appear by ocular Demontration. Secondly, Thoe People who abound with Acidity in their Stomachs are Lean, becaue the olid Food, being over attenuated, is made capable of paing thro' thee Veels, and the groer is convey'd to the Guts; and having but few Nutritious Particles, Leannes mut needs follow: And as I aid, that Leannes is for want of Acid in the Blood, appears that Fat is nothing but a concrete of Acid, and Oily Parts: When the Blood is detitute of Acids, and abounds with Alkalies, as it doth with all People who have too much Acid in their Stomachs, the Blood detitute of Acids to coagulate the Oyl, there can be no Fat produced: And that already generated, having its Acid mortify'd by Alkalies, looes its conitence, and is turned into a thin Oyl, and when the Oyl is gone, the Alkalies prey on the Mucles, Nerves, and Fibers, and caue general Diorders. Thirdly, Thoe troubled with Acidity in the Stomach, are Cotive, becaue the more thin Parts are carry'd off by the Urinary Veels. But it may be objected, How comes it to pas that Steel which is an Acid Cures Atrophies, and does not exaperate them, by increaing the Acidity in the Stomach. I anwer, Steel cannot be convey'd into the Blood before it be turn'd into Vitriol, and therefore it is neceary to give it unprepar'd to People of Acid Stomachs: By in the Acid is o embody'd that it can't pas thro' the Urinary
Veels, and is hindred from attenuating the Chyle, and o being mix'd with the Chyle, they are together conveyed into the mall Guts, and o on to the Blood, where by its Styptick Acidity it confirms the texture of the Blood, and mortifies the Alkalous Particles.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
That few People are troubled with Acidity in their Stomachs, but thoe that live a Sedentary Life, or ue little Exercie is not true; unles by a edentary Life, you mean itting much at Taverns and Ale-Houes, where the Drinking fermentable Liquors, produce too much Acidity in the Stomachs of many Perons: but of thoe that eldom ue uch itting, but live the mot tirring Lives, I have known more three to one, troubled with our Stomachs, than of thoe that ue little Exercie. The Saliva which you account the ferment of the Stomach, I have hew'd is not an Acid in its natural State; and tho' from the mall quantity of Salum got from it, an Acid may be Ditill'd; yet in the Stomach, it acts not as an Acid, and o it cannot change the Food into Acidity, by being too long retain'd in the Stomach, for want of Exercie: But when there's any Acid in the Stomach, 'tis as I have aid, from things ingeted, coniting of divers Particles apt to ferment, aited by the Heat and Moiture in the Stomach. As to your aertion, that thoe People that have too much Acidity in their Stomachs, make Water often, and much, are very Lean are Cotive, uppoing it true (for it wants proof) and that they a • d o, becaue by this Acidity, (which you ay, ought to be convey'd into the Blood) the Food is attenuated, and converted into a thin Subtance; and o by the preure of the Liver queez'd thro' certain Veffels, which pas from the bottom of the Stomach to the Kidneys, and o is carry'd off by Urine. I ay, you hou'd firt be ure that there are uch Veels; which you can never be, but by being skill'd in the Anatomy of the Solid Parts, and o having a Qualification to talk finely: For to talk truely of things een with ones own Eyes, is the finet talk that can be in Anatomy. You hould not have built o great a Supertructure, on a Foundation you have no Knowledge of: But had better have tay'd a little, till you had given an Occular Demontration of thee Veels; ince you believe, you hall o uddenly be able to do it and when you had found them, you might have Talk'd more finely. For your two Obervations, and Doleus's to help you, are not ufficient and plain Demontrations, as you ay. Let us conider both your Author's and your own Arguments. Doleus does but uppoe there may be uch a Paage thro' the Omentum to the Kidneys; but to trengthen his uppoition, he tells us, thoe Animals that have no Caul, make no Water: He hou'd have aid
thoe Animals, but have no Caul, have no Kidneys: And if that had been true, it might have look'd like an Argument that they do not Pis: But if there are Animals that have no Caul, and yet have Kidneys, as Birds have: what ue are they for, if not to eparate ome erous matter from the Blood? and tho' they do not Pis in the manner, as ome Animals do, being more dry and perpiring much; yet there is, as is well known, a paage from their Reins, into the common paage of the thicker Excrements. In his Diection of Animals firt gorged with Water, and finding the Veels of the Caul turgid; he hou'd have certify'd himelf, that thoe Veels were turgid with the Water that was reciev'd into the Stomach, and have een that he could pres it out of the Stomach into them, and out of them into the Kidneys, and where they were inerted. And as for the Diection of Hydropical Perons, tho' he found the Caul o affected it might be but the concomitant, or Effect of the Dropie, and not the Caue; unles he could aure himelf, it was o in all Hydropicks. The Caul's being obtructed, rather argues againt him, that the Liquid Matter could not pas that way. As to the Peron whoe Caul was part Cut away, it can't be Rationally thought that a difficulty of making Water, hou'd be caus'd by the Urinary Liquors not being tranmitted to the Kidneys, but rather, from its being obtructed in the Bladder, from ome other Caue than the Cutting of his Omentum: Nor is he certain, that the pain and weight in the Man's Stomach, and loones when he Drank much, was not from ome other Reaon. As for your Conolation, for Perons trouble with the Stone; you ee of what ue, Skill in the Anatomy of the Solid Parts would be now, if you had it. But I know no Phyicians that have Study'd the Nature and Caues of the Stone, and the poible and likely ways of its Diolution in the Reins, or Bladder; but have at the ame time, concluded nothing likely to Diolve it, but what's as well unchangeable by any of the Ferments of the Body, as inoffenive to the paages of Urine; neither of which Requiites are to be found in your Noble Acid Mentrunms, being coagulable by Alkalies, where ever they meet, and o offenive and intolerable to the Urinary Veels, that were there indeed uch a hort cut as you fancy, for them to pas unchanged to the Reins and Bladder, you might Cure the Patient quickly; but it would go near to be by Death more painful than that by the Stone it elf: And wo be to all your Patients Reins and Bladders; the giving of Catharides would be nothing to your Acids, which will not only caue intolerable Stranguaries, but even corrode the Bladder, as any one may find, if he has a mind to try. But you Mr. Acid, who think you have found a nearer way to the
