Stone o hard a Task, I am apt to preume, will be long enough before you can do the College and Mankind, o great a piece of ervice as to poil Dr. Groenvelt the Famous Lithotomit's Trade. As for your two Caes, you think Demontrations of the aforeaid Paages, the Man Cur'd of the toppage of Urine in an Ho • r and halfs time, and the Woman troubled with the Stone (as you ay) who took your Medicines on Monday Morning, which you Tated on Wedneday Night in her Urine, and was well by Thurday Morning: I don't quetion, tho' you give no more than thee two, but that you could give us a Hundred more uch Stories: But if we uopoe, thee matters of Fact true, I ay, the peediet of your Cures is not o udden, as to make it neceary to conclude, that the Medicines could not go a longer March, and thro' more defiles than if they be uppos'd to pas by the way of the Lacteal-Veins. Almot every one's Experience, will certifie them of more udden Effects of things taken into the Body, in the remotet Parts from the Stomach. When we are faint and weak by Fating, and take Meat and Drink, we oon feel a enible Refrehment and Strength throughout the whole Body, and thoe that take too much Vinous Liquors, in a very hort time, will feel the Effects there of in their very Finger-ends. Beides its well known, that divers things taken into the Stomach, will in half an Hours time produce their Effects in the very Skin, cauing copious Sweats. And what's more, I my elf, have Experienc'd that the mere Tating a thing, has in a few Minutes time wrought by Sweat, Vomiting and Purging: Nay, ome things apply'd outwardly, will very oon both Purge and Vomit; the Particles of which can't be communicated to the Stomach, but by a longer way than from the Stomach to the Kidneys by the Lacteals. And as for the Tating of things in the Urine; I ay, you never Tated any of your Acids there: But whatever you might Tate in the Urine, it's no Argument of your hort paage: The Tate of things is oft found remaining, where they mut be uppos'd to have pas'd the Lacteals. Every Country-Woman knows it by Experience, that Crow Gerlick will not only be very trongly Tated in her Cow's-Milk, but will hardly ever be lot in the Cheee made thereof. As for the total detruction of things, you talk of; there's no uch thing in Nature. And as to your fancy, that thoe troubled with our Stomachs, make Water often, and much; I in my elf Experience the contrary, being commonly troubled with too much Acidity, if I Drink any coniderable quantity of Fermented Liquors, and yet I have eldom met with any but will Pis once, or twice, before I have any uch motion; neither do I find my elf make more Water, when troubled
with a our Stomach, than at other times. Nor are Acids o apt to attenuate the Nutritious Parts of our Food: Every one that knows how to make a Poet can tell you, that the more Nutritive part of Milk, is curdled, and hardened by Acieds: And our Chyle it elf is of the Nature of Milk. As for leannes, that it is caued by want of Acid in the Blood to coagulate the Oyl, it is but your fancy. If you had examin'd Fat by the Fire, or any way whereby you may judg of it, you would not have found it more Acid than Fleh or Blood, but have found it pat your Art to eparate it into an Acid and an Oyl; nor did you ever take Acid and Oyl mixed with a great deal of water, and coagulate them into Fat by uch a heat, as that of our Body. You may indeed coagulate Oyl into Brimtone by an Acid, but you mut ue uch a heat, as cannot be uppoed in the body of an Animal, and your Acid mut be tronger, and your Oyl more undivided than they can be uppos'd to be while diluted, and mixed with the aqueous, and Alkalous Liquors of the Body. If you had undertood Sope-making, you might have een Oyl and Greee coagulated, and hardned by trong boyling with fixed Alkalies intead of being made thin, and you hould have try'd whether Volatile Alkalies would turn Fat into a thin Oyl, before you had o poitively aerted it: For it is well known on the contrary, that Vinegar is given with ucces to thoe that are too fat: An example of which, ee Cattieri, Obj. 13. p. 44. in a Military Man that was very fat, who by continual ue of Vinegar, decreaed eighty even Pounds. As for the cotivenes of thoe troubled with our Stomachs, I alo experienced the contrary, being eldom or never cotive epeciolly when troubled with too much Acidity in my Stomach. But we come to your own raied Objection: How can Steel, an Acid, cure Atrophies, and not rather exaperate them by encreaing Acidity in the Stomach? Here Mr. Acid you had given us ome of your deep thoughts in a rare dicovery, that Steel has that excellent property to carry the preternatural Acid of the Stomach into the Blood, there to do fine feats: But we mut take it upon your word, for you have not proved by any Experiment, that Steel thus uhers the Acid in through the Lacteal Veins, which would without its aitance, have been let down at the inviible trap-doors in the bottom of the Stomach. You uppoe the Acid too gros, when turn'd into Vitriol to pas thoe fine outlets, which I confes are o fine, that I could never ee them; but Vitriol I know when diolved (and it cannot be uppoed long in a coagulated form in the Stomach) will pas very fine filters, and ininuate itelf through the pores of Veels, that will hold divers other Liquors:
And here is another Mytery till, that one Acid is diolved by, and coagulated with another. But the truth of the matter poils all your dicovery, which is that Steel by all tryals is found to be an Alkali, fermenting with, and aborbing Acids, and certainly hindring them where ever they go together with it from having the effects of Acids. And a far better reaon of the good effects of Steel, where it is found a beneficial Remedy, is that as an Alkali, it aborbs the Acids in the Stomach and Bowels, and o hinders them from doing michief, either there, or in any farther recees, paing any way into the Blood, or urinary Veels, heathing their offenive poynts, carries them off with itelf among the Excrements of the Belly. But farther, to hew how repugnant your fancies are to reaon, and themelves, you hall uppoe your Urinary Veels from the Stomach to the Kidneys, and that Acids have the power of attenuating things, and paing that way: Then according to your Doctrine we can't uppoe them to take any other coure, this being the readiet way, and how freely oever you give your Acid Medicines, they will be till preternatural Acids in the Stomach, (and wo be to the Gouty, they ue but little Exercie) and you can never hope to do any thing in the Blood with them, they paing all off by Urine, with the attenuated nutritive Juice, and leave occaion for Atrophies; and all Dieaes you uppoe coming from the abounding of Alkalies, and want of Acids in the Blood, unles Nature knows your Acids from others, or that they are embodied, as you ay, by Steel, or ome other Alkali, and then in truth actum et de Acido; ince there is no fire in the Blood, (if thoe Vitriols or other embodied Acids ever come there) capable to ditil Oyl of Vitriol or eparate the Acid from thoe other Alkalies it is embodied with. But if ome part of your Acid hould cape falling through the holes at the bottom of the Stomach, and run along for company uncoagulated into the Guts, there will till be a difficulty for it to pas into the Lacteals from the Bile; if it be not defectctive, or the Acid too much in quantity: This guard allying forth into the mall Guts, being the mot Alkalous Liquor of the whole Body, and mot neceary for its health, oppoing the entrance of Acids into the Animal Palace, entangling them, and thruting them out with the Excrements at the back-door.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: The Bile is an Excrement, and eems to be as genuine an Excrement of Fire as any thing whatoever, both from its burnt Tate, Colour, &c. and I am ure if it be detain'd in the Body will play the Devil.

sp.speaker: Alk.
sp.p:
If by Excrement you mean only a matter eparated from the Blood, we acknowledg it may be call'd an Excrement, and o may the Saliva, the Mucus that lines the paages of the Noe, and Larynx, yea the Su ••• s Nervous, & Semen; but if by Excrement, you mean omething eparated, and rejected as ueles to the Body, merely to be cat out, as the Dung, and Urine are; I deny the Gaul to be an Excrement, any more than the Saliva, Mucus, Succus Nervous, & Semen, all which have their pecial and proper ends towards the conervation, or propagation of the Body. That the Gaul cannot be rationally uppoed to be an Excrement in the proper ene, is apparent from the manner and way of its eparation. The Liver the larget Bowel in the Body, having no other aignable ue, but the ecretion of this Liquor, which is ejected mot commonly into the Duodenum, rarely into the Jejunum, and there mixed with the Chyle, as all that are skill'd in the Anatomy of the olid Parts know. But it cannot well be thought, that a meer Excrement hould be thus dicharged into the boome of the nutritious Juice, being the mot Alkalous matter in the whole Body, and o according to Mr. Acid, the mot Pernicious: But on the contrary, this Liquor dicharg'd into the Chyle, o oon after its egres from the Stomach, is neceary there for the hinderance of too much Acidity, from paing thro' the Lacteals into the Blood; which appears from the Conideration of the Nature of this Liquor, which by Ditillation yields a volatile Alkalous, in the Caput Mort. a Lixivious-Salt running in the Air, which I have not found in any of the Liquid, or Solid Parts of the Body beides, except the Dung, which has a fixed Salt omewhat like it, but not o trong: Whence I conclude, it has ome Acids mix'd with it carry'd down by the Gall: With thee Salts, the Gall yields alo a Faetid Oyl, as other Animal Subtances do, but the Particles of this Liquor, as mix'd together in their Natural State, make uch a Compound as is preently thickned, or coagulated by Acids, more, or les, as the Acid is tronger, or weaker, into a clammy glutinous Matter, whereby the abounding Acid Patticles, that are ometimes contain'd in the Stomach are invicated and hamper'd, and o in great meaure hindred from paing into the Lacteal-Veins. But I could never ee the Gall make any uch effervecency with Acids, as ome Authors talk of; tho' I have Try'd all orts of Acids, and many kinds of Galls: And as it is it elf coagulated by manifet Acids, o it hinders the temperate Lacteal juice from being o oon coagulated; as is een in this, that Milk into which, a few Drops of Gall are put, will tand in its due conitence un-coagulated, when Milk alone will be turn'd and our'd: So that the proper ue of the
Gall, eems to me, to be for the attemperating the Nutritious-Juice, and o in the Duodenum, Jejunum & Ileum, is a great friend, tho' detain'd in the Body, will play the Devil, you ay. By being detain'd, I uppoe, you mean not duly eparated from the Blood, and dicharg'd into the Chyle. To which, I anwer, Its remaining in the Blood is not o bad, but its abence from the Offl • ine of the Chyle, is as great an evil to the Animal Oeconomy; in which a proportionable and harmonious mixture, is that in which Health coniteth: In which, the Widom of the Author of Nature is een, that all the Parts, and Particles in the Hydraluico-pneumatical Engine the Body, are o order'd, that they help, and are again helped by one another; as here there's proviion made for eparating the Particles that make up the Bilious-Juice e'er they abound in the Blood, and when they are Ejected, they become as ueful to prevent another ort of Particles paing into the Blood, which wou'd be as hurtful there, as their detentation in it wou'd be prejudicial. And there are not een more evil Effects from the Gall's retention in the Veins, than from its abence in the Guts. Fernelius relates in Pathol. Lib. 6. cap. 5. That many Dy'd in whom no other Caue of Death appear'd, but that the Bladder of Gall was empty. And Moebius in Fundam. Phyiol, pag. 168. That in three Infants that Dy'd of an Atrophy, there was no Gaul found. But that the Bile hou'd be as genuine an Excrement of Fire, as any thing, is one of Mr. Acid's hot Fancies. Nothing but Organical Vital Bodies, are properly aid to have Excrements: But hou'd we allow him to talk of Fire's Dung, neither the yellow colour, nor bitternes of the Bile, wou'd be any Argument of its being the Excrement from Fire's Victuals, any more, than the ame colour, and tate, would argue Vegetables in their Natural State, to be made after the ame manner. And as for Empyreuma, whoever Tates it, will find it has none. But before you had given us your Fiery Fancies, you hou'd have been ure there is a Fire in Man, and whereabouts the Kitchin is plac'd: I believe it's not in the Liver, but only in ome few Hot Brains.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The Life of Man I take to be a Fire, or Flame, and all we Eat or Drink, together with the Air we draw in, to be as fewel for this Flame, and what is not proper fewel for it, is cat off as Excrements: That part of the Chyle that is fit to make Blood is made Blood, the ret confuedly mix'd with it, call'd S • erum, is for nourihing the Parts, the Blood being not at all ued for Nutrition, but is the Red Subtance wherein is contain'd the Biolychnium, being its Paul •• . Now I appeal to all converant in Chymitry, whether the Excrements of the Fire, viz. Ahes and Soot, be not Alkalies. That our Lives are nothing but a Flame, or Fire of the ame Nature with
that commonly ued, or very analogous to it, I think is plain. Its the Nature of common Fire, to conume whatever is a proper Pabulum or fewel for it, and to leave its Excrements behind it, which are Ahes and Soot. The Body of Man would oon be conum'd, unles upply'd with proper Food, and how could this be, and what would become of what we Eat and Drink, I can't undertand; unles there were a Fire, or Flame within us to conume it. Common Fire can't ubit without Air: Is it not the ame thing with the Life of Man? Let him be enclos'd in a place where Air can't come at him, he immediately Expires, as is well known to Miners. Heat and Warmth are the contant Concomitants of Fire, and that there's Heat and Warmth in the Body of Man, none, Mater of his Senes, will deny. How is it poible for the Heat of our Bodies to be utain'd, unles there were a Fire in us to do it; mere Motion, will never caue any Heat in Fluid Bodies, altho' excited never o much. There is a Maxim, That there is no Smoak, but there's ome Fire. Every Body mut be enible what vat quantities of Steams are continually dicharg'd from all parts of our Bodies: How this can be, unles from ome Fire within us, I can't undertand. And I have the Conc • rrence of ome of the greatet Men the World has afforded, that the Life of Man is a Flame. The Phophorus, which is as much Fire as any thing we know, is a true Animal Fire, to be Extracted from all Animal Subtances; and if it did not actually exit in them, how can it be Extracted from them I know not: It is an Acid Sulpherous Subtance, and the Pabulum of Animal Fires, is a Sulpherous Acid: Common Sulphur, Tallow, Pitch, do abound with Sulphur, & are inflammable; yet from none of thee is by any known Artifice the leat Phophorus, or any thing like it attainable. Upon the troaking of Cats in the dark, flahes of fire will follow. This gentle troaking can never caue o violent a motion, as you make Fire to be, unles it were actually in the Animal. I confes Fire is a ubtance contantly in motion, and a brisk motion, yet all brisk motion is not Fire: But I know everal fluids the more briskly moved the colder; as a River is always colder where the Current is mot wift. And which is none of the leat Arguments to prove our Life is a Flame; let a Man be eized with a Feaver, or any Ditemper attended with a total los of Appetite, the Fat will firt be conumed, and a Corpulent Man oon brought to a Skeleton, when the evacuations of Urine and Stool are les than in Health: Which could not be, unles there were a Flame to caue that Conumption. There is a difference in ome repects between Animal and Culinary Fire, in many they agree. Neither will burn without due acces of Air; both caue warmth: Neither can ubit without a upply of Sulphurous Acid Particles,
but Animal Fire (o I call Phophorus) immerg'd in Water, and taken out will retain its properties without being applied to other enkindled Bodies: This common Fire will not do. Now where ever there is a Fire or Flame, epecially when upplied with gros matter; there mut be a throwing off of Excrements: The Alkali found in Animals is the Excrement of their Fire, and all the Excrements of Animals are Alkalous. As for the Blood, the Volatile Alkali to be obtain'd from it is only the Excrementious part of it, or rather of the vital Flame, or of its Pabulum, in a way of being carried off by ome of the Emunctories, which if it chance to be obtructed in its paage affects the Body with ome Ditemper or other.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
The ubtance of your whole Doctrine eems to lie catterd in what you have here aerted. That the Life is a real Fire of the ame, or very like Nature with common Fire, to the conervation of which, there is required a Fewel which whatever we eat or drink, and the Air we breath in upplieth; in which Sulphurous Acid Particles are the proper Food, which are contain'd in the red part of the Blood, but what is not proper Fuel for this Flame is rejected as Excrement, and this Excrement is the Alkali; which if not carried off, is the caue of Dieaes. I hall oppoe in the firt place, to your great Men you ay concur with you, (I ay rather from whom you borrowed the fancy) what your Elder Brother Etmuller aies (who I'm ure had a double yea treble Portion of Learning to what you have) De ahtruo repirationis negotio, Cap. X. Veterum enim quem in corde finxerunt Igniculus ac flammula anioribus Medicis, ac Philooph's dudum expirae via unt, i modo unquam arerint. Ideoque ut ad illa quid regeramus operae pretium non et. Haud equidem ignoro praeclaros quodam Carteianos Williium, Sylvium, ejuque cultores levi admia mutatione igniculum huncce e cineribes reucitae, docendo illum potiimum in dextro cordis ventriculo vigere, &c. Plauabilius prae ceteris rem propouit clar: Sylvius Diput. med. 6ta & 7ma in quibus Scriptis Incendium illud in corde vitale uti vocat, ex bilis lixiviae, cum anguine adcendentis cordique advectae, nec non lymphae & Chyli ubacidorum mutua, in dextro cordis ventriculo effervecentia, ne pecioe magis quam vere vereor deducit, &c. ed paucis repondeo Hypothein illam prae ertim de bilis accenu, vigorem rationum, & experimentorum Diemmerbrocii peronati illius Leoniceni, atque Malphigii haud quaquam ferre, Ideoque nec pro adtruendo Igniculo concludere. Moreover, I ay, thoe great Men, and you, hould have had ome certain notion of Fire, and firt have told us what it is. For to tell us that the Life of Man is a Fire, and not tell us what Fire is, is all one, as to tell us, That the Life of Man is a omething, you
know not what. But that this omething, may not continue like the Philoopher's undetermin'd Matter, and o all that is aid remain uncertain; let us conider, what it is that is properly call'd Fire. I ay therefore, 1t. That Fire is omething in Bodily Nature, 2dly. That Bodily Nature, is nothing but Matter coniting of Particles of all Figures and Sizes. 3dly. Thee Particles as they have different Figures and Sizes, are capable of different degrees and manners of Motion. 4thly. That all the different Ideas, or Perceptions we have of Bodies, are caued by means of the different Figures, and Motions of the Particles. 5th. That there is no ort of Particles, of what Figure, or Size oever, that merely on that account of Figure and Size, can Properly be call'd Fire; o that the old Notion of Fire's being an Element of any thing, is fale. 6th. But to the Being of Fire, there's requir'd a certain degree and manner of Motion, of uch Particles, that as to Figure and Size, are capable thereof. 7th. That thee Particles, mut have uch a degree and manner of Motion, as to produce on our Bodies, the two Senations of Light, if not at too great a ditance, and Heat, if no hindering Medium interpoe. 8th. To the production of which Senations, a certain quantity of Matter, fit for uch Motion, and actually o mov'd, is requiite to come together. 9, That thoe Particles are more readily excited to, and longer continued in this degree and manner of Motion, in ome Bodies, commonly call'd Fewel, than in others. 10th. That they more or les eparate the Parts, or poil the Form of uch Bodies. 11th. To aert poitively this, or that to be the particular Size and Figure, or determinate degree and manner of Motion, of Fire making Particles, would be too great a preumption; becaue they are too mall to be Objects of Sight; yet we may uppoe them rigid and inflexible Particles, mov'd mot briskly to and fro, becaue they break and eparate many Compounds, and when apply'd too near our Bodies, occaion the mot dipleaing Senation of Burning; but at a convenient ditance, pleae us by jutling againt us more mooth and flexible Bodies. Thee Propoitions if well conider'd, I think, may give us ome determinate Notion of Fire: There's never any Fire, but where there is a brisk Motion; and you grant me, that all brisk Motion is not Fire, but uch a Motion as I have decrib'd; and no other that I know of, will determine the matter o, as that we may not ay, every Motion is Fire, or no motion is Fire. Now Fire, as I have aid, being a congeries of a quantity of ubtil, rigid and inflexible Parts o mov'd, as to caue the enations of Heat and Light, and if too near the Body that of Burning, there can be no uch thing found in the Body of Man. But let us conider your own Arguments, you ue to perwade
us of the Exitence of a Fire, or Flame in the Blood. The Nature of common Fire, ay you, is to conume its proper Pabulum, or Fewel, and to leave Ahes and Soot as its Excrements, which you appeal to Chymits are Alkalies. The Body of Man would be conumed, unles upply'd with proper Food (fewel you mean for the Fire) and how this could be, and what hould become of all we Eat and Daink, unles there were a Fire in us to conume it, you don't know, and the Alkali found in Animals, is the Excrement of their Fire. I anwer, that change wrought upon combutible Bodies by Fire, and what alteration is made on our Food in the Body, is vatly different, and neither is a conummption in the vulgar ene, not one Particle of Matter being to be rationally thought to be detroy'd. But real Fire by a violent Motion eparates the Parts of many compound Bodies, both the combutible and incombutible ones. Thoe Bodies we call combutible, abound more or les, with Oily Parts, which are as it were the Vehicle of the Igneous: But there are few of thoe Bodies but are compounded of other kinds of Parts, beides Oleous, which in the hurry are eparated from one another, and not only o, but ometimes alter'd, either broken into maler Parts, or by trikeing together, are connected one with an other otherwie than they were in the natural compound; whence new reulting Bodies, or artificial compounds arie, uch as Soot, and ix'd Alkalies, being eparable again. Now which of thee eparated Bodies, hould rather be call'd an Excrement (if the fancy of calling any of them o mut be allow'd) is merely Arbitrary: In mot of them Water is the greatet quantity, of that which is cat out as mot unfit for the continuance of this hurry, and o might rather be call'd the Excrement. The Acid and Volatile Alkalious Bodies are carry'd off next, and the Oyl it elf, tho' commonly alter'd, is mot of it eparated before the Fire goes quite out; the fix'd Alkali, and thoe portions of Oyl, and Acid, that tick in it to make it uch, abiding in the Earth lat with the Igneous particles. Now whatever, is done here, is done by a violent eparation, and ticking together of the Parts of Matter. But what alterations of things are made in the Body, are made by the gentle Motions of Natural ferments, and eparations by peculiar Strainers of the curiouly compos'd Organical Frame, wherein there's no uch degree and manner of Motion, as can properly be call'd Fire. As for the Conumption of the Body, you ay, would oon be, if there were not a upply by Food; I anwer, The forbearance of Food, would not conume the Body, but the Organical Frame of it, yea, and Blood, both containing a great quantity of Oyl, will re • main
unconum'd in pight of Hunger. And the Fat, which you ay, is firt conum'd in Feavers and Dieaes where there's a total los of Appetite is carry'd off, not becaue it is combutible, and o Burnt away; but becaue its apt to be attenuated, and does not o firmly adhere as other Parts. The Evacuations by Stool and Urine, mut needs be little, when the Appetite is lot, and little Eat: But at all times, its well known, the Evacuations by the Pores, are the greatet. And as for what we Eat and Drink, tho' you can't tell what hould become of it, if there were not a Fire to conume it: Yet any one that is led more by Conideration and Experiment, than Fancy, may as eaily give an account of the wate of it, as of wearing out a Coat, or a pair of Shooes, without uppoing ome Fire or other that Burns them to pieces. The Food is firt omewhat eparated by Chewing, then in the Stomach by a gentle Heat, and Motion, and probably by ome ort of Fermentation; the things we Eat, mot of them being capable thereof, if kept in a moderate Heat, and ufficient Moyture, even out of the Body: Then in the mall Guts there is a eparation made, and great part is carry'd down, and rejected as Excrements, which Coals, (if you pleae,) you may catch as hot as ever they were without Burning your Fingers. That part that is not thus rejected is Percolated into the Lacteal Veins, which convey it into the Ductus Chyliferus, and o into the Blood, for the nourihing the Parts, both Liquid and Solid; the Serous part being but the Vehicle for the more olid, and the Globules of the Blood. Whilt a Man grows, the different Particles of this Nutritive-Juice, as they are fit ome for one thing, ome for another, adhere, and are added to the Parts of the Body, and o encreae its Bulk; thoe Parts that are more thin, and fluid, add to and increae the Liquors of the Body, out of which, great part is eparated by Urine. When a Man has done growing, there is no need of addition, but only of a upply of as much as dayly wates, which conidering the Poreounes of the Body in all Parts, and the continual natural, and voluntary Motions thereof, for the feveral Works of Life, can't eaily be uppos'd to be little, tho' we can find no Focus for a Fire to conume us. It's very well known that Labouring Men, and that in Cold-Weather, have better Stomachs, and Eat more, than thoe that live Idlely, tho' kept hotter than the Laborious; which may well be thought to proceed from their uing more Motion, whereby the Particles of Food are carry'd about more wiftly and at length work'd out, and this all done merely by rubbing, where there is no Fire, which you ay, rejects as Excrements Soot and Ahes, the one of which may be farther eparated into Volatile Salt, and Oyl, the other into Earth and fix'd Alkali, either of
which you may call an Excrement of the other, as you love or hate, this or that: But you are fallen out with Alkali, & tercus humanum, offends your queemih tomach, ergo, Alkali Merda et, Alkali is the Excrement. Which I think, as good a Reaon as any you have given. But yet whatever analogy may be in the conumption of combutibles by common-Fire, and of our Food by any thing in the Body, there is this vat difference; In this there is no Soot nor Ahes made of what we Eat and Drink, much les of the Air, The other Fewel as you call it, which we breath in. Here neither the Flame, not the Coal will Burn you, enkindle the mot combutible Matter, or give you any Light. And tho' a Volatile Alkali and an Oyl, omething like what may be got from Soot, may be eparated from the Liquid, or Solid Parts of the Body, they mut firt be wrought upon by a common and greater Fire, than any is in the Blood: And tho' from the Gall, and Dung may alo be eparated a mall quantity of fix'd Salt, they mut firt be expos'd to a real and violent Fire, and o mut the other Parts, before there can be produc'd any thing that may be call'd Ahes from them. Common Fire, you ay, can't ubit without Air, and the like you affirm of the Life of Man; o they mut be both Fires. I anwer, Tho' both require Air; yet not for the ame Reaon. The Air is an Elatick or Springey Body, capable of being expanded, or contracted, and in its Expanion by Heat, or the Motion of the Igneous Particles (which begins when ever a quantity of them, ufficient to produce the Effect can be connected) I ay in its expanion, or the receeding of its Parts from the place where the Fire is begun, it carries off the Particles of the combutible Matter, that are eparated, and become no longer combutible, and o there's more room for the Igneous Particles to move on; as is evidently een in Chymical Furnaces, where the trength of the Fire, depends on the quick carrying off the Smoak, which is done by a tream of Air paing thro' the Bodies in combution, and carrying off thoe Particles that would hinder the Motion of the Igneous Bodies: The Air where the Fire is being rarify'd, that below being more compres'd, expands it elf into the place where is mot room, and other Air ucceeds it, (the Air being more dilated the higher it is) the more compres'd Air till paing that way; o till the tronger the Fire, the tronger the Draught of Air, and the fater the eparated Parts that would hinder the motion of the Igneous Bodies are removed. But the Life of Man requires Air, not to blow a Fire, carry off Soot, or diplace Ahes, much les as a Fewel for a Fire; but beides many other Ends and Ues, chiefly to continue and cary on the Circulation of the Blood: Which I take to be done
after this manner, The Air by its Elatick Property, ruhing into the Lungs, upon the dilation of the Thorax, expands them, and thereby ets the Sanguiferous Veels free and right for the paage of the Blood out of the right Ventricle of the Heart into the Vena Arterioa, at the rie of which, there are Valves to hinder its paage back again; this Veel and the Arteria venoa by their Anatomoes being fill'd with Blood, the Thorax is again contracted, the Air preed out, and the Lungs fall together; whereby the Blood-Veels are preed: But the foreaid Valves hindring its going back, it is drove into the Left Ventricle of the Heart, whence it cannot return into the Lungs, by reaon other Valves hindering it; the Thorax being again dilated, and the Lungs by the Air ruhing in expanded, and the Veels, whoe Blood was preed out into the Left Ventricle of the Heart, again free; the Blood flows into them again from the Right Ventricle, by which filling and emptying of the Veels of the Lungs, the Blood is as it were pump'd and carried along in its Circulation: And is there as it were ground, its adhering Globules eparated, and divided from one another, its Heterogeneous Particles more exactly mix'd, and o is attenuated, and made more capable of paing the mallet Veels thro' the whole Body. So that the principal reaon, why a Man can't live long without Air, is becaue the Blood can't otherwie circulate through the Lungs which way it mut go; which evidently appears from the conideration of a Child unborn, who lives divers Months without repiration, the Blood being carried on by the force of the Circulation of the Mothers Blood through the Foramen Ovale, from the Right to the Left Ventricle of the Heart; which is top'd when the Child is born, and becomes a ditinct, and eparate Animal, needing a force of its own to carry on the Circulation. The reaon why Perons are often kill'd in Mines, is not becaue there is no Air, it being impoible almot to keep it out, but that they ometimes breath in with the Air Arenical, Sulphurous, or other noxious Fumes, of which one would think a Profes'd Chymit could not be ignorant: But you may oon try; the Fumes of Antimony, Arnick, or the beloved Sulphurous Acid, teaming from enkindled Brimtone drawn into your Lungs, will in a little time be found no good Fewel for your uppoed Biolychnium. As to your Argument from Heat and Warmth the concomitants of Fire, and in the Body of Man. I Anwer, Heat is mot certainly the concomitant of Fire, and alo brisk Motion, but as you confes all brisk Motion is not Fire; o I ay, all Heat and Warmth is not Fire, and the brisket Motion in the Body of Man, either in Health or Sicknes, is not brisk enough to make a real Fire in the weaket degree. And tho' you can't ee how Heat
and Warmth could be utain'd without a Fire; you may as well ay, you can't ee how a Man can walk unles he be running. Warmth, Heat, and Fire it elf, is nothing but meer Motion in everal degrees and manners, and wherever there is motion there is ome degree of Warmth, tho' we may not perceive it, for there is no uch thing as abolute cold unles where all things are in abolute ret, which place would be hard to find. Whatever Heat, or Warmth is caued in Fluids, is caued by mere Motion, even where they are et over a Fire, but the nature of watry Bodies, uch as the Liquors in Man, will not admit a real Fire or Flame to be mixed with, and continue in them; and tho' by Motion they may be brought to a Heat inconitent with the Life of the Body; yet this very Motion is not Fire. But doubtles the Heat in Man's Body is caued by ome kind of Motion, and probably a fermentative one; the Blood and other Liquors containing divers alts and Oily particles may well be thought o to move together, as to caue the greatet Heat in the Body of Man. I confes a meer Oyl, and ome very trong Acid Spirits, will by their mixture be enkindled into a real Flame, but there never is nor can be uch a mixture flow in the Veins of a living Man; o there is never Heat enough to enkindle the mot inflammable Bodies. You may take Phophorus without any fear of its being et on fire in your Belly, which tho' as little Heat would enkindle, yet not immerg'd in a watry Liquor, or without the ufficient acces of Air; for which very reaon there can be no Fire in the Blood. And Phophorus it elf, tho' o apt to be enkindled, I have known lie for a Month, and might have done as long as one would, in a Glas eal'd up without any Water, or the Air excluded, and not at all take Fire. The continuance of our Heat is very eaily conceived to be by a continual upply of Saline, and Oleous Particles apt to jotle againt one another in a watry Liquor, and move ufficiently to keep us warm. We know that divers Liquors mix'd together, will caue a Heat, even where there is nothing inflammable in either of them. It has been found by experience, that the heat of hot Springs proceeds from a certain Bed where are Salts of divers natures, which the Water coming to diolves, and o their Motion produces the Heat, omething like that, produced by pouring Water upon Lime, which I think no Man in his Wits can acribe to a Fire or Flame in the Water. That you ay ome Fluids the brisker moved are the colder, is your mitake; that a River is not coldet in the current appears from this, that the Current is not o oon froze; and tho' the wind by its •• tion caues the ene of cold, yet it is not merely by its Motion, but becaue the Particles moving traight on in a
line hinder the hurrying Motion, which is the formal caue of heat, of the Sun Beams, which luminous Particles while dipers'd and eperate have not force enough to caue the effect of Fire, or burning; yet when collected, and bundled up in the Focus of a Burning-glas, are in a poture to caue that enation, when an Inch ditant from the Focus they have not uch an united force. As to your maxim, There is no Smoak but there is ome Fire, I anwer, the teams of our Bodies are not Smoak, nor if you could catch them, would they have a Grain of Soot, but are very little beides Water, as I could hew any body by a method whereby one may collect, Four, Five, Six, Seven, Eight Ounces, or more of Sweat from a Man at any time: And Water we all know is rarified, and carried up by a very mall heat, as is een in the coldet Weather, and the Water rarified by the Sun, will appear omewhat like moak. As for the Phophorus, it is not an Animal Fire, or any Fire at all till enkindled; when et on fire nothing burns fiercer, or burns out ooner, otherwie it is but a very inflammable Sulphur, or Fuel apt to take fire, being not o much as enibly warm till enkindled. And to the difference you fancy between this Animal Fire, as you call it, and the common: I Anwer, Phophorus will not have the properties of Fire after immerion, or before, unles its Particles are excited by ufficient Motion; and o will other Combutible Bodies be enkindled by ufficient Motion after Immerion, yea ome incombutable Bodies as a Flint, and a Steel by a brisk Friction will give fire, or a piece of Iron by vigorous hammering light a Match, never the les for being immerg'd. But Mr. Acid, were his Biolychnium under Water but one Week would never burn again, without a miracle, or the application of ome enkindled matter. Farther, Phophorus may eaily be uppoed to be extracted from Animal Subtances without being thought to be actually in them, and tho' I grant that it was materially in them, I deny that it was formally: For the Particles that compoe this Artificial Compound were dipers'd, and mix'd with others, and o compoed no uch Body, but are brought together by Art, and tuck to one another, and then are in that tate call'd Phophorus, and may be eparated again as eaily, and then are not Phophorus. As Glas of Antimony, or Lead was not really Glas in thoe Bodies before the Operation of the Fire, but made by it, and they may be reduced again to Antimony, and Lead, as they were before, and then are no Glas. Yea ome products of Art were not o much as materially, as to their whole, in the matter wrought upon by the Fire, as Zink Lead, and ome other Bodies ome way operated on without any addition, will not only give Bodies of quite another form, but will
be increaed in weight coniderablely. Phophorus is an Acido-Sulphurous Subtance you ay, I ay rather an Acido-oleous; for Sulphur is a Body compounded of an Acid, and an Oyl, and to ay Acido-Sulphurous is allone, as to ay, Acido Acido-Oleous. And if the Pabulum of Animal Fires were a Sulphurous Acid, and Phophorus a Sulphurous Acid, it will follow only, that Phophorus may be a Pabulum for Animal Fires (were there any) and not the Animal Fire it elf. Common Sulphur, Tallow, Pitch, abound with Sulphur, you ay; That is Sulphur abounds with Sulphur, and is inflammable: A Wit! Mr. Acid abounds with Mr. Acid, and is our; this is deep! Tallow and Pitch abound with Brimtone too you fancy, but I'm ure you never got any Brimtone from them, nor can there be any got without the Addition of an Acid, if then. But whether there can be any Phophorus made of thee? I readily yield, there cannot by any Artifice known to Mr. Acid, but there are very many things done by Artifice unknown to him. But you aid Sir, a little before, that Phoporus might be got from all Animal Subtances; yet now it cannot be got from Tallow, &c. by any Artifice; but you forgot again, that Tallow is an Animal Subtance; it lip'd your memory, being a greay body. Upon troaking of Cats in the dark, flahes of Fire will follow, you ay. Your Pus perhaps may erve you to trike Fire with, but it will only prove a Ignis fatui, which no Wie Man would call a Fire, or think actually in the Animal as its Vital Principle, any more than the hining of a dead and tinking Whiting, or of a piece of rotten Wood can be thought their life, or a real Fire. For tho' in thee there is a light; yet there is wanting the other qualification a burning Heat, as your Aertions Sir, commonly want two things, without which conjunct they cannot be more than uncertain Fancies, viz. Experiment and Reaon, whereby you hould have examined the Nature and Properties of Bodies, that you might not have grounded your Judgment upon fale Principles.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The Principles of mix'd Bodie; I take to be Acid and Sulphur, as the Vital Active ones; Alkali the Principle of Death, and Corruption: There being ince the Fall a Principle of Death in oppoition to that of Life implanted in our Natures, and not only in our Natures, but in the Natures of every thing ele for our akes. [God aid to Adam, Cured be the ground for thy ake, &c. I confes, many of our Age will Laugh and Ridicule me for having recoure to Sacred Writ, epecially the Writings of Moes, which they look upon as a kind of Romance: But let them Laugh on. If there were not a Principle of Death within us, how is it poible for a Man one Hour to be in a good tate of Health, and
the very next Expiring Then there is Water and Earth, the two paive Principles: And from thee I can more eaily account for the Phaenomena in natural Bodies, than from the five old ones, Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury, Water, and Earth, or any other Principles broach'd in the World.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
By Principles, I uppoe, you mean the ame as ome others do by Elements, viz. Simple Bodies, of which, all Compounds are uppos'd to conit, and into which, they may at lat be reolv'd. To which, I anwer, That neither thee Five Things you call Principles, and would have us believe New, and rather of your Invention, than of Doctor Andre's, nor the Five old ones (as you call them, between which and yours there is but little difference) are indeed, the Elements, or Principles of Compound Bodies, and o ufficient to olve their Phaenomena's: Which may appear by a little Conideration. But in the firt place, I hall oberve, that your diviion of Principles into Active and Paive, is not good, or allowable any farther, than as a compliance with an improper and vulgar way of peaking: For in trict Speech, nothing can be aid to do, or be Active, but what has a Will, and thoe Bodies by which we receive the tronget impreions on our Senes, and have thence been call'd Active, have indeed no more Will than the other, that's none at all: To be figured, and mov'd (which is all that belongs to Body) in what manner oever, is not to Will. As for Earth, I hall next oberve, That, that which you call Earth, is not that which is properly call'd the Earth: Your Earth or Caput Mort. being as different almot, as the Bodies in which it's found, and conequently not imple, but it elf a Compound. That which is properly call'd the Earth, is the Quick-Sand, of which and Water, this Globe chiefly conits; it being the Bais of other Bodies, and eems to be a Body coniting of Homogeneal Particles. And as to the Water that is mov'd thro' the intertices of thee Sands, and is found in the Pores of many Bodies, and the Air that alo ruheth into all Porous Bodies, where it can have paage, and compaeth them about; they are as it were the Vehicles of groer Bodies, themelves probably coniting of their peculiar imilar Particles, and are not to be thought Elements of other Bodies. For intance, Wood though it is Porous, and ome of its Pores hold Air, ome Water; yet they are not to be call'd Elements of the Wood, any more than Water running in a Leaden-Pipe, or Air within the Walls of a Houe, are to be called Elements of Lead, or of the Houe. The Air, and Water, I ay, are the Vehicles of the Particles of Compound, and changeable Bodies, carrying them to and fro, in the Production of all the changes we ee them undergo. But to come to your uppos'd Principles, they will appear not to be the
Principles or Elements of Compound Bodies, from thee Coniderations. Firt, Whatever are uppos'd as Elements, or Principles of mix'd Bodies ought ome way or other to be prov'd really, and actually to Exit in the Compounds as Parts of them. 2. They ought to be unchangeable, and conequently imple Bodies themelves. As to the firt, I ay, thee Bodies you call Principles, are not, nor ever were (that we know of) prov'd o much as likely to Exit in, and make up ome mix'd Bodies, or us Principles to be in any. For intance, Gold is a Body in which you cannot demontrate, that there is one Grain of Acid, or Oyl, or of Alkali-Salt, no nor of Water, or of Caput Mort. o far it is from being to be thought a Compound of your Five Principles. But I remember, you have aerted, That Gold is nothing but a pure Acid and Sulphur, which you aid, has been made appear, by ome of the mot trict enquirers into Nature's Secrets. But who thoe were you won't tell us: But upon this uppoition, your Five Principles are excued here. And the more Acid with Sulphur, any thing has. the more perfect it is, you ay. By Sulphur, I uppoe, you mean an inflammable Subtance, and according to this Fancy, Brimtone which is all Acid and Sulphur, would be as perfect as Gold, and perfecter too, for I'm ure, you never aw any thing inflammable, or Acid in Gold. But the reaon of this your Opinion, I uppoe, is this, you have a very great kindnes for Acid and Sulphur, and as much for Gold; therefore Gold is Acid and Sulphur. Again, you hall take Chrytal, Talk, Diamonds, Pearls, Mercury, Silver, or divers other Bodies, I might name, and your trict enquirers into Nature, Dr. Andre, and all to help you, hall not be able to eparate any two of your Principles from them. Again, many of thoe Bodies from which ome, or mot, of thoe your Principles are got, may not without ufficient ground, be thought not actually to contain them uch as they are produc'd, but that they are New Products, not as to Matter, but as to Form; reulting from the combinations of more imple Particles united together by the violence of the Fire. As for Acids, we well know, there are apparent ones, Naturally in ome Bodies, Animal and Vegetable, and from others, produc'd by Art; but even from thoe Bodies, I can eaily get an Alkali intead of an Acid, when I pleae, without any addition, merely by the different ways of Working. For intance, I will take a quantity of a Green Herb, and divide it into two parts, from one half I will get an Acid Liquor, from the other half a Volatile Alkalous Salt, merely by Ditillation. So likewie, I will get a large quantity of fix'd Alkali, and none or very little Volatile Alkali, or a larger quantity of volatile Alkali, and little or no fix'd, which I pleae, from the ame Herb, without any addition, merely by the different ways of Operating. From
thee and many other Coniderations of Things well known to Chymits, it's highly probable, thee Bodies are rather Products made by Combinations and Alterations, than the imple Elements of Bodies. And your aerting, That if Alkali were the product of Fire, the Caput Mort. burnt again, would produce more Alkali, is very weak: For the Caput Mort. has not the matter left whereof to make it. 2. Principles ought to be unchangeable, or ele they cannot be uppoed to be imple Bodies, but Acid, Alkali, Oyl are changeable. As for an Acid, I can change it into an Oyl, or into an Alkali. Oyl I can change into an Acid, and into Oyl again, or into an Alkali. Alkali, I can change into an Acid, and then that Acid, into an Alkali again. Which things are o well known to all that deerve the name of Chymits, I need not recite the Procees; and as for thoe that don't undertand Chymitry, it is beides my purpoe, here to teach them. But as for you Mr. Acid, tho' you may think your elf uncapable of being Tranmuted into an Alkali-Doctor, becaue The making Acids Alkalies, and Alkalies Acids, is contrary to your Experience, or the producing Alkalies or Acids out of thoe Bodies, in which they did not Exit: I can hew you uch an Experiment at any time, and then you are oblig'd upon your Word, to own your elf my humble Servant. As to the Accounting for the Phaenomena of Natural Bodies from Acid, Sulphur, Alkali, &c. they will oon appear too narrow, and inufficient (epecially if we could take them for imple Bodies) to any Coniderate Peron that does not erve an Hypotheis. I challenge any Man for intance to give me a reaon of the following Phaenomona, from the mixture of any of your Principles. Firt in Vegitable, or Animal Poyons, how a very mall quantity of matter, ometimes not the hundredth part of a Grain hould have uch dimal, various, and uddain effects from any mixture of Acid, Alkali, Oyl, &c. When thee in themelves may be took eparate, yea or conjunct, however we can joyn them again in coniderable quantities without any harm. What Hypothetick could ever make a mixture of Acid, Alkali, Oyl, &c. to have the effects of Opium, or of a Cathartick Drugg, that I have known work o violently as to bring a Man exceeding weak, by only holding it in his Mouth a Minute or two, and o pitting it out. The ame may be aid of Specificks, of which Mr. Acid himelf in a little fit of conideration, has own'd, There are many that are niether Alkalies nor Acids, yet eldom fail of curing Ditempers. Should he deny the Doctrine of Specifiks, ays he, he hould deny matter of fact, which he promies never to do, till he is totally deprived of his Reaon: And gives us ome Intances of the Operations of Specificks, which cannot be uppoed to proceed from their being Acids or Alkalies. Another Intance wherein thee Principles will be found
hort, is the Phaenomena of Magnetim; to name one thing, Take a Load-tone and rub one end of a poied Needle on the North Pole of the Stone, you will find that Point will be attracted to the ame Pole when ever it is brought near it: But offer the other end of the Needle to that ame Pole, it will be driven from the Stone as much as the other rub'd end is attracted; but force the end that is driven off, to the North Pole of the Stone, and keep it there ome time, it will be attracted as much as it was driven away before, and the end that was firt attracted will be driven away. Now here can be no conceivable alteration of the proportions of Acid and Alkali, or any other of your uppoed Principles in o hort a time, by the bare contract of the Needle and Load-tone, and this done at pleaure, without the leat alteration of the texture of the Needle or Load-tone. Again the gravity of Gold can no way be accounted for, by uppoing it compounded, howoever of your Principles; this Mettal being heavier than either of them, more than as twenty to three, o far is it from coniting of meet Acid and Sulphur, as Mr. As-Ey'd aeydly aerts; The heaviet Acid commonly known being lighter than this Metal about eighteen times, and Sulphur not much heavier. Now it is impoible that two light Bodies hould compoe a heavy one. I might recite many other Phaenomena in Bodies no way to be accounted for by thee uppoed Principles; as in Colours in the Rain-bow, in the prime and even permanent ones, as in the foremention'd Metal, which cannot receive its colour from things which on the account of their lightnes, can be no Ingredients of it. I might alo demand the reaon of ounds, their Harmonies or Dicords; but I hould tempt our Hypothetick Oracles in vain. But I think I have more reaon to conclude, that the Phaenomena of Bodily Nature, or the different Ideas we receive from Bodies depend upon, or reult from a far greater difference, and variety of Figures, Sizes, Textures, and Motions of the Particles of Matter, created at the beginning, of all Sorts and Sizes to us innumerable. From the Adheions and Combinations of ometimes more, ometimes fewer of thee Simple Particles, all the varieties of mix'd Bodies reult. Where there are Particles together, whoe Figures are more or les apt for Motion, there is a Body more or les fluid. Where the Particles hang together, and are more or les unapt for motion, there is a Body more or les olid. Where are fewer of the Simple Particles, there is a Body les compounded. Where there are more orts of differing Particles, there the Body is more compounded. Where there is a congeries of Particles of one Figure, there is a Simple Body; as probably the Particles of Air and Water may be, tho they do not touch one another
exactly, or ret together, and o are porous and fluid, and capable of receiving other Bodies into their Pores. And perhaps ome other Bodies, whoe Particles firmly adhere, and o are call'd Solid, may alo conit of imilar Particles. This innumerable variety is large enough to make all the mot odd properties of Bodies. The Diviions and Combinations of thee Simple Particles by Art (tho' perhaps eldom or never divided into ets Similar or Simple) is that whereby all the Artificial new reulting Bodies are made. But a ingle Particle, let it be of what Figure or ize it will, cannot be uppoed capable to be divided; becaue it conits of pure Matter continuous, and not of Parts meerly contiguous; and o there is no Vacuum, or room for any other Body to come in to divide it, as there is between the contiguous parts of Matter. And tho' the leat Particle in Nature might be uppoed Mathematically or Imaginarily diviible; yet really and Phyically the greatet Particle cannot be o thought; tho' ome inconiderately aert a Phyical infinite Diviibility. I hould her leave your Principles to their Mater; with thee few Coniderations, but that poor Alkali is o abued by you, there needs a word or two here to be poken for him. And I mut tell you, it is from meer pite and ill-will, and no reaon, that you ay, he is the Principle of Death and Corruption, and created ince the Fall in oppoition to Life. I mut oppoe Moes to you, who tells us (and he had it written by the Finger of God) That, in ix days God made Heaven and Earth, the Sea, and all that in them is, Exod. 20. 11. Wherein Alkali mut needs be concluded (if it be a Creature of God) And God aw every thing that he had made, and behold it was very good, Gen. 1. 31. Adam was fleh and bones, Gen. 2. 23. made within the Six Days, and had no part of his Body made ince; becaue all things were made within that term, and o mut have his Alkali in him before the Fall, as well as it was in other things, tho' not as you ay in every thing ele, either then, or now, which you would not have aerted had you not had a Treacherous Memory: For you before denied it to be in that incorruptible yellow ubtance you love as well as Lemons and Oranges, which you ay conits only of Acid and Sulphur, tho' it is as inipid, as mot of your Dicoure. And though we read, God aid unto Adam, Cured be the Ground for thy ake, yet

< in non-Latin alphabet > Tranlated for thy ake, comes from < in non-Latin alphabet >
tranivit thence
< in non-Latin alphabet > and < in non-Latin alphabet >
Propter, denoting a paage from the Caue to the effect; and the Cure may rather be attributed to Adam, as the Caue, than to God. Adam was to pas out of Paridie to
Till the Ground, from whence he was taken, and he and his Poterity hould bring a Cure upon it, or rather on themelves in the abue of it by their evil deeds, according to which the Septuagint, trantate the word we read for thy ake,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
in thy works: And as < in non-Latin alphabet > properly ignifies red Earth, Man was made of, it will not be extravagant to uppoe thence, that nothing was cured but Mankind, and that by their own evil doings, and and not by God the Fountain of Goodnes. Nor are Thorns, and Thitles to be uppoed created after the fall, or not good in themelves, but the Earth would bring them forth without Mens Cultivation when more ueful things mut be planted with labour, and toyl, and Man turn'd out of Paradice, mut no longer enjoy the Fruits of God's immediate planting. But if the Cure mut needs betook for omething God did, or would do to the Earth it may probably, as ome uppoe, be meant of the Deluge, from Gen. 8. 21. I will not again cure the ground for Mans ake. The word we have for Cure is < in non-Latin alphabet >
ad maledicendum from < in non-Latin alphabet >
vilipendit, intimating, as if God did not eteem the works of his Hands, but let them go to wrack. But here the Cure is taken off. God would for the future uphold all things in their order. But however let the Earth be Cured for thy ake, be to be undertood, I think it will not eaily be read. Let it bring forth Alkali for thy ake. Moes tells you, God pronounced all that he had made, very good; you ay a part of the Creation is bad. But hear what Solomon aith, Widom 1. 12, 13.
< in non-Latin alphabet >
eek not Death in the error of your Life, nor detroy your elves through the works of your own hands. For God has not made Death neither hath he pleaure in the Detruction of the Living, for he hath created all things in their being, and the Generations of the World Salutary, and there is not in them a Medicament of Detruction. From the Fountain of Goodnes nothing evil can be uppos'd to come. But may be ome may Laugh and Ridicule me for having recoure to Sacred Writ, epecially the Writings of Moes, which all thoe look upon as a kind of Romance, who Suppoe Dr. Burnet's Hypotheis true, which Mr. Acid ees no reaon to doubt of. But for my part I confes, I believe Moes a better Philoopher, and a Truer Theorit, than either the pretended, or real Author of that contrary
Hypotheis. If Moes undertood the Myteries of Nature as well as any Man, and was guided by an Infallible Spirit, as Mr. Acid once aid, how is it that he can ee no reaon to doubt of that which contradicts him. But Mr. Acid can't ee how a Man can be in a good tate of Health one hour, and the next expiring, without uppoing a Principle of Death within us. I Anwer, his Memory is treacherous; one while he ays, All Perons have ome degree of Sicknes: Now he talks of Perons being in a good tate of Health: At another time, When he coniders the tructure of our Bodies, of what multitudes of minute Parts they are compoed, intead of being urprized at our being ick o often, he is almot amazed to think that we are ever well. So ay I, Man's Body is a delicate piece of Mechanim, coniting of a multitude of mall and tender Veels, bound up in a thin porous Skin, coniting motly of oft and tender Matter: Man's Mind is a foolih and violent Agent, oft forcing this curious Engine to that it is not trong enough for; and it is no wonder to ee a Man now well, and anon expiring by the exces of Eating and Drinking, of the Paions of the Mind, or other Forces upon Nature, which doubtles would have detroy'd even Adam in Innocency, could they have been, where was no culpable defect in Widom and Goodnes; without uppoing a Principle of Death. As Chrit himelf in whom there was no Sin, was found capable of Bodily Mieries, and a Violent Death. Swords and Pitols, and other the inventions of Man's Cruelty, are not the only things, whereby a Man's Life may be detroy'd in a hort time, but the mot innocent and wholome Food abued, and taken in exces, even Bread, in which ome reckon o much Acid, will oon do the buines. As I once knew a Woman by eating Bread very freely, got uch a Ditemper, that broke out in large Boils in many parts of her Body hardly ecaping with Life. And I think I may affirm, that where one Peron dies by the abue of the Creature Alkali, there are ten that loe their Lives by your beloved Principles Acid and Sulphur, or Oyl, in the one intance of exceive, and uneaonable drinking of Vinous Liquors. And I believe no Man of any coniderable Reaon and Experience, but by Obervation may find, that tho' Acid and Alkali are both good Creatures, ordain'd for their proper Ues and Benefits to Man; yet Acid things in their abue are more frequently, and trongly penricious to the Vital Oeconomy.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
Acids hinder Putrefaction, and reduce things from Putrefaction, already Putrify'd, and o mut be great Medicines: For there's no Dieae but proceeds from ome ort of Putrefaction of the Fluid Parts of our Bodies. Acids every Body knows, preerve
Animal Subtances from Corruption and Stench, and if Dead, Bodies were full of Acids, it is difficult to conceive how they could o oon Putrefie; nay, it were impoible they hou'd. For Acids can't undergo Putrefaction. And the more perfect, and durable any Vegitable is, the greater quantity of Acidum and Sulphur, it affords, and the les of excrementious Alkali: Alkalies preently caue Rottennes and Putrefaction in Animal Subtances, as may be een in making of Glovers Leather: Mr. Yardly a Glover of Worceter, the mot Ingenious Man, perhaps, that ever was of his Trade, he being (which is very trange for a Man of o Mechanick a mean Trade) a curious Phyloopher; tells me, that in making Leather, they firt throw their Skins into a Pit fill'd with a trong Alkalious lixivium, which makes them in a manner Rotten: After they make a trong Acid Solution, into which they throw their almot rotten Skins, which again reduces them to their Texture; nay, makes them firmer than they were at firt. From whence it may be naturally inferr'd, that Alkalies break the Texture, and detroy the parts of Animal Subtances, and moderate Acids preerve them, and retore them to their Tone and Texture, when they are before poiled by Alkalies. Nay, Alkali is the onely detroyer of all Bodies, and what brings them to a tate of Putrefaction and Corruption. Again, Acids uppres Fermentation. Alkalies excite Fermentation, in fermentable Liquors, as is too well known by the Brewers of this Town. Alkalies are the caue of all Praeternatural Heats in the Body. Acetum is good in Inflamations, Eriypelas, &c. And Acids are the only things that quench Thirt. Oyl of Vitriol is one of the bet Medicines known, in continual Feavers. Acids are the mot Effectual things in the World to eae Pains, and if Pain be caued by Acids, it is by giving them in too mall a quantity. Sal Alkali is Cautick, and burns the Skin. Inwardly given without being diluted with an Aqueous, Vehicle caues Vomiting, and depraves the Appetite and detroys it, Alkalies conveyed into the Blood, by breaking its Globules, and detroying its Texture, caue Scorbutes, Rumatimes, Sciatica's, Conumpions, Gouts, Palies, or ome other Chronical Dieaes. An Ingenious Peron, not long ince, who had formerly embraced the Doctrine of Acids, was willing to try what Effects the Transfuion of Acid and Alkalous Liquors into the Veins of a Dog would produce: And the Oyl of Sulphur injected into the Veins of one Dog made him brisk and lively, and hungry, intead of diordering him, Oyl of Tartar on the contrary, injected into another Dog's Veins, made him dull, and in a few Days he dyed,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
How Acids hinder Putrefaction in Animal Subtances, any one may ee by eaie Experiments; Oyl of Vitriol, or Spirit of Nitre. pour'd upon the red part of Blood, preently turns it into a black Corruption, and the Serum into a white purulent Matter: So Leather, Bladder, Fleh, Tendons, Skin, have their Texture detroy'd by thee Acids, and are Rotted and turn'd into a purulent Matter; yea, the very Bones are diolv'd by Acid Liquors: So far are Acids from hindering the diolution of the Texture of Animal Subtances; much les will they do the Miracle of reducing things already Putrefy'd, from Putrefaction, and o, being uch great Medicines. And as inconiderate, have you hewn your elf Mr. Acid, in aerting all Dieaes to proceed from ome ort of Putrefaction of the Fluids of our Bodies: For if there be ever any uch thing as Putrefaction in the Juices of the Body, it can't be reckon'd the Caue from whence a Dieae proceeds; but the Effect or Product of the Dieae: But there are many Dieaes, where there has not been one Rational Argument, or certain Experiment given to perwade a Putrefaction of Humours, properly o call'd, o much as an Effect. The difficulty of conceiving Dead Bodies impoible to be Putrefy'd, if full of Acids; is only to Mr. Acid: Others know very well, that even thoe Animals that abound o much with Acid, that in Ditillation, they will yield one half of their weight of a trong Acid Liquor, will notwithtanding Putrefie, and that as oon, or ooner, than ome others abounding with Alkali. And that a Man's Body may be kept without Putrifaction, or Stench a Thouand Years, without the help of Acids: Yea, Alkalies themelves, we know, are great Preervatives of Fleh and Blood, if ued in due quantity, from Corruption and Stench: As the Honourable Mr. Boyle tells you, in his Book Of Humane Blood, pag. 142. Where twelve Drachms of Blood, were put up with two Drachms of Spirit of Blood, and was thereby preerv'd a Year, of a florid colour, almot totally Fluid, had no ill Scent, or any ign of Putrefaction, and it would no doubt, have preerv'd it much longer. In which Book, he alo gives an account, of divers coniderable good Effects of the ue of the Spirit of Humane Blood, as a Medicine, inwardly and outwardly, in intances too long here to be recited; and tells you, pag. 206. That Volatile Alkalies in general, had been properouly ued in Phyick in England, ince the Year 1656. about which time, he had the good Fortune, to contribute o to introduce them, as to bring them by degrees into requet, and ees mall caue to doubt, but that they would be more generally eteem'd, and employ'd. The Judgment of which every way Learned Peron, can hardly be oppos'd to a young Medicater,
without diminihing him. The truth of whoe Narratives, in matters of Fact, known to him, are beyond quetion, to any that knew him, as I not only well did, but was either an Aitant, or Beholder in the making thoe Experiments, that are the ubtance of that Ueful Book of Humane Blood. To this may be added, the method of Preerving Dead Bodies of Dr. Gabriel Clauder, recited in the Memorials for the Ingenious, Oct. 30. 1882. Which is with a Lixivium of Oak Ahes, and Sal armoniack, in which, both a fix'd and volatile Alkali, are conjoin'd, and found to go beyond mot former Methods of Embalming. And tho' Acid Salts and Spirits won't undergo a proper Putrefaction; yet Vegetables, that yield mot of Acid, and Oyl in Ditillation, will Rot as oon, or ooner than ome others: Yea, Crabbs, Oranges, and Lemons, every Boy knows, will Rot ooner than ome Apples that are not our, and many of thoe Vegetables that yield mot Acid, by burning will yield the greatet quantity of fix'd Alkali; which Product, is as far from being capable of Putrefaction as any Acid, or of Rotting the Coal in which it lies; tho' it has lot the uppos'd preerving Acid. But the chief ground of your Belief, that Alkalies will preently Rot and Putrefie Animal Subtances; I find, is a tory you heard (but could not well remember) from your curious Philoopher and Country-Man, Mr. Yardly the Glover of Worceter, who may be a good Glover, for ought I know; but I'm ure, you have not learn'd Dreing of Leather of him (whether it be his fault or yours) any better than you did Pharmacy of your Mater the Apothecary. As for Philoophy, whether the Glover or you be the Mater, I know not, but probably he might teach you the Four Years, you out-did the Apothecary; but I believe you are both Philoophers of the ame Pitch. But as to Leather-Dreing, the trong Lixivium you talk of (to help your Memory) I tell you is Lime, which is not ued to Rot the Skins, in order to make them the tronger (the Glover knows better) but to get off the Wool, or Hair. And tho' by letting the Skins lie in the Lime-Pit too long, they may poibly be poiled beyond the recovery of all the Acids in the World; yet we all know, that Lime-Water is but a mild Alkali, and a Medicine of great ue in Chirurgery, and is o far from having any cautick, or violent Effect, on Living Bodies; that it may be afely, and to good purpoe ued even in Ophthalmicks, being a mild Remedy not o much as making the Eye, that mot enible Part, to mart; and not only o, but may be ued to good purpoe inwardly in ome Ditempers, without any fear of rotting one's Belly, or making Leather of it; tho' you give an Acid afterwards. But what you take for the Acid Solution, I am not certain, whether the infuion of Bran they ue, or the
Allum-Water. The firt we know becomes very our, and if the Skins lie in it too long, will indeed rot and poil them beyond recovery; but the Allum is not an Acid, as you may find by its turning the Syrup of Violets Green, which it will oon do; nor has it any of the Effects of an Acid: For tho' an Acid Spirit may be Ditill'd from it, there's no uch heat in Dreing of Leather, as can eparate the Acid from the Chalkey Subtance, with which it is already aturated, and made uncapable of having any operation as an Acid upon the Skins. But Allum is ued in making of Leather, on the account of its Atringency to make the Skins more compact, and the Acid before ued, is wah'd out, and not left in the Leather as a Preervative againt Corruption, which every Body may eaily try, and ee oon brought upon Leather, by even a mild Acid; o far is your Inference from being Rational, or grounded upon Experiment, That Alkalies break and detroy Animal Subtances: But Acids do the Miracles of reducing them when rotted and poil'd, a priviatione ad habitum, or from Rottennes to Integrity. And let me ask you here Mr. Acid, if you are Mentis compos, if all Alkalies break the Texture, and detroy the Parts of Animal Subtances; How does the Bladder, the Veins, the Veica Fellis, &c. hold out forty, fifty, ixty, eventy Years, againt this Corrupter in Sicknes, and in Health, and come to be found trong, and entire after Death? And how do the Bones that have no Acid, but abound with Alkali, remain o firm, and entire; when the Coffins made of Oak, or the more reinous Fir with all their Acids and Oyl, are rotten and conum'd? But what follows, That Alkali is the onely Detroyer of all Bodies, and that which brings them to a State of Putrefaction, and Corruption, is o Extravagant, one might upect you delirious; but I would ask you, if out of your Paroxyme, did you ever ee Gold, Silver, Stones, Sand, to which Alkali is trictly bound in Glas, Mercury, and a Thouand other Bodies I might name, detroy'd and brought to a State of Putrefaction by Alkalies? Could you prove your Words, you would perwade us, that Alkali is the univeral Diolvent, and that Fire detroyeth nothing. Well but another michief of Alkali is it excites Fermentation in fermentable Liquors: I tell you 'tis well it will do o, and that the Brewers know it; for we hould have but bad Drink without Fermentation: But I know, you are no Mater-Brewer, any more than a Mater in Leather-Dreing; if you were, you would know, you could have no Vinegar without Fermentation, and that no Liquors can Ferment, but thoe wherein are Materially both Alkali and Acid, and that all Fermentable Liquors, at length turn Acid. Alkalies again, ay you, are the caue of all Praeternatural Heats; I anwer, not till they meet with Acids, which may as well be
aid, to be the caue of the Heat excited between them, as the Alkalies. Vinegar may be good in Inflammations, &c. and o may Alkalies, ay I, which I have ued with good ucces in the Eriipelas. Neither are Acids the only things will quench Thirt: For Water is the only thing Nature requires, to allay a Natural Thirt, which is nothing but the ene of the Latex being deficient; and Thirt in Dieaes, is ooner allay'd by Nitre, or ome other neutral Salts, than by all your Acids. Oyl of Vitriol may be the bet Medicine in continual Feavers, you know, in the World, I will grant; but I know a better, and it is an Alkali, and uch an one, as you ne'er aw. As for eaing Pain by Acids, let any one try on a Cancer, or other painful Sore, or on a Wound: You may try your Tincture, as you call it, but try it on your own Fleh, and you will oon be convinc'd of the contrary, and the more you ue the wore; unles you mortifie the Part, then indeed, the pain is o far over, as the Mortification goes. But as to inward Medicines, every Body knows, a little Opium, will do more in eaing Pain, than a large quantity of Acid; if it were true, That Acid would eae Pain, and Opium does not eae Pain by any Acidity in it, as is eaily demontrable. But I have found by long Experience, on my elf, and others, That Alkalies, in ome Caes, are more powerful to eae Pain, than almot any thing ele; as in the Tooth-Ach, which I have been often troubled with. Strong fix'd Alkalies, every Body knows, apply'd alone to the Skin, are Cautick, and o are Acids, as Oyl of Vitriol, Butyr of Antimony, and the Lunar Cautick. But no Alkalies are to be taken inwardly without being Diluted with an Aqueous Vehicle; being too keen for the Parts they are to pas: So are Acids, which without being given in a Vehicle that mitigates them, will even corrode the Mouth, Pharynx and Stomach; and both Alkali, and Acid, imoderately and unduely given, will deprave the Stomach. For I have known thoe troubled with our Stomachs, yet want an Appetite, as well as a good Digetion. That you ay, Alkalies being convey'd into the Blood, and breaking its Globules, caue Scorbutes, Rheumatimes, &c. is but mere fancy (if it be o much) without ground: For you ne'er aw, or heard of any of thoe Dieaes, caus'd by giving Alkalies. As for the injection of Oyl of Sulphur into the Veins of a Dog, making him brisk and hungry, and Oyl of Tartar, into the other Dog's Veins, making him heavy, and at lat killing him: You warily conceal who the ingenious Peron was; but we have the ame Story in Etmuller's Dicoure de Chirurgia Infuoria, Cap. 10. And he was a more Ingemious Peron, than to embrace the Doctrine of Acids, or Alkalies either, or any uch little Hypothetick fancy of a Tyro, and Dy'd too long agoe, to be one of your Diciples; as you would willingly
have us believe, the Ingenious Peron to be. But he does not tell you, that he made the Experiment himelf, but relating the pernicious Effects of the Infuion of Spirit of Vitriol from Fracaatus; he ubjoins that of Oyl of Sulphur not killing, but eeming to make the Dog hungry. And this Relation, ays he, may eem trange, to him that coniders the great affinity of Oyl of Sulphur and Spirit of Vitriol, that they hould produce uch different Effects: But being animated, and aited by a certain Friend, I made the Experiment, and injected j. of Oyl of Sulphur per Camp. in j. of Water, and having made a convenient Ligature, let the Dog looe; from whence he oon began to have a hort Breath, and to be troubled with Convulions, epecially of his Mouth, with a great deal of Froth, which continu'd till he was as it were trangl'd, and o Dy'd in half an Hour's time, a great deal of thin red Water flowing out of his Mouth, when he was Dead, with a great deal of Froth wimming upon it. He gives a particular Account of what various Diorders were found in Diecting him, too long here to Relate; but he concludes thus, It eems that the Blood by the injection of the Acid of Sulphur, being made thick, unfit for Circulation, tagnated in the Lungs, and there by the Motion of the Air was turn'd into Froth, and Red Serum, and being driven on into the maller Arteries, and thence into the Vena Cava, nothing could Circulate through the Lungs; from whence the Vicera, and greater Branches of the Arteries were found empty. So far different is the Account of this Experiment he made himelf, from what he had, as a Relation, which we may therefore quetion. But as for Oyl of Tartar, whereby another Dog was Kill'd, not mentioning the quantity injected; he tells us, the Blood was made very Red, and more Fluid, than uual: From whence aies he, it appears, that too much coagu • ation of the Blood, like as too much Diolution of it, does Kill. He alo gives an Account of the Injection of Aqua Fortis, and Sp. of Nitre; both which uddenly Kill, Coagulating the Blood: And from all which, every Man that can reaon, may certainly conclude, that the thinning of the Blood by Alkalies can't be the Caue of of all Dieaes. And you Mr. Alkali, as harp as you would eem, I believe, will find it yet more difficult till, to make your fancy of Alkali's being the Caue of all Dieaes, appear but a little likely; if you come in particular to conider, ome of the Maladies, common to Humane Nature: For which I will prick up my Ears.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
The firt thing I begin with, is the Small-Pox, that fatal Ditemper to Three Kingdoms, and even to all Europe in that by the means of it, God was pleaed to deprive us of a Princes whoe worth was uch, as a ufficient value can never be et upon it, or Los
ufficiently Lamented. 'Tis the common Practice of Nures, and the generality of Practitioners, as oon as they perceive the Symptoms of this Ditemper, to give Gacoin's, Countes of Kent's Lapis de Goa, or ome other Tetaceous Powders, known Alkalies: The one Party to drive the malignity from the Heart, in which it's impoible for any malignity to lodg, more than in any other Part, by reaon the Blood moves at leat tentimes fater through the Heart, than any other Part, the Lungs excepted: For the Cavities being large no Stagnation is to be feared; but if any where, it is in the extreme Parts, where the Blood moves lowly. The econd ort, give them to correct the Acidity, they uppoe to be in the Blood. Now I could never hear of any one, that by Analizeing the Blood in the Small-Pox, could find the leat footteps of Acidity (as I before hinted) but on the contrary, it appears after many tryals, That the Blood of uch Perons, does more abound with Alkalous Particles than that of ound People: So in this Cae, the giving of Alkalies mut be uperfluous, if not highly pernicious. The Caues of the Small Pox, with mot other Feavers, and acute Dieaes, I uppoe to be from a quantity of uch Particles, being ome way or other admitted into the Blood, which being Heterogeneous, or of a quite different Texture from that of the Blood, and o not capable of being mixed with it, caues a hurry and diorder. Now a Feaver always preceeds the eruption of the Putles, and when the Heterogeneous Particles are thrown out to the urface, then the Feaver ceaes. Now to ait Nature in throwing out thee Heterogeneous Particles, which they pretend, are hindred by Acids in the Blood, they give Tetaceous Powders, and other Diaphoreticks, which eldom fail of their intention, of throwing out large quantities of Putles, more than Nature is able to bring to maturity, and if hedoes chance to Cope with them, is the only occaion of poiling o many Angelick Faces, we every Day oberve. But that is not all, but by Alkalies the Globules of the Blood are broken; when as the Excrementitious Serum only, ought to be eparated, according to the Rules of Nature, and not the leat Drop of Blood, when in its Natural State, and its Globules unbroken. But by the means of Alkalies the Globules being broken, are made capable of being receiv'd into the cutaneous Glands, which is the occaion of the purple Spots in the Small-Pox, and Feavers, which ne'er fail of being the certain Prognoticators of Death. But this is not all, thoe broken Globules getting into the Maeanders of the Brain, hinder the motion of the Animal Spirits through the Nerves, and caue Deliriums, and all thoe fatal Diorders of the Brain too frequently een: Likewie the Blood being capable of being contained in its proper Channel, is the occaion of violent Bleedings, bloody-Urine, &c. None of the bet
Symptoms. Beides, by their Diaphoretick quality they wate the Serum that there is not ufficient left to upply and bring to maturity the Putles, thoe Medicines alone had thrown out: So about the 9th. 11th. or 13th. Day, the Putles fall, and the Acrid Matter being aborb'd into the Veins, Caues Secondary Feavers, of dangerous Conequence: The Small Pox requires the giving as few Medicines, as any Dieae whatoever, unles in extraordinary Caes: Yet the Eye of a careful Phyician, is as convenient as in any. Indeed, I have heard ome complain, uch a Doctor had o many Fees, and yet never Wrot a Bill: But let me tell them, in many Caes, epecially in this, the Phyician deerves his Fees better for not Writting at all, than for o doing. In this Ditemper, Acids are the things skilfully and timely given, which I have een not only by my own, but other Great Men's Practice, to be the onely afe, effectual, and never erring Medicines.
