And why hould we fly to Acids Chymically prepar'd, when Nature has provided Oranges and Lemons, Citrons and Limes, which anwer our intentions? For in Five Hundred, at leat Patients I have had, of all Qualities to do with in this Ditemper, where I have been call'd in the beginning, I don't know, that I have had one that has Dy'd, or been Disfigur'd: Nay, ome that have been brought into ill Cirumtances by Alkalies, I have retriev'd from the Jaws of Death by proper Acids. To allay the hurry of the Blood, and to confirm its Texture, I give Juice of Oranges, Lemons, Limes in Barley-water, or Small-Beer, acidulated with Oyl of Vitriol, Vinegar, or Verjuice Poet-Drink: If the Brain be diturb'd, and the Patient Delirious, I find it abolutely neceary, to let Blood in good quantities, and ue more powerful Acids, which ets all to rights. So the method I take in the Cure of this Dieae, being according to Nature's Dictates, is hort and eaie: It being in the Cure of this Dieae, as in the accounting for the Phaenomena of Nature; they that go upon fewet Principles, generally Dicover mot of her Secrets, and can give the bet Account of them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
The Small Pox has been Fatal to Englih Princes, more than once; tho' not o much in it elf, as through the ill Practice of Ignorant, or wore Phyicians: But that God hou'd be pleas'd with any Evil, be the Caue, or Sender of Dieaes, or the Taker away of any uch Good, whereby Obedience to his Laws, might be promoted; I think, cannot be believ'd, but by inconiderate Sinners, looking on God, as if he were like themelves. If I did believe, that the Sicknes of him that is Sick, and the Death of him that Dies, were the poitive Will of God, I think, I hou'd be wicked, as well as foolih, in endeavouring to Heal. But it's common with Phyicians, when through their Ignorance, Carelenes,
or other fault the Patient Dies, injuriouly to ay, God took them away, and dareingly to lay their own faults upon their Maker. As for Nures giving Tetaceous Powders to drive Malignity from the Heart, I have nothing to ay, towards their information: 'Tis Phyicians buines to look to them, that they onely obey their Directions, and do their proper Office: Nures know not what Malignity is, and you need not prove to them, that there can't be Malignity in the Heart, any more than any where ele, or o likely, as in the Extremities. But the Reaon you give, tho' it might erve Nures (who may believe any thing) if you offer it to Phyicians, viz. That the Blood moves ten times fater through the Heart, than any other Part (but the Lungs) hews your great Ignorance and inconideratenes. If you but count the Pules of your Heart and Writ, you will oon find your Mitake: And if the Blood hou'd move fater through the Heart (as you fancy) than through other Parts, it Circulation could not continue, the Fountain being empty'd fater, than again upply'd. As for the ue of thoe Powders, you call Tetaceous, by Phyicians, whom you honourably place, Second to Nures, and I uppoe, Third to your elf, I think, none of them o foolih, as to give them to correct Acidity in the Blood, any otherwie, than by Aborbing it in the Stomach. [And Mr. Acid himelf once told us, That none pretend Crab's-Eyes, Pearl, Corral, &c. to be ueful any farther, than to aborb Acids in the Stomach, where we know, and you grant, it is ometimes too much,] and o hindring a upply of Acid in the Veins: Where tho' you could never find any, I have told you the Reaon before, and how it's Demontrated, that there is an Acid in the Blood. I have alo anwer'd already, your Aertion that the Blood of Perons in the Small Pox, abounds more with Alkali, than the Blood of Sound Perons: To which, I farther add, this Obervation, That I have een the Sweat and Serum of a ound Peron, turn Syrup of Violets Green readily; when the very Ichor and Corruption in the Putles of the Small Pox, would hardly dicolour it: On which account it appears, there was not o much Alkali, or o little Acid, as in the Sound Perons. And contrary to your Accuation of Alkalies, as pernicious: I ay, I have never found the giving of Alkalies in this Ditemper, in the leat hurtful, but very beneficial, if duly given; and I have ued Alkalies here, more than any other Medicines, and never had one Patient Dye, or Deform'd, in two Seven Years Practice. But if the Caue of this Dieae, and of mot Feavers, as you affirm, be from Particles admitted into the Blood, which are of o Heterogeneous, or different a Texture from that of the Blood, as that they are not capable of mixing with it; then it will
certainly follow, that thee Morbifick Particles in thoe Dieaes, are not Alkalies; Alkealies being Homogeneal to, mixable with, and requiite in making up the Natural and ound Texture of the Blood: There being no Blood from whence they may not be gotten in great quantity, and the Globules, or Red part of the Blood yields a greater proportion of Alkali, than the Serum. And thus you have unwarily thrown down, what you had Built before. But here is another Cramper, viz. How any Particles that are uncapable of being mix'd with the Blood, hou'd (as you ay) be admitted into it, and flow with it: None but your harp ight can ee this. As for the hurry of the Blood, or Feaver, Caus'd as you ay. by thoe unmixable Particles, being mix'd with it. I ay, firt it's certain. That Blood naturally contains, or yields abundantly more Alkali than Acid: Now the Alkali alone cannot be put into a hurry, or fermentative Motion, and o grow too Hot, neither will the msllet quantity of Acid, caue it o to do; but more Acid added may produce a greater Heat; as any Body may ee, by mixing Acids and Alkalies. Now thee Acids (which probably never are a tenth to the Alkali) being ubdued, and having lot their Force by being coagulated with the Alkali, tick in the Extremities, here and there, and caue little Inflammations, and at length Suppurate, which when they are once thus fix'd, the Feaver ceaes. Now to ait Nature in Precipitateing, and ubduing thee Acids, rather than ome unknown, unmixable Particles; the mot Rational, and Experienced Phyicians have given Tetaceous Powders, and other Aborbents to hinder a upply of them from the Stomach, the chief Officine of Praeternatural Acids, and alo volatie penetrating, and Diaphoretick Alkalies to help to ubdue them already too abundant in the Blood. Which things, as you (hall I ay ingenuouly or unwillingly) confes eldom fail of their intention of throwing out plentifully the Morbifick Matter which Nature is more able to bear, and bring to maturity in Putles in the Skin than to Cope with in the Blood, there detain'd through the weaknes of Nature wanting help, or by Acids given hindering the Eruption. And tho' in gros Bodies (which you your elf reckon have always more Acid, having more Fat) the large quantity thrown out to the Skin, oft poils thoe Angelick Faces, you eem o tender of, to get the Ladies Favor; yet the not coming forth of this Morbifick Matter, often makes a greator poil of the whole Bodies of thoe Angels, laying their Beauty in the Dut. But as few Patients chue rather to Die with a mooth Face, than Live with a rough one; o it's the Phyician's part, rather to take care of Life, than Beauty: And it had been well it had been o in the Cae of that Princes, whoe inward Form, trancended that of her Face;
whoe fair Soul, wou'd have been Conpicuous thro' a rougher Skin, and no les ueful; had not her Life been thrown out, intead of the Morbifick matter. As for the breaking of the Globules of the Blood you talk o much of; it is mere fancy, grounded upon no Experiment. The attenuation of the Blood made by Alkalies, as alo by the working of the Lungs, is not to be thought a breaking of the Globules; but rather a eparation of them from adhering together, whereby they are more equally mix'd with the Serum: Thence alo the Blood becomes more florid, the urfaces of thoe little round Bodies, when more disjoin'd, being capable of reflecting more Light. Nor is the Extravaation of the Blood, at any time, to be attributed to the breaking of the Globules, and making them mall enough to pas out of the Veels, which at the ame time ufficiently contain the Serum, whoe Particles are perhaps a Thouand times maller than the Globules, tho' you hou'd uppoe, every one broken into Twenty pieces: But rather from ome breach of the mall Veels, from ome Corroion, or other violence, either from without, or from the rapid Motion of the Blood. Neither is the toppage of the Animal Spirits, from what caue oever, to be thought to produce Deliriums, and uch like Dieaes: But on the contrary, their over wift Motion from too great Heat. The toppage of the Nerves, if there be any uch thing is more like to caue Palies, Lethargies, Apoplexies, &c. The Serum is not wated too much by Alkalies, or other Diaphoreticks, if given with Dicretion; and o adminiter'd, they prevent the falling of the Putles, and return of the Morbifick Matter. As to the few Medicines, you ay, the Small Pox requires, I readily agree that it requires fewer than are commonly given, and o do all other Dieaes: For the giving of many Medicines, as is the Cutom of Precribers, is a Practice wherein the Phyician will for ever remain uncertain, whether he do good, or none, or harm, and by what: The Judgment, and Care of a Phyician in this Dieae, I agree, is alo neceary, and the Patient had better hire ome Practitioners, epecially owr Doctors, to do nothing, than to diturb and hinder Nature in throwing on the Morbifick matter, by large and improper Precriptions. As for Acids being the onely afe, effectual, and never failing Medicines, as you ay, you have een by your own, and other Great Men's Practice: I mut tell you, tho' you reckon your elf among Great Men, That many Phyicians Greater in all commendable Greatnes, than you, or any other of your great Crabb-Tree-Heads, have had better ucces in a contrary Opinion and Practice. I my elf can aure you, that Alkalies are Medicines, in this ditemper a Judicious Phyician can hardly want. For as the Ebullition, and Expulion are not to be too much
promoted, or hatily carryed on; o when they are too low, they ought to be excited, and hatened, which may well be done by volatile Alkalous Medicines. A Judicious Phyician will not give Alkalies, or Acids he knows not why, only becaue they are Alkalies, or Acids, or follow always one Intention, the retarding the motion of Nature, or allaying the hurry, as you do Great Sir, with your Oranges and Lemons, Crabbs and Limes, which tho' they ate milder, than ome Chymical Acids; yet a drop or two of Oyl of Vitriol in an Aqueous Vehicle may be a milder Acid than the Juice of Oranges or Lemons taken alone. As for your boat, that in Five hundred Patients in this Ditemper of all Qualities, viz. Emperours, Kings, Dukes, Earls, Madmen, Tinkers, Coblers, and their Conorts, &c. to whom you have old your Lemons, and Oranges, not one died, or was difigured; you may as well be believed as the Quack, who aid in his Bills, amongt other Brags, that he had been Counellor to the Counellors of Twenty Chritian Kings: When there are not o many in the World. Nor have you ever had a quarter o many Patients ick of this Ditemper. And you might have told us of retrieving from the Belly of Death, as well as from the Jaws thereof, ince you believe People expect you hould make them Immortal. But truly it's unlikely you hou'd do uch Miracles, epecially in this Dieae, when you endeavour nothing but to hinder the motions of Nature, or to allay the hurry, as you call it, which truly is not a method according to Natures Dictate's: Short it is indeed, and may be a hort way to the Grave, and eaie it is, for the Doctor to give always the ame things; but often very uneaie for the Patient. But if thoe that go upon the fewet Principles in dicovering Nature's Phaenomena, dicover mot of her Secrets, and can give the bet Account of them, as you ay, then thoe that have but two Principles, as Figure and Motion, Alkali and Acid, Acid and Sulphur, are like to outgo you Sir, for you creep upon Five Legs. As for your abolute neceity of Letting Blood in good quantities, where the Patient is Delirious, and the Brain diturbed, it's abolutely Dangerous, and were well let alone for proper Sedatives, for it oft proves pernicious in this Ditemper: As in the Cae of the bet Princes England ever had: Neither Alkali, nor Acid, was o effectual towards terminating the Dieae, as the Officious Lance, weakning, and diturbing the Motion of Nature. But methinks we have been long on this Dieae, What hall we have next.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
I come to the Scurvey, where I expect the cry of all Mankind will be againt me, what ay they, is there no Acidity in the Blood, the occaion of thoe breakings out of Scabs, Pimples, Botches,
and of wandring Pains? Have Patience, and I will make it appear thoe Symptoms come from Lixivious Alkalous Particles, and Firt, it appears, That the Blood of Scorbutick Perons, has more volatile Alkali, than that of Sound Perons, beides, a quantity of lixivious fix'd Alkali, which I could never find in Sound Peron's Blood. Another Argument is, that I have been told that Seamen having had the Scurvey in long Eat-India Voyages, Landing at Cadis, have by Eating of Lemons and Oranges, been oon perfectly Cured: But in thee Cold Countries, we are forced ometimes to have recoure to more powerful Acids: Some object that more than ordinary altnes is found in the Blood of Scorbuticks, which they take to be an Acidity, but intead of Acidity, if they will enquire, they will find it to be a Lixivious Alkalous one. And here I hall inert a Preparation of Antimony, I have found of extrrordinary ue in inveterate Scurveys. Take White Fowers of Antimony viij. vol. p. of Tartar lbij. diget 14 Days, decant it, then Ditill off half the Liquor, and keep the remains for ue. The Spirit of Tartar is made thus, Ren: Tartar lbxx. Ditill it in an Iron-Pot with a Moor's-Head, with a large Worm fitted to a Tub of Water: Ditill by degrees as long as any thing will come over, take out the Caput Mort. Calcine it to Greynes, put lbiij. of it into a Cucurbit, pour on it the Spirit freed from the Oyl, draw off half, with a moderate Fire, pour out the remains as ueles: put lbij. more of the Caput Mort. on which pour the Spirit drawn off, and with a gentle Fire draw off half, which keep for ue. It is a Noble volatile Spirit, and as Noble a Mentruum, as I have met with. Of the Tincture, I give Four, Six, Eight, or Ten Drops, Morning and Evening, in a trong Decoction, or infuion of Juniper. Berries half a Pint. This anwers every thing aid of a true Panacaea.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
If the cry of all Mankind be againt your Opinion of the Scurvey, it is no good ign you are in the right; for we know your capacity too well, to believe you wier than all Men. And you have never yet made it appear, that the Blood of any Dieaed Perons abounds with Alkalies, more than that of the ound People. You have not made ufficient tryals, nor been aware of the difficulties of finding the true Quantities of the Products of Blood, nor have you demontrated, That there is any thing Lexivious in the Blood of Scorbuticks. A Salum more or les may be found in the Blood of both ick and healthy Perons, and probably more in the Blood of thoe that have the Scurvey; which poibly a Man of haty concluions (as Mr. Acid o oft hews himelf to be) may take it for an Alkali; becaue it will turn Syrup of Violets green, as common Salt, and ome other Salums will do, and for a Lixivious, or fixed one; becaue it
does not rie eaily in the Fire. But if you knew how to work, you would find an Acid Spirit come from it in Ditillation, as from ome other things you take to be Alkalies. But a Lixivious Salt, as you have acknowledged, is the Product of Fire, and the Fire in the Blood is nothing but a hot fancy, that makes no ahes. But you mut make ue of another Fire, before you can get any fixed Salt, or Volatile either out of the Blood. But if you could produce uch a reulting body as a fixed Alkali, by burning the Blood, or other parts of a Scorbutick, or other Dieaed Peron it would not prove, That an Acid, was not actually therein before, or that this Alkali was: For I have never found a Lixivious Salt, o trong and copious in any Animal Subtance, as where there was a manifet and plentiful Acid; nor will any other Subtance as far as I have oberved, yield o much fixed Alkali in burning, as thoe that otherwie, give mot Acid and Oyl. As for your Scorbutick Seamen cured at Cadis (if the Story be true) it may be more rationally thought they were recoverd by eating Freh Meat, and drinking Generous Wine, than by Oranges and Lemons, unles they had been the only things they fed upon. Your preparation of Antimony, you ay, you have found of uch extraordinary ue in inveterate Scurveys, hews your Ignorance in Chymitry, and argues againt you, doing all that a true Panacaea can be aid to do, if any one can be o all-believing as to credit you, when no one Acid (as you have ometime aid) will do o: For what Acid will cure an acute Dieae, will not Cure a Chronick; Volatile Acids being mot effectual in Acute Dieaes, fixed ones in Chronick, [to which I mut tell you by the by, that you never aw a fixed Acid in your life] but your Panacaea does all things, and yet if made according to your Precription is no Acid: For tho' the Tartar by Ditillation yeilds an Acid Liquor, yet the pouring it on the Caput Mortuum, and ditilling off but half twice the fixed Alkali retains the Acid, and ends up only a Phlegmatick Liquor, which is a very poor Meniruum; the greatet Vertue remaining behind, tho' Mr. Chymit throws it away as ueles: But as your Liquor may retain ome Particles of the Flowers of Antimony when digeted together, o as it is Vomitive, it may do omething on that account, but not as an Acid; the Vomitive qualitiy of Antimony depending on omething ele; but giving it with half a Pint of the Decoction, or infuion of Juniper-Berries, poils the credit of the other things; the Juniper-Berries jutly claiming the greatet hare in the Cure, if it do one. But what hall we have next? What ay you to the Gout?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
It has been contantly handed down from Generation to Generation, that the Gout is a Ditemper not to be cured, and in pight of the noie the lat Age has made of Experimental Philoophy, no Man ever went out of the common Road, to try whether that were true or fale: But now it do's evidently appear that the Gout is not uch a Fury, but that it may with eae be overcome by proper and powerful Acids. Now if my Predeceors have been o notoriouly Ignorant, as to the Caue and Cure of common Ditempers, it is not unreaonable to believe they have been o in others: Nay, they have been o. And the reaon why People have hitherto in vain attempted the Cure of the Gout, has been from their prejudice againt Acids, which only can do ervice. What would not People give to ave their Lives, and be free from pain? Phyitians as the cae tands can do neither with any certainty; but by making multitudes of Experiments upon the Foundation I can lay down, the cae may be altered. If People were once atisfied, That the abounding of Alkalies is the caue of the Gout, it follows that Acids are the only proper things to correct it. That the Gout is caued by Alkalies, may appear from the Chalky ubtance generated in the extreme Parts, which is generated in the time of the Fit only, and is a Collection of Homogeneal Particles, Particles of one determinate Figure, by reaon the Fire won't totally detroy its texture; which were it a Body compos'd of Particles of different Sizes and Figures (which are what we Chymits call Heterogeneous ones) the Fire would detroy it. And that they are Alkalous, none I uppoe will dipute, they anwering all the Phaenomena that mot known Alkalies will do, viz. caue an Ebullition with Acids, and when calcin'd turn Syrup of Violets green, and ometimes (tho' not always) will do it without. I take notice few People are troubled with the Gout, but thoe who drink much Wine, or other generous Liquors, abounding with Vinous Spirits: Thee Spirits meeting with Volatile Alkalous Salts, by means of the Salt the Vinous Spirit is coagulated into what Helmont calls Offa Alba, which not being capable of moving through the mall Veels, caues Obtructions and Pains, and by the addition of Terretrious Particles, is turned into the Chalky Subtance, I cannot agree with thoe Gentlemen, who aert all Pain proceeds from a Solution of Continuity. I don't argue, that there is no Pain prooceeds from a Solution of Unity, but there are vilent Pains where the Union is entire, as in a blow with a blunt thing. But I lay it down as a poitive Aertion, that all Pain is caued by a Stagnation of Juices, cauing a Compreion of the
Membranes: But as the Stagnation is greater or leer, and as the Stagnating Matter is more or les Acrimonious, o is the Pain greater or les, but there is no Pain in any part without Stagnation. People have more reaon to believe there is a Solution of Unity in the Palie, where there is a viible Conumption, tho' there, they are altogether void of Senation. The Medicines I ue are few, and motly well-known, but never ued in the manner I have done: The general Bais of them is the ame, they being all Acids; and my Medicines will put no force upon Nature, have no hazard, but trengthen all the Parts. I have given as clear hints, nay clearer than ever were given of the Cure of the Gout, which has hitherto been vainly attempted, but my method will as certainly Cure the Gout, as the Cortex, Agues, or Opium make Sleep, and I have known it fail but two or three times, and thoe were to be imputed rather to the Pervernes of the Patients.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
I cannot forbear to tell you Mr. Acid, there has not been a more Ignorant Calumniator of all Phyicians, or Confident Praier of one little Quack, than You; perpetually hewing us, that you have neither Read others, nor known your elf. All the Phyicians of the World, from generation to generation, have affirm'd the Gout incurable, and tho' the lat Age hath made a noie of Experimental Philoophy; yet to pight them, no Man would go out of the common Road, to try whether that were true, or fale. Till Colbatch roe, who hath made it appear, that the Gout is not uch a Fury, but it may be overcome by powerful Acids. Colbach's Predeceors have been notoriouly Ignorant of the Caue and Cure of common Dieaes; much more of the Gout, or ele Colbatch has been notoriouly ignorant and abuive of his Predeceors. For every Body acquainted with Authors, knows there's not one of any Note, but has Writ more Learnedly and Judiciouly of this, and other Dieaes; and whoe Obervations of Cure, are abundantly more Credible than Mr. Acid's, whom we can prove a Lyar, by his own Words. For he has acknowledg'd his Mater Helmont to deerve better, of the World, and to be a greater Man than himelf. Yet he among the ret, his Scholar John aith, hath affirm'd the Gout incurable, and been ignorant of the Caue and Cure of common Dieaes. But Helmont hath aerted the Gout Curable, and profeeth himelf Mater of a Medicine, viz. Arcanum Coralinum of Paracelus, which radically Cures that Gout, and many other Dieaes, and it is not an Acid neither, being a fixed Medicine. And Paracelus before him whom you couple with him in your contradictory Praies and Dipraies, if we may give no credit to his own words eeing
by you, that great Doctors will lie, hath a ufficient Tetimony of his Abilities in Curing the Gout, as well as other difficult Dieaes in his Epitaph on the Church-wall at the Hopital of Saltzburg, as following: Conditur hic Philippus Theophratus, inignis Medicinae Doctor, qui dira illa vulnera Lepram Podagram Hydropiim, &c. Miriica arte utulit, &c. And he was one as well as Helmont, that had no prejudice againt either Acids or Alkalies. That nothing but Acids can do any ervice in the Gout, is an aertion contrary to the Judgment and Experience of all the Phyicians that have Writ of this Dieae, and the Practice of Mr. Acid himelf, as I believe, we hall find before we have done; and o univeral, that no Man wou'd have aid o, but one Confident enough to ay, he knows all Things, and foolih enough to contradict himelf. What would not People give to ave their Lives, and be free from Pain? Phyicians in general, the College themelves, if they be Phyicians, can do neither for them, with any certainty, till they have made multitudes of Experiments on Chym • t Colbatch's Foundation, which may be long a doing. Therefore Sirs, if you are Wie, come to their Mater himelf, he can do both, if you can believe him, and be ure to pay him well for his Lilly, White Vinegar. it may be a great while e'er many of the People call'd Phyitians come to be atisfied, that the abounding of Alkalies is the caue of the Gout; but if they were, it will not follow on your Hypotheis, that Acids are the onely proper Correctors of it. We will uppoe, that in the Gout, or any other Dieae, there is too much Alkali in the Blood: What is to be done? Why, it ought to be carry'd off by the Emunctories, ay you. By what means? By Acids ay you. How can Acids do it? Why, they are contrary to Alkalies, ay you, and fight them whereever they meet, conquer them, and make them quit the Field. No ay I, 'tis a mitake, they are not contraries, or Enemies, but as good Friends as any old Sweet-hearts, eparated againt their wills. They rejoice when they meet fall a Dancing till they are hot again, & when tired they lie down together in mutual and cloe embraces, and are o wedded by the Law of Nature, that they will not be divorc'd, unles one of them can be tempted to Adultrey; then indeed the other does not beat, but leave its Companion with didain. Your Mater Helmont tells you. There are no contraries in Nature (he means Bodily Nature) but contrariety is only in Wills: And he gives you good Reaon, for what he ays: But could Alkalies and Acids, any way be aid to be contrary, What then? It don't follow, that one mut needs thrut the other out of Doors; and if they did, one would think the Detroyer of all Things, being too much for the other, mut thrut it out: What is tronger than
Death. But experience tells us, that whereever they meet, they o combine that they are both harder to be drove out, than either of them ingle. You have an intance in Sal Armoniack, made of the Acid Spirit of Salt, and Volatile Alkali of rine; which Alkali alone is o Subtil and Diipable, that it will fly with the leat heat, and is hardly kept without wating, except with well fitted Glas-topples; but combin'd with Spirit of Salt, they are coagulated together into a Body, that will be kept open without any los of Subtance, if urg'd with heat will indeed fly but together, and that not without a coniderably trong Fire. But if the Volatile Alkali be united with ome Acid that is not coagulable into a Body, it will nevertheles be rendred les Volatile, requiring a greater Fire to raie it, than it did alone. Now if Alkalies and Acids can be thought to meet o copiouly in the Blood, as to make what you call a Conflict, but I with better reaon term a Dance or Playing together, and produce an ebullition, and Heat; that Heat may deerve the name of a Feaver, and be a diturbance in the Vital Oeconomy equally, whether it be a Dance, or a Fight, if there be too much of the Sport; and thee two Bodies combin'd, epecially if the Acid be of any coniderable quantity, will be les apt to be carried off by Tranpiration, than the one of them ever o abundant. But if there cannnot be o much Acid pour'd in, as to make an Effervecence and Coagulation with the Alkali, which is in Siknes, and ought to be in Health abundantly more than the Acid can be; yet the Acid may have this effect, as to thicken, and hinder the motion of, the Blood, and thereby render it more unapt to dicharge the Alkali; if we uppoe it ought to be dicharged. And that Acids do coagulate and thicken the Blood, we have often een upon tryal with Oyl of Sulphur, as well as Oyl of Vitriol: So far is Acid from being the thing, much les the only thing that can dicharge, and drive out your fancied noxious, and to be dicharged Alkali. And tho' Acid may be proper enough in ome Dieaes, where the Blood is too thin and moveable to thicken it; yet in uch Dieaes as Scurveys, Rehumatims and Gout, where the Blood is already too thick, and apt to Coagulate, and tick in the mall Veels; the making it thicker by Acids mut needs be improper, contrary to all Indications of Cure. The Chalkey ubtance generated in the Fits of the Gout, does not prove the Dieae caued by Alkalies rather than by Acids: For Alkalous Salts when in olution, are not Coagulated alone, but by meeting with Acids; except by evaporation of the humidity they are diolved in, which can't be uppoed here. Neither is the Creta a Salt, and were it as you ay produced of the Volatile Salt of the Blood and Homogeneal, it
mut be all Salt. But you never aw a Salt inipid, or a Volatile one contant in the Fire, as you ay this matter is. Nor are all Bodies coniting of Particles of different Sizes, and Figures (which is what you are o kind as to tell us you Chymits mean by Heterogeneous) totally detroy'd by the Fire, as you may ee in Bricks, Bones, Glas, Metals and a Thouand things. But the Podagrick Matter, as Kerking tells us, Spicileg Obj. 28. by Ditillation yields a Spirit of a middle nature, between Spirit of Tartar and Spirit of Sal Armoniak more Acid than one, and more mild than the other, and an Oyl very like Oyl of Tartar, leaving a fixed Salt in the Caput Mort. much like Salt of Tartar: Where are your Homogeneal Particles Sir? But the abounding of Alkalies, right or wrong you will have it, is the caue of the Gout. But how I pray you Sir, after what manner? Why, few are troubled with the Gout, ay you, but thoe that drink Vinous Liquors; and o the Blood abounding with Vinous Spirits, thee Vinous Spirits meeting with Volatile Alkalous Salts, are by the Alkali Coagulated into what Helmont calls Offa Alba; which not being capable of moving thro' the mall Veels caues Obtructions and Pains, and by the addition of Terretrious Particles, is turned into a Chalkey Subtance. Now John I have caught you, and you cannot come off your Contradiction, but by begging Pardon on the account of your very Treacherous Memory. The Chalkey Subtance was but now a collection of Homogeneal Particles (that is, Particles of one determinate Figure, as you pleaed to Englih it for us) but now it is a Compound of a Vinous Spirit, an Alkali. Salt, with an addition of an Earthy Matter. This is the reult of abundance of Experiments no doubt; thee are Grounds to build your Practice upon, whereby you are able to do more than other People, that is, than all the Phyicians of all Ages. But I mut tell you for all that, that you grosly mitake Offa Alba, not knowing what it is. But I tell you, it is not a Coagulation of a Vinous Spirit, but a Precipitation of the Urinous Salt out of its Phlegm, by the affuion of the Vinous Spirit; but unles the Vinous and Urinous Spirits be both trong it will not do; nor will all Urinous Spirits make the Offa Alba. The reaon of this Phaenomenon where it ucceeds is this, The Volatile Salt not being Soluble in trong Spirit of Wine, and having but little Phlegm of its own, more than what will diolve it, the Vinous Spirits being apt to mix with that Phlegm, fills its Pores, and o it lets fall the Salt. But it's impoible to find a Livings Man's Blood o trongly Alkalous, as that there hould be but jut enough Latex to diolve the Salt: Nor were it poible, can there be added Vinous Liqours in quantity, and trength enough to
make uch a Coagulation. We Phyitians all know, Mr. Chymit, that the Blood never abounds o much with Alkalous Salt, as to make o much as a weak Spirit, nor can the Spirit of the Wines we drink, be eparated from the Phlegm in our Bellies, nor can we drink Vinous Spirits trong enough to Coagulate an Alkalous Spirit. Moreover, this Offa Alba which Helmont talks of, is o very Subtil and Volatile, that it would eaily find paage, and be carried off through the mallet Pores by a gentle Heat, and would be o far from Coagulating into a Chalkey Subtance, as that it is a good Medicine to thin the Blood, and hinder Coagulations; as alo very beneficially ued externally in pains, of the Gout it elf. As for Rain tho' you grant ome Pain, may proceed from a Solution of Continuity; yet you can't agree with thoe that ay, all Pains do: But there are violent Pains where the Union is entire as in a Blow with a blunt thing. Truly Mr. Acid, you are a Man of a blunt Undertanding, for all you have a harp Name, or ele you would eaily perceive, that in any Blow that is painful, there is a violent preure made upon the mall Veels which burts them, and forces the Blood out of them; which is the caue of the Blacknes often following Blows, and there can be no Extravaation without aolution of Unity more or les. So all violent ditentions, all Corroding Matters make Solutions of Unity, breaking ome of the mall Fibers, at which we have the Senation of Pain. But your poitive Aertion, that all Pain is caued by a Stagnation of Humours, and thence a Compreion of the Membranes mut be excued as a fault of a very Treacherous Memory: Some Pains come from Solution of Unity you grant, and yet preently ay you, all Pains proceed from a Compreion of the Membranes. Truely Doctor, I hould be afraid to trut my Life and Health with a Man of uch Brain; I hould be afraid he would forget to morrow, and Precribe contrary to to day's Precription. But I will ask you a Quetion or two, becaue you are very harp at a preent thought. Are there no Pains but in Membranes? And does not a Stagation and Flux of Blood into a Part, caue the Swelling and Ditention of one Part as much as the Compreion of another? And does not Ditenion, as well as Corroding Acrimonious Particles break the Fibers? And are not Wounds both Inci • ions and Punctures in many Parts preently painful, where we can uppoe no preent Stagnation? If you cannot ay no, and new us better Reaon than you have done yet, we hall hardly be of your opinion, That all Pain proceeds from Compreion of Membranes. As for Paralyis, tho' it ounds omething of Solution; yet uppoing you do not much init upon the meer Greek of it, we will deny it
to be a Solution of Continuity, and rather take it to be a Relaxation of the proper and natural Tenion of the Intruments of Motion; but we uppoe Mr. Acid uffer'd a Solution of his Senes, when he aid Paralyticks were altogether voy'd of Senation; for the want of Senation is another thing, the Greeks call it
< in non-Latin alphabet > . As for the Medicines you ue in the Gout, I believe you, that they are few, and well known, and were o before you knew them; but never ued in the manner you ue them: That's with o little Dicretion. For Phyicians ue to conider various Indications, and o give divers kinds of Medicines; but you have no more Indications in your hort and eaie method, than the Quack had, who gave a Gliter for every thing; to the Old Woman for the Tooth-ach, and to the Man that lot his Cow: He was for nothing but dicharging the Excrements of the Belly; you for nothing but Purging the Veins of Alkali, your uppoed Excrement of the Blood. Whether your Medicines be all Acids, as you ay, I hall know when we come to conider them particularly. The clear hints you ay you have given of the Cure of the Gout, eem no clearer to me than what we had before, from your Predeceor Atkins the Taylor, who was famous in his time, as you are now, for Publihing the Wonders of the Gout-Balam, which is a Medicine (if I may call it one) o far from putting no force upon Nature, that it will corrode, bliter and excoriate the Parts, doing nothing but as a Cautick; and what has been done before you were born, by the burning with Moxa. We ee nothing you have done which hath been attempted in vain by others, nor the certainty you brag of Acids Curing the Gout as well as the Cortex doth Agues, or Opium make leep: Your own Obervations you have given us, which doubtles are not the leat of your Cures, Certifie us, that your Patients have been Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven, or more Weeks under your Hand, not only in the Gout, but in meer Feavers even acute ones (if you don't micall them) which is as long or longer than others keep them with Alkalies. So far have you been from hewing us the Wonderful and Atonihing Succes in Curing Feavers you have bragged of. Nay, you have not given us any aurance, that you have Cured any of the Patients you mention, (tho' you ay but two o • three have fail'd) they might have been well as oon, or ooner by a contrary method, or without any Medicines, for ought you know. But a Fit of the Gout being even with a Sowr Doctor a tedious long thing, and when over, the Dieae not Cured; let us dwell upon it no longer, but come to conider ome other Ditemper: What ay you of Conumptions?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I have een numbers of People under this Circumtance, to whom have been given large quantities of Alkalies, and all orts of Balamicks and Pectorals without any advantage; tho' I have een others who have had the manifet igns of a confirm'd Ph • hiis or Conumption, by the plentiful ue of Acids, reduced from a tate of dying, to that of perfect Health. The Englih Conumption is from an Ulceration of the Lungs, and I believe without Vanity I may ay, I have Cured more true Conumptions in the pace of one Year, than any Phyician in England has done. My reaon for the ue of Acids, and diue of Alkalies here, are as follow. The Globules of the Blood by being mixed with a great quantity of Acrid, Alcalous, Lixivial Particles, are broken and confuedly mixed with the Serum, and o admitted with it into the mall Glands of the Lungs, and not being capable of being dicharged caue Inflammations and Hectick Feavers. Now by Alkalies the extravaated Globules are not thrown out, but the Blood made wore, and by Balamicks the Putules from the extravaated Globules are brought to uppuration; whence come Ulceration, and he mut hew himelf an Artit indeed that can heal uch Ulcers. Now proper Acids being given in due time confirm the texture of the Blood, and reduce the Serum into Fluidity; by which the Feaver and Inflammation are taken off; the extravaated Globules by a thin Serum; and the motion of the Part carried off; and o the Putules diappear. But how comes it to pas that the broken Globules are admitted along with the Serum into the Glands of everal Parts, and yet cannot by the ame reaon be carryed off? I Anwer, the broken Globules jut coming out of the extremities of the Arteries are hot, and their ides lax, and o capable of being compreed, but admitted into the Glands; the motion of the Serum being low they oon grow cool and firm, and from the different Figure of thoe broken Globules, from the Pores the Serum paes, they are not uffered to pas; o being without motion they corrupt, whence are the Simptoms. Now to confirm what I have aid, beides my own Obervations, Riverius aith, that with Conerve of Roes acidulated wirh Oyl of Sulphur, he has everal times Cured a confirm'd Phthiis: Aud of Oyl of Sulphur Helmont tells you, that he advied a Man to take two Drops thereof every Meal, and not to exceed that Doe, who thereby lived to Old Age free from Dieaes. By which intance it appears Acids are not the caue of Dieaes, but Preervatives, and what ever is a Preervative from Ditempers, by the ame parity of Reon mut be of ue to repell them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
That you ay, you have een, and done uch, and uch trange things, is very little Ground of our Faith, That it was o. I have heard a Montebank e'er now, that could neither Read nor Write, Boat as great Experience, and promie, That he wou'd Cure thoe, whom all Men in the World had left off, as Incurable From a tate of Dying, to that of perfect Health, is a great Change; epecially to one who has affirm'd, That, none are in perfect Health: But I uppoe, you would have as well aid from a tate of Death, to perfect Health, if you could have hoped for Credence. If you had aid, you had Cured as many of Conumptions, viz. Ulcerations of the Lungs, as any Phyitian in England, uch a Year; you might poibly have been believed: But to ay, you Cured more, implyes, you Cured ome. But you are witnes for your elf Sir. And that an Ulceration of the Lungs, is peculiar to England, is a fancy peculiar to Mr. Acid. And that there are not divers Conumptions, where there is no Ulceration, is his ingle Opinion But as to your Reaon for the ue of Acids, and diue of Alkalies, viz. That the Globules of the Blood are broken, by acrid Alkalous Lixivial Particles, and o admitted into the Glands, with the Serum, and not being capable of being carry'd off with the Serum; growing Cold and hard, caue Inflammations, and being uppurated Ulcerations; is a mere incoherent Fancy: Not being in the leat valid with me, being not confirm'd by well Atteted, or any Experiments. You never aw the broken Globules you talk o of, but in your Wild Imagination, and can't aure us, into what Figures they are evered; how differing from the Pores they cannot pas with the Serum whilt broken thus into leer pieces; but can, when once united again, and confirm'd by Acids. The Putles you fancy in the Lungs, you never made appear, or felt the broken Globules there cold and hard, or heard the Biolychnium (that keeps them lax and oft, or if you pleae, in flux) his, quench'd in the cool extravaated Serum of the Lungs. Beides, you mut uppoe, That this Dieae is till procured by Phyitians, whenever caus'd by means of Lixivial Particles: For as we told you before, there can be no Lixivial Salt in the Blood; it being a product of real, yea, common Fire. And till one wou'd think, That if the Globules of the Blood can be broken by Alkalies, they might be broken till by more into leer Parts, and o pas out by the Diaphoretick power of Alkalies; rather than when confirm'd again by Acids. That Balamicks Caue Suppuration, is contrary to the common Experience of all Phyicians, who know they hinder Corruption. When the Lungs are Ulcerated he mut be an Artit indeed, that can heal uch Ulcers: True, And it's uch a piece of Art, I believe, an Acid Doctor never perform'd, tho' he himelf may Boat uch Cures: 'Tis no uncommon
thing for Quacks, to perwade their Patients, if they have but a Cough, and Spit a little, that they have a Conumption, their Lungs are corrupted, ulcerated, and wated; with as great Confidence as if they could ee through them: When the Patient is well again, a mighty Cure is Brag'd of: And who can then diprove it? but he that ees an impoibility in the thing. That Acids confirm the Texture of the Blood, and make the Serum thin; is o far from Truth, that they do the contrary, as any one may ee by Tryal, and find, That Mr. Acid aies any thing merely for his Hypotheis ake, without the leat Reaon, or Experience. As for Riverius's Curing a confirm'd Phthies with Conerve of Roes Acidulated, the matter is to be quetioned, epecially, whether Oyl of Sulphur were the onely thing ued with benefit; if Riverius ever aid o: For you could not tell us where. And the Man that Helmont advied Oyl of Sulphur to, might have Liv'd as long and healthy, without that trivial thing, as he calls it, for ought you, or Helmont either knew, who charg'd him not to exceed two Drops, being enible of the danger of taking too much of o keen an Acid. Acids, or any thing ele, being uppos'd Preervatives, does not conclude. That they mut be Curatives: For Food. Air, Exercie, Content. &c. are Preervatives; but none will therefore expect to Cure all Dieaes by them. But Mr. Acid is reolved upon the Fancy. That Acids do all Things, confirm the Blood, and make it thin if thick, or thick if thin. or what he pleaes. But how this is done, Mr. Acid mut be Wier than Solomon to tell: But what ay you to Rheumatims?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
This is another Ditemper aid to proceed from Acids, but fally: For here having analiz'd the Blood by the Fire, I have found it abound more with Alkalous Particles, than that of ound Perons, from which alone it may be inferr'd, That it proceeds not from Acids, but from Alkalies. But it may be objected, Whence comes the izynes and vicoity of the Serum, if not from Acids? Every Body that knows what Hart's Horn is, knows that the reaon of its making Gelly, is from its abounding with Volatile Alkalous-Salts: For the ame reaon, Calves-Feet and Iingglas make Gellies. And if the Vicoity of the Blood can be taken off, this Ditemper vanihes: But this is not to be done by Alkalies; but by proper Acids, uch as the foremention'd Tincture of Antimony and Chalybeats. But People will ay, I have caught my elf in a Trap, when I bring Chalybeates in as Acids; when all own them to be Alkalies; inamuch as Fileings of Iron will make as great an Effervecence with all orts of Acids, as any of the Alkalies. From this difficulty, I hall endeavour to extricate my elf, and to prove, That Iron or Steel till it be converted into
Vitriol (and every Body will allow Vitriol to be an Acid) can't act upon the Blood and Serum to caue an alteration, nor any way enter into the Veins and Arteries: Skillful Practitioners before they give Steel-Medicines, ask their Patients, Whether they have any Acidity in their Stomachs (where I allow Acids ometimes abound exorbitantly) and if they are enible of any Acidity there; then they give Iron without any Preparation, which by the Acid in the Stomach, is turn'd into Vitriol, and o made capable of being carry'd into the Blood: Whereas had it been before atiated by Preparation, it had had no Effect at all: If there be no Acidity in the Stomach, it is carry'd off by Stool, and not admitted into the Blood. And mot of the Preparations of Steel, I know of, good for any thing, are made by Acids, which turn it into Vitriol: But Alkalies do o lock up the Body of Iron, as to make it unfit to be taken as a Medicine. The Preparations of Mars I generally ue, are that which goes by the Name of Doctor Willis, and that which follows, R. Fileings of Mars lbis. al Armoniack, lbij. pulverie and mix in an Iron-Mortar, let it tand a Week in a Cellar, then put it into a Crucible and keep it almot Red Hot an Hour, when cold make it into fine Powder, and keep it in a Glas-Bottle. Thee Medicines I have known of great ue in Rheumatimes, and the lat has never fail'd me in the mot inveterate Ob • ructions of the Menes: Father, in anwer to the Objection, That Steel can't be an Acid, becaue it makes an Effervecence with Acids: I ay, all Sulphurs mix'd with Acids, will caue an Effervecence and ome of them take Eire: And that all Metals are full of Sulphurs is pat Dipute; and from this way of arguing, Sulphur mut be an Alkali. But beides the Preparations of Steel, I have oft ued Cinnaber of Antimony, or common Cinnaber with good Succes, mix'd with Gum Guajacum in confirm'd Rheumatimes and Sciaticaes. I did believe Cinnaber to be an Alkali, but I find by a peculiar management, a large quantity of Acid Spirit may be got from it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
As to your Aertion, That the Blood of Rheumaticks, in Analizeing it is found to abound more with Alkali than that of Sound Perons, I have anwer'd you before. I hall only add your own Confeion about Analizeing the Blood, That it wou'd be almot inpoble for any private Man to make a ufficient number of Experiments requiite. And we find in the Experiments you have favour'd the World with, you have Analiz'd the Blood of but one Healthy Peron, when you ought to have try'd rather an Hundred Sound Peron's Bloods firt, and have een the difference of their Products, and have made your Tryals in large and equal quantities, and not uch little odd parcels as you have done; if you would be at any certainty. As for your Reaon of the Vicoity of the Blood
in Rheumatimes: I Anwer, Every Body that knows what volatile Alkalies are, knows, That they have not only nothing of Vicoity in them themelves, but alo render the Blood and Serum thin. And you make a mighty noie, how Alkalies break the Globules of the Blood; but if you had any Conideration, you wou'd not think, diviion into maller Parts, is the way to thicken. But perhaps Alkali is uch a bad thing as to thicken, and make thin both, according as there may be Michief done: Being the Detroyer or Executioner of all things, has more ways of Killing than one; As Acids will thicken and make thin, when you wou'd have them. But as for Hart's-Horn, Iing-glas, Calves-Feer, if it be from Alkalies that they make Gellies: Why, don't other Animal Subtances abounding as much, and more with Alkali make Gellies as well as thee? And why do Vegitables (that you ay abound mot with Acids) make Gellies, as well as Hart's-Horn, &c. as we ee in Mallow-Roots, Comfrey, Quince-Seeds, &c. The Vicoity of the Blood is to be taken off by proper Acids, you ay: But I have aid enough already of the contrary Effects of Acids, to hew your Mitake in this Opinion, and Ignorance in relation to your Tincture of Antimony: But as for Chalybeats, People may well ay you have caught your elf in a Trap, by bringing in Chalybeats as Acids; for every Phyician knows, That Metals, epecially Iron, blunt and Abord Acids making an Effervecence with them, and are diolv'd by them. But let us ee how you get out of this Trap? Why Iron ay you (as you told us once before) can't act upon the Blood and Serum, nor enter the Veins and Arteries, till turn'd into Vitriol. How prove you this Sir, that Iron won't be admitted into the Blood till turn'd into Vitriol, and that it will then? It is only becaue you fancy o, for you have never hew'd us by any good Experiment, that Iron either unprepared, or turned into Vitriol will pas into the Blood. But if your queemih temper would have uffer'd you to meddle with the Subject, you might have took a T—d, and a like quantity of Blood from ome of your Patients under a Steel-coure: Firt of unprepared Iron, then of Iron prepared with ome of your Noble Acid Mentruums; from one of a owr Stomach; from another without a owr Stomach, and have got ome body that knows how to reduce Mettals to ait you (your wonderous Friend Mr. Stringer, ure would not have denied his help) and when you had een which way the Iron goes, you might have been confidently poitive, or modetly ilent, or have been convinced that Phyicians do not give Iron uppoing it will pas into the Blood, but to aborb Acids in the Stomach and Bowels, and to hinder them from paing into the Blood, which if they were z
turned into Vitriol by owr Stomachs (which I believe has not been proved) and o necearily carried into the Blood, and could act there as Acids, would frutrate the Phyicians intention, who only aimes at cutting off a upply of Acid from the Stomach the grand Officine thereof. But uppoe Iron either unprepared, or turned into Vitriol, will or will not pas into the Blood, What's this towards proving Iron an Acid? Why Iron may be turned into Vitriol by an Acid? Tarbox, Iron is an Acid: Here's Logick for you Sirs: Or, the Acid in Vitriol is an Acid, therefore the Alkali in Vitriol is an Acid. You might as well ay, the Volatile Salt of Urine is an Acid, becaue the Spirit of Salt which is embodied, and coagulated with it in Sal Armoniack while eparate was an Acid. But ay you, every Body allows Vitriol the whole Compound to be an Acid; and therefore you infer, that Iron one of the Ingredients is an Acid. I Anwer, Neither is the Premis alow'd, nor your Conequence Natural. I deny Vitriol the whole Compound to be an Acid, it being but a Neuter, and the Acid in it never acts as an Acid in this form; being aborb'd, heath'd, and poil'd of its Acid force (the Compound being but a Salum) till eparated again, which cannot be but by a Fire great enough to calcine an A-eyed Chymit's Bones. As for your Argument, That Steel may be an Acid, tho' it makes an effervecence with Acids; becaue all Sulphurs mixed with Acids will do the like: I ay, that all but Ignorant Tyros know the contrary; that no Sulphurs properly o call'd, viz. Brimtones will make an effervecence with Acids, or be eaily touched by them. Some Oyls indeed will grow hot, and make an effervecence with ome Acids even to a Flame, but not all with all, as is well known. But as for Metals. I tell you, you never aw a Brimtone, much les an Oyl extracted, or eparated from them in your Life; tho' 'tis pat dipute with you, and o we need not argue Sulphur to be an Alkali: But we cannot think it an Acid unles we deny our Senes, much les are thoe Oyls that will grow hot with Acids to be thought o. But I think you have caught your elf in another Trap, by allowing Acids ometimes to abound exorbitantly in the Stomach, which exorbitant abundance of Acids mut be uppoed a Diorder or Dieae (as you elewhere confeed) as well as exorbitant Alkali, and o all Dieaes are not from too much Alkali. But I believe there is never more exorbitant Acid in the Stomach or any where ele, than in the Patient, who is o unhappy as to fall into the hands of Mr. Acid, who tho' he acknowledges The Heart-burn caued by Acids, yet aborbents are far from being ueful in this cae, ays he, but the Heart-burn is as often cured by Acids; uch as Oyl of Vitriol Dulc. &c. as by Alkalies.
Here's that which hangs together finely All Dieaes are caued by Alkalies, yet ome by Acids as the Heart-burn, and too much fatnes; yet Alkalies are far from being uefull, but the Heart-burn is as often Cured by Acids, uch as Oyl of Vitriol, as by Alkalies; that is not oftener than by Alkalies which Cure it ometimes, tho' they are far from being ueful: So in this Dieae, if you come to Mr. Acid, you mut be Cured by that which does it no oftner than that which is far from being ueful. Truely every rational Man will think Acids o far from being ueful to Cure a Dieae from too much Acidity, that he will account it no les than Ignem oleo extinguere. Wo be to your Patients, Here Sir you will make the Biolychnium Blaze. But truely, I mut tell you, Thee Contradictions can't be the faults of a Treacherous Memory, but rather the want of Wit. Well, as to Mars, again all the preparations of it you know good for any thing are made by Acids. That may be I confes, if the Petle and Mortar are Acid Mentruums; but I tell you John I know good Preparations of Mars not made by Acids, and yet the Body of Mars open'd more than by any of your great Acid Mentruums. But if no preparations of Mars were good for any thing but thoe made with Acids, why do you ue others, and o trap your elf again? That which you give us the proces of is not made by an Acid; Sal Armoniack being no uch thing, but a Compoition of Sea-Salt and Volatile Alkali of Urine; the Sea-Salt it elf being no Acid while in this form, or till altered by a trong Fire. You have ometime confeed, that ome Preparations of Steel and Antimony given as Alkalies, did you great ervice; but ince you have well examined them, you find them mot Noble Acids. Sure your Tryals have been very unhapy to lead you into Mitakes, or you have forgot your Rule, That whatoever in Ditillation yields a greater quantity of Alkali, is an Alkali, et Vice Vera; or I believe, it wou'd not do here; for you may Ditill Steel, and Twenty things more, long enough before you can get either Acid or Alkali to come over: Nor could you prove by this Rule, That Cinnaber is an Acid, which you o mightily commend in this, and other Caes, and ay you, can peak Ten times more than Hoffman in its Praies; tho' he Wrote a Treatie of it, which I believe you can a Hundred times more, but your Credit will be a Hundred times les. But I mut tell you, That Cinnaber is o far from being an Acid, that if Analiz'd a lb will yield xiij, or more of running Mercury, one of the greatet Aborbers of Acids in the World, and the ret, viz. the Sulphur, is not an Acid; but a Compound of an Acid and an Oyl; whereby it is o heath'd and entangl'd, that it can't act as an Acid, nor be et at liberty o to do, but by a burning
Fire, You never found a larger quantity of Acid got from Cinnaber, than what may be got from the Sulphur that goes into the Compound, which is o much les than the Mercury. And now John, conidering your continuing Ignorance of the Medicines you ue, I think I may ay truly of you, as you ay fally of all Phyicians; if you Cure Dieaes it is by chance, as a blind Man may catch a Hare, giving ome tolerable Medicines as Acids, when indeed they are Alkalies; eeming uncapable to judg, or make fair Tryals; ince your Brain is turn'd in the Production of your owr Hypotheis, and the Idea of Acid o trongly fix'd in your Imagination (like a true Bethlehemite) whatever is good is Acid, and whatever is bad is Alkali with you: Your Tongue o trongly impregnated by all orts of Sowrs, no Alkalies are trong enough to over-power them, and give you their genuine Tates. And I don't quetion if you let me know farther of the Medicine you precribe, and let Men in their Senes be Judges, I hall find you mitaken in other things beides Mars and Cinnaber, and hall be forced to reckon you with one of thee two Quacks, he that gave every Patient the Receipt that came uppermot in his Budget, wihing him good Luck; or he that made uch a horrid noie againt Mercury, Cure without Mercury, great is the Danger of Mercury, &c. when he himelf. gave even crude Mercury in his Pills, envying (as it is like) other Perons the profit of ueing it. Here's Fool and Knave, Which will you be for John? Do you Ignorantly precribe Acids or Alkalies, as they happen to lie uppermot in your owr Noddle? Or, do you decry Alkalies with a Deign if poible, to have the ole ue of them. For really if you can perwade me out of Conceit with Alkalies, I hall never ue Mars, Cinnaber, nor a great many other things you precibe.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I confes, I have formerly been a tickler for Alkalies (being carry'd away by the common Vogue) and eeing the inufficiency of common ones, have been at great Expence, and vat Trouble to Volatize Salt of Tartar, till at lat by Daily Obervations, I was atifyed that Alkalies tho' ne'er o exalted, would do me very little, if any ervice in the Cure of Dieaes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Then I find you were always inclinable to be a Stickler for one thing or other, Firt for Alkalies then for Acids: And what will you tickle for next? For I believe, you will go near to meet with the condition of your promied Recantation, and you mut tickle: Well, but you quickly left tickling for common Alkalies; I wih you had tay'd, and not tickl'd againt all Alkalies, till you had made ome Tryals with Volatile Salt of Tartar, which is o much commended by the Chymits. Your Mater Helmont (to
name no little Men to you) commends it, and all fix'd Salts Volatiliz'd, at a great Rate, Pag. 386. Fixa Alkalia i volatizentur Magnorum Pharmacorum potetates adaequent—Quippe vi incii •• is, reolutionis, & abterionis delata uque ad limen quartae digetionis, tenacitatem coagulatorum in vaibus fundamentaliter tollunt. And 'tis pity you were at o vat Trouble and great Expence to no purpoe. But at lat by Dayly Obervations you were atisfy'd the mot exalted Alkalies wou'd do you little, or no ervice in the Cure of Dieaes. This is very fine, that you could make Daily Obervavations, of the inufficiency of thoe things you never aw, nor knew ued. The fix'd Salt of Tartar Volatilized, is not the onely Volatile Alkali you never aw, but there other Noble Volatile Alkalies you never heard nor dream'd of, much les can imagine, what can be done by them: I will undertake to oppoe one to all your Acids: For intance, The Quintecence of Wine, you hall ue nothing but Acids, I nothing but this; and if I don't do mot Cures, you hall be my Mater, and I will become an Acid Diciple. But pray you Sir, let us have a little farther account of what things you take to be Acids, and what Alkalies; for you have aid, an exact knowledge of the Materia Medica, is an abolutely neceary Qualification for a Phyician, and that you hou'd be unwilling on any occaion, to precribe a Medicine the manner of whoe Opperation you are unable to give an account f • r, which I have a hrew'd gues you have always done.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: almot all the Products of the Vegetable and Mineral Kingdoms are Acids, and there are manifet Acids, and occult ones; ome work by Stool, others by Urine; ome Diureticks, others Diaphoreticks; ome Emeticks, and others are Alteratives; having no viible enible Operation. I may without Preumption, reckon all orts of Balams Pinguedinous and Oleous Subtances among the number of Acids; by Reaon that in the mot bare, and imple Ditillation, they afford large quantities of Acid Subtances; nothing that is Alkalous. Bread the taff of Life, by Ditillation yields a large quantity of Acid: Sugar tho' in Tate it eems nothing les, by a Philoophical Management appears nothing ele, but a Congetion of Acid Particles. All Mettaline Sulphurs are to be rang'd amongt the number of Acids, being nothing but a Congetion of Acid Particles.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
If almot all the Products of the Vegetable and Mineral Kingdoms are Acids, we need not care what we give, we can't mis giving Acids. But what will you do for your Five Principles, I doubt they will be o occult that you can never find them: But your occult Acids that have no viible enible Operation, will be found to have no viible or enible Effects, as Acids; and o will
never appear to be Acids. Thoe divers Operations you acribe to Acids, are not the Effects of Acidity: You never aw an Acid Vomit or Purge, but you mut be beholden to ome Particles of another Nature, to whom thoe Effects are to be attributed. To ay uch an Acid Purges, uch another Vomits; is as profound Philoophy, as to ay, uch a Bottle of Sack Purges, uch another Vomits, when it is the Particles of Gallap in one, of Antimony in the other, that does the Buines. As for Balams (which you dicommended, peaking of Conumptions) • inquedinous and Oleous Subtances, I will excue your Preumption, for it is from Ignorance you ay they are Acids: Every Chymit knows, That they yield by Ditillation ome none, others, but very little Acid, but the greatet part of them is Oyl. Tho' Bread the Staff of Life Ditilled, yields a great deal of Acid, which may be of ue in ome Operations, its more grateful to the Stomach when it comes only from the Oven, than when its drawn from the Re • ort, which makes it a Sword of Detruction, rather than a Staff of Life, if taken inwardly: However Sugar by Ditillation, or Fermentation, may be brought to an Acidity by uch a Phyloopher as you; yet I can hew you by a more Phyloophical way than any you ever walk'd in, how to make either a fix'd or a volatile Alkali of it, and as trong ones as ever you aw. But you mut burn your Fingers at common Chymitry a little if you will be a Chymit; before its fit to teach you any thing Uncommon: Sulphurs I have told you, are eparable into an Acid and an Oyl, and o can't be nothing but a Congetion of Acid Particles, and Oyls are far from being Acids. But whether there are any Sulphurs of Metals, or what thoe dogged Bodies conit of, or how they differ, I dare afirm has hitherto been occult, and out of the ken of any As-Ey'd Pretender in England.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I could rang my elf into the Mineral Kingdom, but the different Operations of them are o well known to every Body, I think it needles to take any particular notice of them; yet thus much I will preume to ay, That after having made all the Enquiry into the Nature of Mettals, that Humane Indutry is capable of. I am perfectly atisfy'd that they differ one from another onely in Degree of Purity, and therefore for ought I know, the buines of Tranmutation is not o Ridiculous a Thing as ome would make it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Mow Sir John you have aid all: For if you have made all the Enquiry into the Nature of Mettals, Human Indutry is capable of; and tell us alo that the buines of Tranmutation is not o Ridiculous a Thing as ome make it: We can't do les than believe you have the Phyloopher's Stone, beides all other Mettalline
Arcanums. For the greatet Adept Prince or Potentate, never made more Enquiry into thee things, than Human Indutry is is capable of. But I admire your Boldnes, how you dare o openly dicloe your elf. But ince you have aid o much, I hope you will let us ee Tranmutation, and convince the Unbelievers. But whatever you may perwade us about the Tranmutation of Metals, I doubt we hall never ee Mr. Acid Tranmuted into a Wie and Modet Man, that's contrary to the Nature of his Compoition. And tho' you tell us the different Operation of Metals is o well known to every Body: I tell you there are carce Six Men in England that know o much of Mettals, as to reduce them dexterouly out of their Oars, and perhaps not two (etting aide your elf) that know any thing of making a true Medicine of thee Bodies. But Sir, if you have uch a large Knowledg, poibly you may have the Alkahet too, and when you talk of Alkalies being o univeral a Detroyer, you make us fancy it may be made of that; but like a Cunning Adept, to hide from us the ubject Matter: You every where diwade from medling with Alkali, but you wou'd do well to be o kind as to undeceive us poor Seekers.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: The Alkahet that univeral diolvent, is a thing has made a very great noie in the World, and tho' many People have been at vat Charge in quet of it, yet I have carce met with any one (except one Peron) in our time, who has been Mater of it: but upon ome late Experiments made upon the Pyrites, I am perfectly atisfy'd the aid Noble Mentruum is with very little Trouble and Charge to be obtain'd, from this o Common, yet mot Valueable Subject! I have already procur'd a Mentruum from it, that will readily diolve all the Metals and Minerals I have met with, but the utmot Extent of it I do not know; but as oon as I do, the World hall have an Account of it. I have mention'd this for the ake of ome honet Virtuoi, who will be very glad to be inform'd of the Subject from whence this Noble Mentruum is to be obtain'd. I have reerv'd but one Secret in my Book Of the Gout, and that is a Medicine obtain'd from the Pyrites; and to all thoe that will but give themelves the trouble of nicely enquiring into the aid Stone (which to me eems one of the greatet Myteries in Nature) the aid Secret will very eaily be Dicover'd.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Good News for poor Chymits! But thanks to the Honet Virtuoi The Alkahet is to be had with very little Trouble and Charge from the Mytical Pyrites. Mr. Acid has got a Mentruum already from it will Diolve all the Metals and Minerals he has met with, if you will believe him: (But I dare lay a Wager againt it.) And a Secret for the Gout, which we may eaily Dicover by a little nice Enquiry. Doubtles this Noble Mentruum
and the Alkahet alo, are Acids, for all the Noble Mentruums he knows are Acids in the Three Kingdoms. But thus Acid will be the
niveral Detroyer of Bodies, being the Univeral Diolvent. But pray you Sir, are there no Alkalies in the Mineral Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Arenick is the highet, and mot exalted Alkali, as Oyl of Vitriol is the mot exalted Acid. As for the external ue of Arenick. I know nothing experimentally, but being a thing of pernicious conequence inwardly taken, I uppoe it can have no very friendly operation externally apply'd. Internally taken, it caueth Vomitings, Convulions of the Stomach, cold Sweats, Palpitations of the Heart, Swoonings, violent Thirt; and eems to be a direct enemy to Life; which it fails not oon to detroy: All which Effects it will not fail to have, given in never o mall a quantity. And thoe People who have been o vain, as to pretend to correct the poyonous quality of Arenick, o as to convert it into a good, and afe Medicine; have attempted it only by the means of Acid Salts: as Sea-alt, Niter, Tartar, Vitriol, &c. wherein I cannot tell whether any man has been o happy as to ucceed. To prove Arenick to be an Alkali, and as uch the caue of thoe dreadful Symptoms attending thoe that take it; I give you this Relation. A certain Young-woman taking a large quantity of Arenick, was immediately attended with all the mot violent Symptoms imaginable: A Doctor gave her large quantities of Salad-oyl, the uual Remedy, without the leat abating the Symptoms; upon which he gave her the Juice of Lemons plentifully, which oon took off thoe direful Symptoms; tho the operation of the Acid might be impeded by the quantity of the Oyl he had taken before.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
What you mean by exalted Alkalies, or Acids, I don't know, unles mot volatile, or mot trong. But as for Arenick, it is far from being the mot volatile or tronget Alkali; neither is Oyl of Vitriol the mot volatile or tronget Acid. But whatever Arenick is, it will not produce its effects in the mallet quantity, having been given as a Medicine, a grain or two in ome caes. Neither have all thoe People who you ay have been o vain as to attempt to correct it, done it by Acid Salts. For I my elf have a Medicine from it, wherein is not a grain of any kind of Salt, which I can give to the quantity of a cruple, or more, to good purpoe, in ome caes; giving Nature no uch diturbance as is common in the ue of many vulgar Medicines. And outwardly I have ued Preparations of it, doing in ome caes what I could never do with any thing ele; never eeing any ill effects of it. But that Arenick is an Alkali, and produces its evil effects as uch, is but your Fancy, not knowing what it is. Your Argument to prove it an Alkali, is uch a light one as you uually give for other things. A Peron
took Arenick, and was not preently cured by taking Oyl, but as by taking Juice of Lemons, I anwer; the thing to be done
<> this cae was, to get the Arenick out of the Body as oon as po
•• ble; and till that could be done, to hinder its operation upon the coat of the Stomach; to both which intents Oyl was proper: and when the Arenick was vomited all up (if timely done) then
<> Symptoms would ceae. Now the dicharge of the Arenick,
• nd defence of the Stomach, mut in all reaon be attributed to
• he Oyl, not to the Juice of Lemons, which was given upon it;
<> having no power to work upon, or alter the corroive nature of Arenick, which is a body that makes no effervecence with Acids,
• or does it turn Syrup of Violets green (the ways you try Alkalies by) but is a very ulphurous Mineral, and Sulphurs conit
•• rtly of an Acid, which may be eparated from the Arenick; and certainly that which contains an Acid, and has none of the igns of an Alkali, cannot be the tronget, or mot volatile Alkali. But Alkali being fix'd upon in your Hypotheis for the Principle of Death, and Arenick producing uch mortal effects, you preently concluded it an Alkali. And were you not reolved that whatever is good mut be an Acid, and whatever is bad an Alkali; you could not be o ignorant of the nature of things, and o contradict your own Principles as you do, in almot all your Precriptions, giving Alkalies, Aborbents, or other Mitigators of Acids. For intance, Steel and Cinnaber before mention'd, Lapis haematitis, which is a Mineral of Iron, from which you never got a grain of Acid, yet you highly commend it, and give it not firt turn'd into Vitriol, Antimonium diaphoreticum, [that is, Antimony and Niter fix'd together, and it is well known that Niter with all ulphurous Bodies, is turn'd into a fix'd Alkali, ome of which Alkali remains in the fix'd Powder of Antimony, notwithtanding the lotions.] Cochinel, an Animal, abounding with Volatile Salt. Vinous Spirits, Aromatick Oyls, and divers other things, which will much take off the edge, if not wholly blunt yuur Acids. You cry out againt the naueous Tribe of Alexipharmacks, which you ay are very rarely of any other ue than to end the Patient to his long-home; and yet precribe Theriaca, Androm. Diacord. Confect. de Hyacinth. Aq. Theriacalis, Epidem. Lactis Alex. Cinnam. Mirab. &c. all orts of Aromaticks. So that I profes, if you had not declar'd your elf an Acid Doctor, I hould hardly have melt you out by the Precripts you have publihed. And I uppoe you have given us thoe that you think will do your Caue the mot credit. Yea, I remember you have commended as an admirable Remedy, and the next thing to your Balam, in the Gout, a L • xivium (as you call it) of Cows-rine and Sea-Salt; when every body knows rine is full of Volatile Alkalous Salt: and Sea-Salt it elf, in its natural form, has not the effects of an Acid.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
It is, I uppoe, allow'd by all, that Sea-Salt is an Acid For which caue, we that eat Fleh can't live without it: For Fleh abounding with Alkalous Salts, they are in a meaure lock'd up by Sea-Salt. And People who lived before the Flood, 'tis to be believed, did not eat Fleh, but liv'd upon Vegetables; which, I uppoe, was one great reaon of their long Lives: If they ha •
eat Fleh as we do, I can't imagine what they would have done for Salt. For uppoing Dr. Burnet's Hypotheis true, which I ee no reaon to doubt of, I uppoe their Rivers mut have been void of Saltnes; and for them to have eaten Meat without Salt, mut have prejudic'd their Healths, and hortned their Lives. As we aw in the Irih Wars, by eating Meat without Salt, whole Regiments were wept away by Fevers and Fluxes. Now the Antidiluvians eating Vegetables, had no need of Salt; there being a ufficient quantity of Acidity in them to confirm the texture of their Blood. Farther note the efficacy of Salt-water, to prevent the dreadful Symptoms of perons bitten with mad Dogs. On which occaion alo, a Child at Worceter was cur'd of a Tympanitis by being dipt with others, alo bitten by a mad Dog; who not many hours after he was dipt, pis'd everal Quarts, and was perfectly cured. And a Peron in Herefordhire, I am told, has cured everal by the ame method. Common Salt, I allow, will excite Thirt not quatenus Acid; for Spirit of Salt will take it off: But I aure you, I have tumbled more at this thing of Common Salt's exciting Thirt, than any thing ele beides, and therefore have par'd no Cot to find the Reaon; but at lat, after much Labour and Sweat, I found there was no Salt but had more or les of a damn'd thing call'd Bittern mix'd with it. Now this Bittern is the mot corroding fix'd Alkali in nature; and tho it be inconiderable in quantity, in repect of the Acid, yet it will fix it elf on the Parts after the Acid of the Salt is all diolved, and o excite Thirt.

sp.speaker: Alk.
sp.p:
It is o far from being allow'd by all, that Sea-Salt is an Acid, that I know none that can tate will allow it, except you Mr. Acid, who are either reolved to deny your Senes to erve your Hypothetick Fancy, or have o us'd your Mouth to Acids, you can tate nothing ele; as Perons in ome Ditempers tate every thing bitter. But let the healthy Country-man tate it, and I will engage he will not ay 'tis owr. That it may be by the Fire changed into a owr Liquor, is no better an Argument, that it is now owr than that Sugar, becaue it may be turn'd into Vinegar, is Vinegar; or into an Alkali, is an Alkali already; or that an As-ey'd Doctor is a wie man, becaue poibly he may learn Wit. It is not true, that thoe that eat Fleh can't live without Salt: for not only divers kinds of Animals that live wholly on Fleh eat no Salt, but abundance of People in North-America, who live
very healthy, and trong, and motly upon Fleh, have no Salt a tall; as Hennipen tells us in his late account of thoe Parts, and I don't quetion but we might do the ame were we accutom'd to it, without hurting our elves by Alkali. Neither do we ue Salt to lock up Alkali in Fleh, which it will not do; Sea-Salt no way uniting with, or retaining volatile Alkalies, except it is firt turn'd into on Acid Spirit; as you may eaily ee, either by ditilling Salt-meat, rine, or Sea-Salt, and a volatile Alkali mix'd together. But we ue Salt to preerve and relih our Meat, neither of which would be done by its Acid Spirit. Nor can the Longevity of the Antediluvians be acrib'd to their living upon Vegetables, much les from an Acid in them, when all Vegetables that are commonly eaten turn into an Alkalous Chyle. And if living upon Vegetables would o much conduce to long Life, why have not ome in our time, who would eat nothing ele, lived longer, or at leat more healthy, than others? And tho you, not doubting of Burnet's Hypotheis, can't imagine what they would have done for Salt before the Flood, yet I and others, not doubting of Moes's Hypotheis, can very well imagine, That they might have had Salt to relih divers orts of Vegetables, as well as for other ues, from the Sea, from Fountains, or from the Rock the original of that ueful Body. As for the Cure of Perons bit by mad Dogs, by dipping; it cannot be well thought to depend upon the Saltnes of the Water, much les on the uppoed Acidity of the Salt: If it did, why would not the drinking Salt-water, or Spirit of Salt, or wahing with them, rather do the Cure; which has not been found effectual. But the reaon of this, is more rationally thought to lie in the blotting out and detroying, or preventing the Idea of Rage, by the contrary Idea of Fear impres'd upon the Spirits of the Perons bit. Which is apparent from the manner of dipping, as I have had the Account from Perons dip'd; which is till the Peron has an apprehenion or fear of being drowned: Therefore they dip ome twice, ome thrice, more or les, as they find them fearful, or courageous. On the ame account, dipping might provoke Urine, and o do omething towards curing the Dropy. And I believe the inducing a contrary Idea, would be a more effectual way of curing other orts of Madnes, than any of the common Methods; if Phyicians would give themelves to conider of, and put in practice the everal ways, and means by which it might be done. I agree with you, That Salt does not excite Thirt quatenus Acid; becaue that would be to do it quatenus what it is not; neither does it do it quatenus Alkali. And tho it has cot you o much Money and Sweat, to reolve this tumbling Quetion, you mut tumble, and Sweat again, or remain under a Mitake. For the Damn'd thing Bittern (to repeat your Beauih Expreion) is
not where, and what you uppoe it: Firt it is not in all Salt; for it is that which will not hoot with the Salt into regular Grains, and if Boyl'd up, will not continue in a dry Form, but runs into a Liquour in the open Air. Therefore that Salt that is hot into its proper Chrytals and keeps dry, has no Bittern. But if this won't do, Ditill your Salt into an Acid Spirit, and then you will be atisfy'd there is no fix'd Alkali in it: Turn this Spirit into Salt again, the ame in quantity and Quality (as every Chymit knows how) and this Salt hall make you as Thirty, as any other Common Salt. Secondly Bittern it elf is not the mot corroding fix'd.-Alkali in Nature, for tho' it will turn Syrup of Violets Green (as Allum alo doth) more readily than Common-Salt; yet it is not corroding as an Alkali, as any one may Try by Tating it, and the mildet fix'd Alkali, and they will find a difference, much more between this and the mot Corroding ones: Nor is it a fix'd Alkali, for it will rie in the Fire, and come over good Spirit of Salt, even per • e without any addition of Earth, leaving nothing behind but a white inipid Earth, which will not o much as make an Effervecence with Acids; Neither will Bittern fix it elf on the Parts after the Salt is diolved, for it's diolved much ooner than Salt it elf. Thus you ee Sir, by a little Skill in Chymitry your Damn'd fix'd Alkali is become a Bleed Volatile Acid. But Bittern in its Natural Form jut Boyl'd up into a dry Form is but a Salum, not fermenting with Acids much more than Common-Salt will, and may be taken in as large a quantity as Common-Salt, producing no more Thirt than that does.
