But you are uch a Slave to your Hypotheis, that every ill Effect mut needs be attributed to an Alkali, even as far as to make Poyons Mortiferous merely as Alkalies; as you have Aerted in Arenick. And I hear, alo you have the ame Opinion in Animal Poyons, as that of the Viper, which if it be an Alkali, and therefore a Poyon, I hou'd think, a far more exalted one than Arenick, and Damn'd one than Bittern, performing its violent Effects in far les quantity. What ay you is it your Opinion?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
Yes, And for a farther Confirmation of my Doctrine of Acids, you have the Cure of one Mr. Phillipon, that hew'd a Collection of Rarities, who was Bitten by a Viper, and Cured in a few Days by Acids: Which Cure, conidering the Symptoms (which were as evere as poible) I may without vanity ay, There has not been a more Extraordinary Cure wrought in o hort a time. Now if the Poyon of the Viper did conit in a volatile Acid, as ome wou'd make us believe, How is it poible the Symptoms could be taken off by giving Acids, and that in uch large quantities? Nay, had it been Acid, it's reaonable to think the Symptoms would have been Aggravated. So in a Relation Dr. Stubbs gives a Peron
Bitten by an Adder, was Cured by the Mixtura iimplex a Noble Acid. And Lemery in his Coure of Chymitry, confees, That the Viper does more abound with Volatile (Alkalous) Salts, than mot other Creatures; by reaon of the cloenes of the Cutaneous Pores hindering Prepiration, and that their Poyon conits in an Emiion of a very great quantity of Volatile-Salts at the time of their being enrag'd. But then to quare with the Vulgar Opinion, he tells us, Thoe Volatile Alkalous Salts are intantaneouly at the time of their Emiion, during the time of the Viper's hort Rage, turn'd into Acids of the mot Volatile Nature; which is uch Jargon, the Tranmutation of Metals to thoe that are its greatet Enemies, is a Jet to it. Charas alo gives us an Account of a German Bitten at his Houe, who after all the pother that he makes about his Volatile Salt of Vipers, was Cured not without great Hazard and Trouble, by the intermixture of many other Medicines and thoe even Acids, as Treacle-Water, Citrons; but thoe Acids could not be o effectual, by reaon of the Alkalies given him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
The Recovery of Mr. Phillipon was not o peedy, nor what you did towards it o apparently Effectual, as to give you jut occaion to Brag of o great a Cure: Nay, you cannot certainly prove to your elf, or others, That what you did, did the Cure, and that other things did nothing towards it; yea, or that he would not have been well as oon, or ooner without any of your Acids. The Patient himelf aid, He could not tell whether he had any benefit by what you gave him. But I am ure, had he had ome more proper Things, or even the Viper-Man for his Doctor, he might have been well ooner than he was. But let us uppoe the bet we can of what you did, and take what you borrow from Dr. Stubbs, and Charas together; you do not make an Argument out of all ufficient to make a Coniderate Man believe, that the Poyon of Vipers conits in an Alkali. Suppoe you did do the Man ome little good, and Dr. Stubb's Mixtura implex were an Acid (which if it were that of Paracelus, I deny, being but a Salum) and Charas's Alkalies, were not o oon Effectual on the German; but wanting Patience and larger Does, they gave ome Acids, I ay uppoe that the Acids did ome good, it will not follow, That the Venom of Vipers is an Alkali. For if an Acid has done ome things towards the Cure of the Bite, in one or two Caes, you can't deny but that Alkalies have done it in many. For tho' in ome Caes Acids were ued, they were not ued alone, and o could not certainly demand the Credit of the Cure. But you have many Caes, where the Volatile Salt ued without Acids Cured. Can it be uppos'd Volatile Alkali Salts did the Cure, if the Poyon were nothing but a Volatile Alkali? Or, did you ever ee any Volatile Alkali in o little (yea or in a large) quantity,
put into a Wound, and produce uch dire Effects? No, the Infuion of Volatile Alkali in an Hundred times the quantity into the Veins will not do it, or o much as caue a Diorder. Can the Poyon of Vipers conit in a Volatile Alkali, and their whole Body abound therewith, and yet their Fleh be wholome Food? No urely. Can the Poyon of Vipers conit in an Alkali, and yet be Cured by an Alkali? And that even by an outward Application: As I my elf have een in the following Experiments I ome Years ago was Aitant in the making of, at the Honourable Mr. Boyle's, which were made upon Pullets and Pigeons, thus We pluck'd the Feathers off the Breat of one of them, and taking a Viper when he was enrag'd, we caued him to Bite; letting the Fowl go, he Dy'd in three or four Hours. Then we took anoher and caus'd him to be Bitten in like manner, by an enraged Viper, and apply'd the Viper-Stone to the Wound, which not only prevented Death, but all the dire Sypmtoms the other Fowl Dy'd with; which Stone being taken off after ome time, the Wound was Healed by ordinary means. Now this Stone is an Arid-Body, making an Effervecence with Acids, which could not have uch great Effects in the Biting of Vipers, if the Poyon were an Alkali, and to be detroy'd by an Acid. But tho' the Poyon of the Viper can't Rationally be thought to be an Alkali; yet neither do I think this Poyon conits in an Acid. Thoe Perons that have ventured to Tate the Liquor in the Viper's Gums, tell us nothing of any Acidity, or Alkalous Tate, nor give us any Experiments to confirm their Opinion of its being an Acid. Nor do we ee uch Mortal Effects of o mall quantities of either Acid, or Alkali in Wounds. But this Poyon doubtles does conit in omething more ubtil • than any of thee manifet Qualities. The Ingenious Lemery, I confes, is of the Opinion that the Poyon, of the Viper is an Acid; but he (nor no Mortal I believe) has any uch Jargon as you fally accue him of, who is a Man capable of Teaching you Pharmacy this Seven Years yet. To hew how groly you have abued him, I will recite his Words in this matter: I conceive, ays he, what they call the Venom of Vipers, conits only in the abundance of Acid Volatile Salts, which the Animal throws out when it Bites, and thee Salts paing into the Veins and Arteries, coagulate the Blood and hinder its Circulation, and the coure of the Animal Spirits, even as it happens when an Acid Liquor is Syring'd into a Vein, which may be ufficient to explicate all the Accidents which happen upon the Biteing. And afterwards aies he, The difference between the Effects of an Acid Liquor yring'd into the Veins, and thoe of the Venom of Vipers is this, an Acid Liquor being immediaiely infus'd into a large Veel fixes all the Blood of a udden, and caues trong Convulions, which are follow'd hortly
with Death: Whereas the Acid Salts that flow from the Viper when he Bites, do not Work o quickly; their Acidity being probably not o trong as that of an Acid Liquor, and have long paage into the Mas of Blood: And there's one Circumtance, adds he, which makes my Application till more probable, That the bet Remedics ued for uch as are Wounded by Vipers, are thoe that detroy Acids, and diolve the Coagulation of the Blood, as Volatile Alkali-Salts drawn from Animals. But to undertand this more fully, continues he, it's fit to conider everal things, Firt, Vipers are more fill'd with Volatile Salts than other Animals, and o not think it trange that they throw out much of it in their wrath. Secondly, Tho' thee Salts turn Alkalies by Ditillation, they are Acids in their own Nature, before the Fire works upon them, as I have aid when I poke of the Principles. Thirdly, Vipers are covered with a cloe compact Skin; o that the Salts they contain do Circulate and Subtilize much better, and do Evaporate les than other Animals. Fourthly, The hape of the Viper being long, traight, and round, like a mall Gun, the Salts they throw out in the Biting are driven with much more violence, than if they came from a more open place. Fifthly, The two long Teeth of the Viper being traight and harp, make deep Wounds, but which hut up o quickly, the Acid-Salts which enter, have no paage to come out. But it may be Objected farther, aies he, If the Venom of Vipers proceed from their Volatile Salts, then the Salt of Vipers hou'd increae, rather than Cure the Malady. Anwer, Volatile Salts which flow from Living Vipers, and enter the Fleh by the Bite, are very different from thoe drawn by the Fire from Dead ones, which are taken at the Mouth, the firt are Naturally pointed, Acid, and Coaglating; the others have been blunted by the Fire, and rendred Poreous, are Alkalies, very Rarifying, or Diolving, o are qualifyed to break and detroy the firt. Secondly, The Volatile Salt of Vipers taken at the Mouth, has another determination then that which enters the Fleh, and o produces different Effect; not being forc'd in its Motion, preads every where, and diolves the Coagulum the other had made in the Blood. Thus much I have Trancribed, not for the ake of Lemery's Opinion, eeing no ground to believe the Viper abounds with Acid Salts, but out of love to Jutice, that it may be een how the Abuer of all his Betters, has abued this Author in particular. But I have one thing more comes into my Mind to tell you of, Mr. Acid, ince we are Talking of Wounding, which is that I have heard, you have formerly Boated great Things in Chirurgery, and have Wrot a Book call'd Novum Lumen Chirurgieum. What is there in it pray you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p:
There's nothing but Truth contain'd in my Novum Lumen
Chirurgicum, and it's Built upon a pair of Medicines, the one Internal, the other External, which I did not think fit to make publick. But here lies my Misfortune common to all thoe who make new Dicoveries; a great many believe the Truth of what I aid, that my Medicines will perform what I promied; but amongt thoe who believe matter of Fact, many ay, This Man was not the Author, others, that they have the ame Medicines. I very well know it's the Nature of mot Men not to allow any Peron the Honour of his own Dicoveries. But my Medicines are entirely New, and will tand the everet Tet, and I am certain my Medicines will Cure any Wounds, whether in the Fleh, or in the Cavity of the Body: Where as dangerous Wounds were ever Cured by former Applications, and that with much greater peed and afety to the Patient; ince they prevent Feavers, and Mortifications: My Medicines if timely ued, Cure all orts of Wounds without Suppuration, but where Suppura • ion is begun, are the bet Digetives now known. But all Probes and Tents, all Digetive and Suppurating Medicines, all Cauteries and traight Ligatures are Injurious and Procratinate the Cure. To hew wherein lies the unreaonablenes of commo • Methods of Chirurgeons in the Cure of Wounds, wherein they hinder and oppres Nature in her regular Operations, let a Wound be made where it will, and how, whether by Cutting, or Contuion, it matters not, the Nutritious juice is brought immediately to the extremities of the wounded Veels. Now all the Medicines made ue of in the common Methods of Chirurgery relax the divide Fibers, that they can't retain the Nutritious Matter, but let it pas into the Wound, where by the ame Medicines it's turned into the Subtance commoly call'd Matter, and this Corruption can't be without a ort of Fermentation, and the Fermenting Particles fret the Fibers, caue Inflmmations, and by ent'ring the Blood, and dividing its Texture caue Feavers. Now it's evident, whatever will caue Pain uch as will create a Feaver, mut be of a Heterogeneous Nature, and an Enemy to the Body (for I poitively believe it's from the Medicines apply'd, only are occaion'd all thoe ill Symptoms that attend Wounds) to which it's apply'd, or into which it's receiv'd. The truth of which, the nature of a Feaver is ufficient to confirm, which is in the Terms of many great Men nothing but a Nixus Naturae to throw off its Enemy. And a Late Learned Author in a Treatie of Intermitting Feavers, the only Rational Piece in my Opinion that ever was Writ upon that ubject, plainly makes it appear, That the Seat of Agues is in the Cortex of the Brain, from whence at certain Periods of time, the Matter is thrown off by the Nerves to all the Parts of the Body, which caues the coldnes; this Matter afterwards received into the Blood by the Capillary Veins being • erogeneous
to it, puts it into a violent motion, which ceaes not till the matter is thrown off by the Pores. Now after the Chirurgeons have generated Matter (tho' many times intead thereof they caue Mortifications) they then ue mundifying Medicines, and when Nature is oppreed, leave her to do her own work. This is their practice in External Wounds, but what is to be expected where the Lungs, Liver, Guts, &c. are wounded? Here they own their Medicines inufficient, and if any o wounded chance to recover they count it almot miraculous. But I leave it to every Man's judgment which method is bet to be confided in, either that where carce one in ten micarieth as in mine, or where not one in ten recovers as in the Common Method of Chirurgeons: Beides there remains another thing, that is when any large Blood-Veel is wounded how to top the Flux of the Blood which they can't do without actual, or potential Cauteries, whoe inconveniences every body knows; and trict bandage often cauing Mortifications. But the methods I ue are hort and eaie, thus; I make a olution of my Powder in Water, or for want of it in Urine, and queee or inject with a Syring into the Wound if it be deep, then cloe the Wound, and if large, tich it up and lay a Pledget upon it. If any large Artery be cut, I hold the Pledget cloe with my Hand till the Flux of Blood ceaes which will be in a mall time; then bind it on with an eaie ligature, and give my Tincture in Wine. Now to prove my Medicines agreeable to the nature of Humane Bodies, and of that Juice by which I conjecture the Body is nourihed, and more efficacious than the Medicines ued by Chirurgeons, the following Arguments will evince. 1. They never caue Pain unles jut at the Application, and that very little more than would be caued by-Spring Water. 2. No Pain afterterwards. 3. If there has been Pain before, it has been taken off in a hort time. 4. There has never been any Feavers be the Wound external or internal. 5. All incied Wounds are cured if timely ued in a few days time, without Suppuration: Gun-hot Wounds in flehy parts are cured after the ame manner, only require longer time. And by my Medicines mot wounds within the Cavity of the Body may be cured with all the eae imaginable. For Intance Experiment. 1. John Mahulton.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Hold Mr. Acid, let your Experiments alone now, you may tell them to the Phyicians and Chirurgeons that were in Flanders with you, and aw them made. Seeing is believing, they ay: But I who have not een hall hardly believe you did any Miracles, or that all contain'd in your Novum Lumen Chirurgicum is true. Becaue I know your pair of Medicines, not capable to perfom uch Wonders: The very appearance of which Arcanums, is enough to Extinguih your Novum Lumen, Your Tincture
of the Sulphur of Venus, as you fally and foolihly call your Internal Medicine, and your Powder, are not your Invention but Originally Rebel's, I might ay, every Bodies: The one being nothing but Spirit of Roman or Dantzick Vitriol Twelve Parts mix'd with Spirit of Wine Eight Parts: And the other nothing but Roman Vitriol Calcin'd to Whitenes, which you Colour'd with a little Dragon's Blood: And we know how you come by thee Secrets: Thee are the great Medicines you would o fain teal the Honour of being thought the Inventer oft Thee are your fire-new Medicines! The Birth of the Mountains! And leat you hou'd deny this (being given to the faculty) any one that undertands any thing of Chymitry, may know your Tincture (as you call it) if not by Sight and Tate, by bare Ditillation. And as for your Powder, let them Diolve it in Water, the Dragon's-Blood (if you till Colour it) will not Diolve, but may be eparated, and put upon a hot Plate, is known by the Smell: Let them put ome Urinous Spirit to the Powder, it will preently dicover the Copper by its Blew Colour, and every Body knows by the Tate, that it's a Vitriol. And now let People judg, whether a little Roman Vitriol be o trange a Dicovery beyond all hitherto known in Chirurgery? Or whether all Chirurgeons have been ignorant thereof? Whether Vitriol will Cure all Curable Wounds inwardly, and outwardly, with more peed and afety than any thing ele? If it would, there are better Vitriols to be had than this you fally call, your Invention. Whether Copper Corroded by an Acid, with its fretting Atringency be likely to Cure all orts of Wounds without Suppuration, and yet is the bet Digetive in the World. This is like Acids making Thick, Thin, Purging, Vomiting, Binding, Looening, and every thing; becaue it is Acid, and you are in love with it. Roman Vitriol Digets, yet hinders Digetion; but only while a Secret in Mr. Acid's Hand, if you can believe him. All Probes and Tents, all Digetive and Suppurating Medicines. all Cauteries and traight Ligatures, are Injurious and Procratinate the Cure: Yet Mr. Acid's Digetive does not. But I Anwer, Your Digetion-hindering Digetive as well as others, and the ret of the Things you cry out againt, may be Injurious and Procratinate Cure, where Fools or Knaves act intead of Chirurgions: But in the Hands of Experienced Artits, all thee are neceary ometimes; but when, and where, you are not a capable Judg. Let a Wound be made where, and how it matters not, ay you. Here you hew your Ignorance, for Chirurgeons to Laugh at: They well know the place and manner of the Wound, much alters the Indications of Cure. That all the Medicines made ue of in the common Methods
of Chirurgery, relax the Fibers, and turn the Nutri
• ious Juice into Corruption, is a fale Aertion, by a Peron ignorant of the Materia Medica. All the Chirurgeons that I
• ver was acquainted with, were not ignorant of more kindly
<>
• tringents, and better Balamicks than Roman Vitriol. And before ever Mr. Acid was heard of, I my elf have healed Wounds, and that in the Joynts, without Pain, Sorenes or Corruption, by Medicines that might be taken inwardly in coniderable Does. But Roman Vitriol, or any ort of Corroion of Copper with common Acids will caue Pain, and Inflammation in the Wounds, and thence Feavers. Let any body try it on himelf, and he will be atisfied. Now what will caue Pains and Feavers, mut needs be of a Heterogeneous Nature, and I poitively believe, that it was from your Medicine, that your Patients in Flanders had o many ill Symptoms. Nature triving tho' in vain to cat out the extraneous body of Corroded Copper, far more michievous than Lead or Iron, with which Soldiers more mercifully wound one another. That a Feaver is Nixus Naturae to throw off its enemy might perhaps be believed as a great fancy of Great Men, if they could tell us who Nature is. The Late Learned Author of the Treatie of Intermitting Feavers, if what you ay be true, eems to be a Man of great Brain, and the Seat of Agues by him dicover'd, a Witty Invention: I wih you had named him, that I might have een alo what he makes the matter of thee Feavers. I fancy they mut be Maggots, who every time they dicharge their Bellies after repat, drop down their Excrements through the Nerves, which being of an Alkalous Nature diolved in the aqucous Vehicle of the Succus Nervous caues cold, but being received into the Blood, and Heterogeneous to its Acid, caues a Fermentation and Heat, till the Excrementitious Alkali is cat out by the Pores. But as for the Chirurgeons when they have generated Matter; then, for want of Roman Vitriol they mundifie, and o leave Nature oppreed. Roman Vitriol prevents all, and helps all, but I believe Mr. Acid's direction, I would ay his Word is the chief thing in the buines. Another Man uing it will do or tell of no Mi • acles. But what is to be expected in the Wounds of the Lungs, Liver, Guts? Why here a recovery is counted a Miracle by the Ignorant Chirurgeons, who know nothing of the new dicover'd Roman Vitriol. But let any Man judg which method is bet, that which depends upon Roman Vitriol alone, ued alike in all differences of Wonds, or that which relies on all orts of Medicines in the Hands of Artits: Mr. Acid ays in the firt method not one in ten micaries, in the lat not one in ten recovers. I mut tell you Sir, you have not proved by Evident and
well atteted Experiments, you ever cured any one Wounded in thoe Parts; o far are you from curing Nine in Ten. If you could have done what you pretended, I can never believe you would have left your famous Practice. As for topping of Blood, you know well where your Vitriol has failed, but let any one that has a mind to be atisfied of its Vertue try it. But you abue others to ay, they can't top Blood without actual or potential Cauteries Actual Cauteries are eldom ued, or any potential greater than calcined Roman Vitriol. But we know better things, Medicines that may be taken inwardly, they are o mild and wholom, that will top Blood with much more eae, peed afety, and heal far better when that is done, than your calcin'd Vitriol; tho' we never thought fit to Quack with them. Beides every Chirurgeon who deerves the Name, can top Blood in many caes without any Medicines at all. That your Medicines are as agreeing to the Nature of Human Bodies, and the juice by which they are nourihed as Copper is to Fleh, and Oyl of Vitriol to Blood; I readily grant, but that they are indeed friendly, your Practice has not proved, we have only your bare Aertions, ask the Marques of Carmarthen ele. That your Vitriol never caues much more Pain than Spring-Water in the Application, nor any afterwards, takes off former Pain in a little time, uffers no Feaver, Cures all incied Wounds in a few days without Suppuration, Gun-hot Wounds in a little lo •• er time, mot Wounds in the cavity of the Body with all the eae immaginable. I Anwer: Firt, Your Method is hort, and your Se ••• s are known, let whoever will try how weet. Secondly, Why durt you not go into Flanders again? And why did you quit your pretenions to Chirurgery, and take another method of Quacking; leaving your firt new Light, to go out like an Ignis Fatui, and rub your Cat for another, You began to ee at the Seige of Namur, that your Chirurgical ham would not take, and therefore had ome reaon for another Eay. You found the Practice of Chirurgery too plain, and enible a work to deceive Mankind in. The Internal part of Medicine is more abtrue, and you may tell People they have a Fire in their Hearts, which is fed by Acids, long enough e'er they will have them earch'd to diprove you. A Dicoverer you would fain be thought, and a Light to the World; but I don't Quetion, but by that time what has been aid, is well conider'd, you will ee your elf but a falling Star, which appears but in a very little part of his Paage to the Earth. And now Mr. Acid you may go home and think: And if poibly you can be perwaded to become Coniderate and Modet, and what you have Foolihly aid, and done can yet be retriev'd, you will acknowledg me, as I am, no Enemy, but a Friend; tho' I have blunted the Sharpnes of your Acids.
